text:
Robe brune avec une jolie mousse beige malheureusement peu persistante. Arômes malté, fumé, tourbé. Goût caramel et malté. 
Carbonatation fine et abondante. Texture légèrement sirupeuse. 
Bonne bière.

12 oz bottle poured, with a massive thanks to Chris for the bottle. Any time I get to try a top rated beer from a style, Im in. Dark copper brown pour with a thick, cream foam head. Toasty, slightly sweet caramel aroma. Flavor is a good roasted malt, paired with a slightly sweet rich caramel. Slight plastic. Some vanilla. Thick body. Pleasant cream. A delicious beer for the style. Pretty sure it deserves the top spot in the style. Excellent.
12 oz bottle. Pours a medium brown, little bit of off-white head. Aroma rich, caramel malts, maybe some smoked elements. Body medium, creamy, finish sweet and rounded.

Bottle in Seattle. Rainy night tasting. Huge thanks to Chris. Thin off-white foam, deep ochre, amber and mahogany. Deep rosy malt flavor, rather interesting. Nose is copper-metallic, deep freshly milled barley nose. Reminds of kvas in a sense, dark rye bread. Malty sweet resin edge. Pretty tasty for the style. Nice.

Bottle, thanks luttonm! Brown color with ruby highlight and tan ring. Aroma is malty, toffee, caramel, a bit earthy. Taste is caramel, pure malt, earthy again. Medium carbonation. Rather light-bodied. Quite nice.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Pours hazy red brown. Aroma of roasted malts and caramel.

12 ounce bottle from 3 Floyds day at 101 Bottles in Kent Ohio USA. Smell the malt somewhat. Dark cola in color. Little bit of beige head Smooth, hides alcohol very well. Overall an above average.scotch ale and not overwhelming.

Tap at CYO. Pours a deep brown with a finger of foam that lingers. Lots of malt on the nose with caramel toffee and chocolate standing out. Full-bodied with a chewiness to it. More caramel chews on the palate. A good fall/winter beer for sure.

Bottle, 355ml. A dark reddish beer with a small head. Aroma is of wood and dried fruits. Taste is medium bitter with losw sweetness. Medium bodied with faint carbonation and a nice malty finish. Aftertaste of malt and dried fruits, as well as some firewood.

Bottle, 355ml. Clear deep ruby with a large frothy tan head. Grainy aromas of biscuits, oats, bread, doughy yeast. Medium to full bodied, moderate carbonation. Medium sweet, medium bitter. Fruity flavors into a rich malty aftertaste.

Pours dark golden brown, slightly red. Nice layer of creamy head. Nose is malt, caramel, toffee. Taste follows. Big flavors of sweet caramelly malt that are smooth and rounded. Creamy and full on the palate. Delish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sweet grain malts, bread, caramel, molasses, biscuit. Clear, dark brown, medium, creamy, beige head. Light sweet. Intense caramel, biscuit, molasses, bread malts, light wood, light bitters coming up in the slightly dry finish. Beautiful Scotch Ale, nice, intense malts throughout. Keg at brewery, Munster, IN.
A Scottish Ale with a malty flavor. Dark in color, lite aroma, rich but not overbearing.
Pours a dark mahogany with a thin white head. Aroma is caramel and toffee. Flavor is caramel, biscuit, cracker, bread, and some roast. Has a smooth body and tastes sweet. Very good.
Great beer. Tastes like a really malty porter. Sort of like Monday night drafty kilt.

BOD 2/3/16. Dark brown cola like pour that is clear and turns a beautiful garnet under intense light. Outstanding head volume and retention, world class lacing.

Outstanding nose of toasted malt with subtle notes of char and smoke over a caramel substrate with a dark fruit element, probably plum.

Almost medium body with a very smooth texture that has creamy aspects. World class carbonation with a nice effervescent middle and a rollicking finely bubbled prickly finish that tickles the tongue.

The flavor profile is quite outstanding. Intensity is moderate, complexity is outstanding and balance is perfect. In short, this tastes great but doesnt hit you with in your face flavor intensity. This is a malt forward beer that begins toasty, progresses to a moderate sweetness with strong caramel notes and a subtle molasses aspect then flows to the middle. The middle delivers just enough bitterness to perfectly balance with a pine and roast character that delivers a touch a char and a dose of smoke. These flavors slowly fade into the malty finish that brings a slight dryness and a hint of plum. Alcohol remains completely covered and a nut character emerges during the fade which also brings the strongest molasses aspects.

bottle poured into a snifter..burgundy with an off-white head..aroma of dark fruits,malts,caramel..tastes of plums,raisins,figs,biscuits..smooth/dry finish..
good stuff.

A. Ive seen great ones from them, not top as always in the aroma sector.
A. Appearance is just perfect. Dark tan with a perfect dense and foamy half inch super light brown head.
T. Tastes very very good but not great as all they do. Was expecting a greater kick for a scottish.
P. Caramel and a sweet bread and coffee finish, very subtle, very nice.
O. Great balance if course. Can use a little bit more booze in a scottish guys believe me.

12 oz bottle. The pour is a very dark brown with a thin cap of light tan head that stays a pretty dense cap and leaves a pretty hefty bit of solid lacing. The aroma is really sweet. There is a ton of chocolate and caramel malts. A light dark fruit presence is there as well. It's got a little booziness and it's definitely sweet. The flavors are just as good. It's sweet and carries a good scotch ale flavor. The dark fruits really pull this together a bit. There is a sweet malt, a light caramel, and just a hint of metallic sweetness. The mouth feel is excellent. There is a nice creaminess and a soft carbonation that helps not seem a little thicker. The aftertaste is sweet and a little light, but it's malty and good. This isn't a bad scotch ale at all.
Bottle at home, bought in Munich Tap House, 23rd December 15. Chestnut brown, aroma is malty, sweet, caramel. Taste is slick sweet malty, spice. Not bad

Aroma - dark fruit, raisins, figs, some caramel and molasses
Appearance - hazy brown body with a small tan head
Taste - dark malt, toast, some oak chips, fig, raisins, plums and molasses
Palate - medium body, texture is slick, carbonation is average, sweet in the finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Taste is caramel malt smooth, complex, semi sweet notes with hint of spice.
Dark amber/brown in color, clear in clarity. Malt with some vanilla notes to the nose with a hint of hops in the aroma.
Medium body with delicate lace after the creamy head dissipates. One of my go to beer from my buddies from 3 Floyds

Appearance: Clear, deep brown with nice light tan head.
Aroma: Dark malt, sweet, molasses.
Taste: Dark malt, slightly toasted. Smooth, slight wood? Very easy drinking!
Bought: West Lakeview Liquors, 355 ml, $2.99
Info: 16/9-2015

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown beer with a small, brownish head on top. Aroma has massive dried fruits, grapes, apples, some chocolate, some caramel. Very full and rich. Flavor is again quite rich, sweet, fruity. Loads of sweet dried fruits again present in the different levels. Big hint of caramel in the aftertaste. Low level of carbonation, long, sticky sweet aftertaste. Good stuff for real!
12oz bottle. Cola color with little head. Figs, plum and caramel aroma. Less figgy taste, more roasted caramel. Very enjoyable and easy to drink.
Fig and plum aroma with some roasted sweet malts. Taste is fig and plum, vanilla, roasted malt, peat, toffee.
Mahogany pour with a white head. The aroma has slightly roasted aroma with some caramel notes. It has a medium body with average carbonation. The taste is lightly to a roasted and mildly sweet.

Poured into a small snifter at Lizardville. Deep brown color mostly opaque. Small to no head. Aroma is malty with caramel, graham cracker, hint of vanilla and leather. The taste was quite similar yet more muted than the aroma suggests. It was the right mouth balance. Finish is malty and caramel. Pretty good.
Some malts in aroma kind of wine like, similar to new castle but not that bad.malts came through to save it from a 2+ rating. Other than that not much else.
Bottle pour deep mahogany with amber hue and moderate tan head. Taste mostly caramel malt and some sweet fruit. Mid palate light bitter. Light peat. Not as hoppy as most 3f beers.

Dark brown/ruby color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, peat/wood, caramel, & some fruit; Flavor of slight roasted malt, caramel/syrup, dark fruit, some chocolate, and spice; Pretty decent.

Look - Brown, almost amber. Thin ivory head with weak bartender pour. Little lacing. 

Smell - Plum. Malt. Caramel. 

Taste - Plum. Malt. Caramel. Toffee. Tootsie roll. 

Feel - Medium feel. Medium carbonation and almost a carbonation bomb. Very little bitterness on finish and aftertaste.

Overall - Solid brown/Scottish ale. I dont know whats not normal here.

I love this beer. Aroma is malty and peaty. Clear but dark as a scottish should be, tastes like it smells good carmel notes, smooth with some alcohol burn at the end. Overall great beer and one of my favorites from 3floyds

12fl oz bottle poured into a pilsner glass. Deep amber with two fingers of tan head. Almost looks like root beer. The aroma eludes me. Taste is very woody. Lots of sweet malt and just enough hops to keep it from being cloyingly sweet. It's pretty yummy. Thick palate, pleasantly sticky. The 7% alcohol is well hidden. Scarily drinkable. Thanks for this one Jeremy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at bjs Easton. Dark brown pour with lingering off white head. Smoky malt nose and super smooth. May be best Scottish ale I've had. Bready and thick. A few of these and I'd happily be wearing a skirt, Scottish style.

12 oz bottle poured into a Spiegelau tulip. Trade from a friend, thanks Daniel! Dark brown with a finger of beige head. Aromas of dark fruit, caramel, raisins, toffee, toasty notes. Tastes of dark fruit, raisins, caramel, sweet toasted bread, light spice. Medium body with a dry finish. Nice Scottish ale.
Bottle, amber pour white head, nose and taste are caramel, nutty, pretty good

Bottle pour at home, Sent to me from a friend, thanks Jon. Very dark amber pour, kind of roasted aroma, very smooth beer, spice flavors, malt mouth feel, hops but not biter at all. Definitely one of the better Scottish style ales iv had.
12oz bottle. Aroma is of sweet malt. Dark brown color, with light brown head, good lacing. Lots of sweet malt in the flavor. Medium body. Good Scottish Ale, but not the best Ive had.
On-tap, this pours a medium brown color with a slight brown head. The aroma is malty, with a hint of booze. The flavor is rich with malts. Hints of oak and fairly dry. Finishes crisp and clean.
Tap at DLD 15. Dark pour. Very full body. Roasty nose. Tastes pretty hoppy -- dry hopping overpowers the slight scotch malt character underneath.
Robust hops and caramel. Surprisingly good balance despite hop forward Scottish ale. Nice finish.
On tap @ the brewpub.Medium amber, hoppy fruity aroma with underlying caramel malts. A hopped up presentation of the style, as to be expected from these guys. Nice.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Being a Florida boy and living in Indiana now (for the time being), its a pleasure to be able to try this beer. Pours a solid brown with an inch of tan head that retains well. Nose of grains and mushrooms. Big flavors of nuts, syrup, raisins, and toasted wheat bread. Soft/medium carbonation and medium/full body. This is not one of my favorite styles, but this is pretty dang tasty.

Bottle. Another one of those beers I apparently never bothered to rate after years of drinking it. Still one of my favorites anyway. Pours a deep, chestnut brown, billowing off white head, decent retention and lacing. Nose is malty, brown sugar, caramel, maple syrup, vanilla, dried figs. Mouth is silky and malt forward, coffee, caramel, burnt sugar, mild sweetness. Always been one of my favorite 3Fs brews, as well as my favorite Scotch Ale (not from Scotland). Perfect beer for this shitty cold, rainy weather. It is, baseball season after all.

Pours a brownish amber with a minimal head that disappears before you can set the bottle down. 

Faint cider smell and sweet tobacco. 

Malty taste with some bready notes. Not much alcohol present on the taste. Maybe some banana. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.
Glass: Imperial pint glass.
Appearance: Hazy chestnut hue with a tan head.
Aroma: Smokey, fruity, caramel and toast. Hints at being sweet. Touch of brown sugar.
Taste: Prominently fruity with hints of smoke, sweet caramel and bready malts. Possibly oxidized.
Palate: Full-bofied, mildly carbonated.
Overall: A bit too fruity, perhaps oxidized, but not bad. I would like to try this from a tap/

12 oz. bottle bought from the 3 Floyds Brewpub in Munster, IN, poured into a snifter. This is a pretty beer. It pours a deep brown color and looks like a stout in the glass until held up to the light, which reveals it to be a deep ruby red. Tan off-white head that fades after a few minutes. Theres nothing really powerful about the nose on this one. It has a sort of German lager smell to it, but nothing in particular. Tastes like a solid Scotch ale, complete with all the caramely malts and slight roasty flavors. As the description suggests, not very hoppy at all. The brand that 3 Floyds has created precedes this beer, and it does a good job of being a fine flagship beer. Not mind-blowing, but solid.

Pours a cloudy reddish-brown and a massive light tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, molasses, lightly spiced. I first tried this several years ago and became a favorite of mine although its hard to find. I get it when I can, you should too.
Had on tap at 3 Floyds. Somewhat sweet flavors of malt, caramel, and some spice. Carbonation shows. Fairly sweet but light finish. Decent.
Bottle @ Mikkeller, Viktoriagade. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich fruits, nuts, caramel, malt and hops. Sweet finish.
Great smell with maple, malt , floral, color with clear ruby brown, thin crown, smooth dry with a bit high carbonated, right texture, ...good beer
12oz bottle pours a dark brown color without much head. Very smooth Scottish ale. Some molasses and nice mild spice.

From a bottle, pours dark brown with slight ruby tinges, smaller light brown head. Nose is caramel and spice some bread. Heavy body, light carbonation, sweet with balanced finish. This is a great scotch ale.
Rated based on notes taken on 17 Mar 2012 -- This is a great Scotch ale. I would love to try to drink this all night, although I dont think it would end well at 7-8%

Pours a murky brown with a thin mocha head that faded quick. Has a sweet caramel, roasted nut, and malty aroma. Flavors of caramel, toffee, nuts, and rich malts. Medium body that was smooth and chewy on the palate. Very solid brew!

Pours a hazy medium brown with a quickly dissipating khaki head. Aromas of malt and caramel. Taste of malt and caramel with a little bit of chocolate sweetness. Very nice ale. Malty finish. Not overly sweet but very little hop flavor. Nice example of a scottish ale.

12 oz bottle. Caramel and coffee appearance. Head dissipates almost immediately. Nutty on the nose with hints of coffee. Complex aroma, very pleasing. Sour immediately on the tongue. No aftertaste. Very little alcohol flavor. Good malty option.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2014 Bottle: Rich, caramel colored body, hints of ruby at the edges & darker brown towards the center. Head dissipates quickly to a thin beige ring. Aroma contains sweet caramel malt, red apple, prune, & a strange off-note that really reminds me of Robatussin. Light toastiness. Flavor is luckily void of the cough syrup. Hints of toasted malts, caramel, burnt bread, light raisin, hints of apple, some slight nuttiness, & a touch of phenol in the finish. Medium body, just shy of sticky. Light hint of earthy bitterness lingers, but actual hop flavors are muted. Not bad flavor, but the medicinal aroma brings the score down a bit.

Bottle: Many thanks Hackobock: Served in a Chouffe glass:
Medium sized creamy head.
Amazing deep dark ruby red colored beer.
Aromas of malts, caramel, prunes, plus, some toast, bread, cream and some red fruit with meat tints.
Flavour is malty, grainy, roast, bitters, caramel, light herbal, some honey, light bready/dough and some caramelised grains.
Aftertaste is bitter, malty, caramel and some honeey and hay tints.
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, just a bit more than medium bodied.
Quite a tasty beer though a bit in one dimension...
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
On tap at Three Floyd's brewpub. Pours a murky brown with minimal head. Nose shows toffee, caramel, chewy malts. Taste is roasty, chewy toffee, sweet caramel and light malts. Great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
its one of the smoothest ive had. not as strong of a peat malt flavor (maybe it gets knocked for that), but its got a great body and taste. Another well made beer from Three Floyds!"

Julie says smooth with a sweet fruity undertone without hops Julie gives a 4. B.   

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz. bottle, pours a dark amber / mahogany with a small beige head. Aroma brings out toasted malt, toffee and cardboard. Flavour is about the same, with notes of toasted malt and toffee, with a toasted finish. Quite flavourful for the style, perhaps not as fresh as it should be though. Good beer that wouldve benefitted from drinking fresher.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours deep brown, nose is sweet toffee, fruity, taste is similar, rich.

Transfer from BA review on 12-5-13-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer pours a deep brown-copper color with a tiny tan colored head. The head fades very fast, leaving some foam islands on the surface of the brew and a tiny bit of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma is big and sweet with tons of caramel, toffee, and chocolate. Along with these sweeter aromas is a rather decent showing of a lightly roasted bready smell as well as some smells of yeast. A very light hop aroma of an earthy nature is there as well rounding out the smell nicely.

 Taste  The taste begins with a big sweet caramel and toffee flavor mixed with a roasted brown bread taste. Soon after, flavors of chocolate and a bit of some darker fruits of plum and prune come to the tongue sweetening the brew even further. Some cola like tastes later join in as well but at a loss of some of the toffee, diminishing the more buttery smooth sugar flavors of the brew. Toward the end, some hop flavors of an earthy and grassy flavor, as well as a bit of a oaky flavor, come to the tongue. The combination of flavors that is left at the end of the taste ends up leaving a quite sweet, roasty and malty flavor to linger on the tongue. 

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the averages to slightly thicker side in terms of thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is average. The added thickness of the brew is nice for all the roasted and sweet flavors of the brew although a bit less carbonation may have helped accentuate these flavors even more. 

 Overall  This is a sweet and malty brew for sure. A fantastic beer for a nice fall or winter day. Lots of sweet sugary taste with a nice brown bread flavor.

September 4, 2014. Bottle. Pours clear ruby red with a medium tan dense head. Aroma is caramel, nutty, fruity notes. Taste is medium sweet caramel, nutty, light dried fruits. Finish is light bitter and with fruity nutty notes. Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours dark caramel with small tan head. Nose is caramel with a little scotch. Taste is sweet caramel, toffee and some scotch but it hides the alcohol well. Some lasting bitterness in the aftertaste. Nice beer.

Bottle; a reddish brown with a beige head; sweet aroma of toffee, malt, and a hint of nuts; taste is pretty sweet with caramel, malt, toffee, and yeast; finish is sweet not much bitterness with this one; I really enjoyed this one

Serving: Bottle. It pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and a tan head. The nose is pleasantly malty with notes of brown bread, caramel, and a light earthiness. Medium to full bodied on the tongue. A mix of toasted bread, dark caramel, perhaps a touch of chocolate covered nuts, and it finishes with a slightly earthy bitterness. Nice brew.
Nice malty nose and a tight head. Lots of grain and a little bit of hops makes it balanced and sessionable.
Chocolate malts, roasted barley, coffee grounds and a roasty/hoppy aftertaste. Worth checking out!

From a bottle. Pours dark brown with a fizzy beige head. Tastes nutty, like burnt toast, roasted malt, tobacco, and bitter coffee. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like nuts, tobacco, roasted malt, and toast.

Bottle. Pours clear tawny brown with creamy tan head. Aroma is bready and caramel malts, fig, dates, mixed nuts, light vanilla, and faint spice. Flavor is chewy, semisweet malt profile, dark fruit notes, light vanilla, and faint hops; dry, nutty and caramel finish. Medium body and carbonation.

In five characters: malty. Great creamy head, good head retention; medium body, excellent smooth mouthfeel; sweet with a slight hop accent. In yeoman?s terms: delicious and leaves you wanting another sip.
I thought this was a solid Scottish ale. Not much nose.. Hints of smoke and peat. Flavors are all malts with a bit of a watery finish. Nice chewy mouthfeel with dark fruit and peat.
Bottle @ Mikkeller & Friends. Aroma: Malty, fruity, caramel. Taste: Dito + sweetness. Caramel and toffee in the finish.

Bottle @ Mikkeller & Friends, Copenhagen 15/7-14. Malty and fruity with nutty and caramely notes, sweet, chocolate and vanilla, medium body with an oily texture. The finish is bitter and somewhat dry.
Bottle - Cloudy brown pour with a medium tan head. Has a tea aroma to it. Sweet malts, light syrup, medium body.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance is a very dark copper color, almost brown, with a big, fluffy tan head. Aroma is lots of sweet malts and a hint of chocolate. Taste pretty well follows the nose. Its a tad more watery than I expected, but still good. I like it.

Dark brown with a two finger tan head. Aroma is caramel, roasted malt, brown sugar and hops. Taste is roasted malts, nuts, caramel and a hint of hops. A good one but not my style of beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Mikkeller & Friends in Copenhagen. Very malty and sweet with caramel, candy, caramelized sugar and some dried fruit. It reminds me a bit about GD Hibernation. Yet another great beer from FFF.
Bottle Pours very dark brown with tan head. Aroma is very caramel, butterscotch, raisins, figs, nuts, bread. Tastes is medium-bodied, peeted, cereal, bready, lots of raisins. Very good.
Nice rich Scottish. Ruby brown color. Deep caramel malts in the nose. The taste is almost creamy with some smokiness and coffee taste to compliment the caramel.

Ive had this brew many times. Finally getting around to a review. Thanks to Dave for bringing a bottle over. The beer is dark amber with burgundy highlights. Aromas of toffee, brown sugar, yeast. Brown breads and malt with yeast and a touch of hops in the finish. Alcohol presence is moderate. Medium carbonation with a growing sweetness. This is alright.
Caramel really powers this brew. Probably the reason behind the ruby red color and the rich / smooth taste. Good brew. Not really my style but still very enjoyable.

Murky brick-red and brown color. Not a ton of head but that might be my own pour. Almost looks like a still liqueur.

Very unusual aroma for a Scottish: coffee, hazelnut, plums, and raisins. There is a surprising grape sweetness at the end. Really something.

The taste is nutty like a brown ale. It has more berry sweetness with a touch of breakfast blend coffee. There is a cigarette ash finish but I think its because maybe I had a cigarette recently. 

The feel is chewy but also ashy. Somewhere between a brown and a Scottish ale. Somewhat dry but also has a sugary sweetness. Unique.

Havent had a scottish ale in a while so Im looking forward to giving this one a shot. Bottle thanks to gumballdust. Great guy to look to if you want some FFF brews. Pours a rich medium brownish red color with a nice one finger cream color head. Very nice looking beer. Aroma is hints of sweet malts, a touch of hops, caramel, and coffee beans. Nice balanced nose. Flavor is big, rich malt flavors that continue to develop on the palate long after the sip. Sweet, bready malts followed by hints of roastiness and toffee. Delicious. Mouthfeel is rich and smooth. Really enjoyable beer overall.

12 oz bottle. Thanks John Schroeder for sharing this with me! Pours a dark translucent brown with deep crimson hues when backlit. 2 fingers of head quickly settled to a thin wisp of head, and left no lacing. Aroma is understated, but rich: sweet caramel, malt, spice notes - a certain gingerbread complexity. Flavor is malty, with more gingerbread, and generally sweet. Lasting finish, medium mouthfeel, and brown sugar notes linger on the palate.

Pours a medium brown, little bit of off-white head. Aroma rich, caramel malts, maybe some smoked elements. A little bit of resiny character. Medium medium, creamy, finish sweet and rounded. Very nice.
Sweet carmel, roast and enough hop bitterness. Right at the line between Scottish and Scotch ales.
Bottle here in Chicago. Pours a color of cola. Smells nice and malty, decent amounts of caramel sweetness. Taste matches. Good. Very solid, clean finish and light-to-mid mouthfeel.

Bottle, thx to Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: clear brown beer, nice stable beige head.
NOSE: caramel, sweet, alcohol, some mint? Burned malts.
TASTE: caramel, rather sweet, alcohol, noticeable, mostly in the aftertaste.
Probably the best Scottish Ale in my opinion, since I dont really like the style...

Bottle from Mikkeller & Friends @ home.
App: Hazy dark brownish red with a two finger thick beige/greyish brown head.
Aroma: Leather, caramel/burnt sugar, plum, raisin, dark bread, some alcohol, some spice.
Taste: Sweet, caramel, butterscotch, leather/tobacco, peppery, raisin, some well integrated alcohol warmth, peppery finish, licorice aftertaste.
Palate: Medium to bigger body, round moussy and slight spritzy carbonation, slight oily.
Overall: Good scotch, feels accurate and neat, maybe a bit dull.
Thus was the first Floyds Ive had. Really enjoyed it. Great color and lacing. The taste was lighter then expected but flavorful.

Pours deep mahogany into a tulip. White head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Dark caramel and toffee aromas. Soft with dark caramel and toffee upfront turning to mild pit fruit in the lasting finish.

Pours reddish-brown with a thin head. Malty nose with boozy caramel notes. Sweet taste. Pretty good. A bit sweet for me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle - pours a medium brown . Sweet bready aromas with some mild piney hops . Very approachable . Delicious
Malty and sweet aroma and flavor, probably a bit more hop balance then most Scottish ales. Alcohol fairly apparent for low abv. Some fruity characterica as well.

Deep red, walnut color. 1/8 inch head, very slight lacing. Sweet toffee, rich malty taste with no evident hop bitterness. Very good beer, but not the style I normally prefer. Would complement a good cigar.

Solid Scottish Ale. Has that peaty, malty roasted backbone that you would associate with the style, as well as a hint of whisky. Little toffee and butterscotch sweetness to balance things out. Really enjoy the balance with this beer, it is a FFF staple and always enjoyable from the bottle.

Bottle acquired as a throw in from a trade. Date on it was a little over 3 months back. Not sure if that had anything to do with it, but I didnt really care for this. Pours dark brown with a bit of red in it. Small head, not much lacing. Aroma of caramel, toffee, nuts, some wood and possibly plum? Taste was very sweet to me. Lots or caramel hit me and sugar. Not much bitterness, lots of malt. Oily and a syrup texture, too sweet for me.

35,5 cl bottle @ hotel room, Copenhagen. Bottled 03.12.2013
Aroma has butterscotch toffee, sweet malty tones and caramel. A German feeling here. Flavour has toffee, malty tones, some caramel and hints of berries. Rather malty palate. Sweet, malty and decent.

355 ml bottle. Pours a dark brown colour with a small beige head. Aroma of sweet English toffee, grass and some wooden notes. Flavour of sweet English toffee, mild bitterness, smooth maltiness and some earth. Quite thin bodied with some alcohol warmth in the finish. Smooth but a bit too thin for my taste.

355ml bottle from Mikkeller & Friends

Pours reddish brown with a smooth head. Aroma of sweet syrup, caramel, toffee and bread malts. Taste is smooth, sweet and caramel with some nutty notes, breadiness, syrup and fudge. Finish is sweet, sticky and nutty with loads of caramel and mild roastiness. Okay.

355 ml bottle @ hotel room, Copenhagen.
Pours clear dark mahogany color with a small head. Aroma of caramel malts, some nuts, mild bready notes and ripe fruits. Flavor is also malty and caramelly, toffee and bread, some wooden notes with some faint sugary notes on the finish. Nice full-bodied Scottish Ale.
4315

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2014 Served: 12 oz bottle
Look: Pours a dark amber with tan head that falls away to nothing.
Smell: roasted almost smokey. Heavy malt smell. Slight sweetness almost sugary. 
Taste: Hints of coffee, dark fruits and chocolate. 
Feel: heavy, low carbonation.
Overall: not very hoppy. Low carbonation. 
First Drank: home Decatur March 2024

Bottle from Mikkeller Online Shop. Dark brown body, with red reflections and a medium, creamy, beige head. Aroma of dark chocolate, caramel, coffee, raisins, whisky. Taste with about the same aromas, also nuts and some subtle hop fruitiness. Mouthfeel is medium, oily, with a strong carbonation and it finishes moderate roasty-bitter and with sweet/sour dried fruits. Enjoyable! Complex and dark, but with a good drinkability at the same time and a typical "grower", that gets more complex, the more it warms up.
Draft. Dark amber color. Slight sweet malt aroma. Sweet malt with a tiny hop back that fades quick. Least favorite beer from them.
For a Scotch Ale, very good. Sweet sugars/malt aroma. Taste is sugar, somewhat syrupy/caramel, alcohol. Very good beer!
Some light barrel here with a little whiskey malt. Some sugar/caramel sense. Pours brown with decent head and lacing. Finishes with light sweetness. Bottle thanks to bmoosey.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2016 12oz bottle poured into a pilsner glass. The aroma is a pleasant blend of sweet, sugary caramel, a touch of coffee beans, and chocolate covered raisins. There?s a subtle undertone of berries with a slight alcohol, or maybe cough syrup is more appropriate. As it warmed up and settled, I could also pick up a trace vanilla and floral quality to it. It pours a dark brownish-red body with a lightweight, fizzy dark tan head. There?s not much head, and it recedes quickly to a thin ring with a wispy film and it leaves very little lace. The taste is a medium / medium-high sweetness with a slight bitter touch at the finish. The body is a medium / medium full richness with an above average, soft carbonation that has an oily and slick texture. The mouth is mostly a juicy and fruity feel with some grass. The finish is a roasty grain with a resin texture. The mellow resin hangs around a bit for the aftertaste with some figs and candy grape (borderline grape cough syrup). There?s just enough bitter presence at the finish and aftertaste to cleanse the palate, but not damped the fruit sweetness. The linger is brief.
Duft: sødlig, malt, brunsukker, gær, en smule rosin, smag: maltsøde karamel. CitruS rosin, ROM agtig smag
Bottle. Reddish pour with an off-white head. Lots of roasted malt in the aroma and taste with a nice hop balance. Outstanding.
Bottle. Copper colour with small off-white head. Caramel, malts, dark fruits, slightly roasted aroma. Caramel, sweet, malt and dark fruits taste. Medium to full body.
From tap. Noise is medicinal. Toasted malts. Soda bread. Taste is malts and chalk. Well done.

A- Ruddy brown hue with a nice, 2 finger, off white head that dissipates quickly.

S- Hints of fig, indistinct maltiness, very faint dark chocolate notes

T- Flavor is fig, roasted malt, black tea

M- Medium bodied, slick, creamy with medium/low carbonation

D- This really isnt my style but I found this particular example highly drinkable.

Really enjoyed the changing flavor as the temperature changes. Take your time on this one!

Shared 355 ml bottle. Pours amber/bronze with a dirt white head. Nose is malty sweet with raisins and figs. Taste is malty sweet as well, some caramel, toffee and even vanilla. Pretty solid.

Pours reddish brown, clear, thin half finger tan head. Aroma bready, caramel, toffee, dark fruit, fruity esters. Taste big and malty, all flavors in the aroma, caramel, dark fruit and bready notes dominate, no alcohol detectable, slight roast and fruit linger, slight earthy hops in the background to balance it out. Full body, low carbonation, finish slightly on the sweet side. Overall terrific beer, in style, well balanced, yet very complex.

Bottle received in trade thanks to Crajun. Deep toasted brown pour, thin khaki head disappears immediately. Nutty, earthy aroma with notes of brown bread, molasses, slight burnt sugar. Flavor follows the nose, but not nearly as sweet as I would have expected. Nice and malty, well balanced with enough hop on the finish to let you know it's there. A tad flat on the palate, but quite drinkable. 6.5 % abv hidden quite nicely!

bottle from trade with bmoosey. GREAT beer. lots of malt! aroma is malt, nuts, toffee, brown sugar. nice hazy brown pour. taste is similar to aroma finished with enough bitterness to stop this from being cloyingly sweet; loved this!!

Bottle from Save On. Clear amber with nice lasting head and lace. Woody sweet cherry aroma. Roasted caramel sweet cherry sweet fruityness with woody hoppy roasted bitterness. Medium full smooth body. Very good.
Bottle at Jeffrey. Pours deep ruby brown. Nose is light peat and caramel. Tastes of bacon, tobacco, peat, caramel, prunes, malt, with hopping bitterness on finish. Smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle, thanks stfun! Dark brown pour with thin white head. Intense aroma of tobacco, dark malts, molasses, and caramel. Big, chewy mouthfeel. Taste dominated by flavors of raisins, and dark fruit. Sweet throughout, with a molasses, and tobacco finish. This does thin after the first taste or two making this surprisingly drinkable. Great example of why it can be bad to prematurely make assumptions about certain beer styles; I had convinced myself that I didnt like Scotch Ale/Scottish Ales, but damn this is really good.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown amber, clear at the bottom. Subtle notes of beans and coffee. Solid scotch flavor, a little weak on the balance. Smooth though.

Draft at E8ght Ball. Pours reddish brown with a small white head. The aroma and flavor has some caramel, toasted grains/nuts, mild peaty smoke, and has a nice layer of hops. The body may be a touch thin. Easy drinking and a nice example of the style.

Pours a dark reddish brown. Strong caramel malt and rasin aroma. Taste is biscuity caramel malts. Moderate sweet rasin flavor. Palate is well carbonated with sweet almost Chocolatey aftertaste. Very smooth. Very good.  Note: as this warms the fruity, raisiny flavors really come out. Must try.

Pours a nice clear dark amber color with a light tan fizzy head that doesnt last too long. Aroma is nice and smooth of some of that good clean malty caramelness with some bread/yest character mixed in. There seem to be some underlying sweet fruits as well. Flavor is nice of malt, bread, spices and maybe some fruit. Once you let this warm up the fruit and caramel really starts to come out. The mouthfeel is nice and sweet and malty with a little fizziness. Carbonation is maybe above average. Overall this is an great beer.

Thanks to tat2dhllblly for this as an extra.
Poured to NB globe.

A: Brown ale with superb clarity. Little to no head formation. Wait, I just poured more, with the bottle completely upside down...there we go. 1/2 finger peanut head dissipates quickly.

S: I have yet to be less impressed with the nose on a beer. This smells like malt and vomit. Horrible.

T: Thank you lord, the taste does not match the nose! Roasty, toasty. Reminds me of freshly baked dryly salted pretzels. Nice. Good. 

M: medium body with moderate carbonation. Would prefer a little less carbonation on a beer of this style. Leaves mouth slightly dry, but not too bad at all.

D: So long as I was not smelling this, and just drinking it liberally, I could drink this all night, quite drinkable in that regard. Otherwise, I would only purchase this once in a blue moon to try and recall if this is no good. I will, however, likely try this again once I get another bottle.

Serving type: bottle

A clear dark amber ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, classic burned caramel malt with grassy hops, wooden notes, very nice. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt with light nice peaty notes, treacle, very nice. OttBottShare Dec 15 2013.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, no bottle dating. Pours lightly hazy deep ruby red color with a 1-2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of caramel, plum, pear, apple, raisin, toffee, bread, floral, herbal, light pepper, light chocolate, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of malt and yeast ester notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, toast, toffee, pear, apple, raisin, plum, brown bread, light chocolate, floral, herbal, and toast/yeast earthiness. No bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toast, toffee, pear, apple, raisin, plum, brown bread, light chocolate, herbal, and toast/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice balance and complexity of dark malt and yeast ester flavors; with nice robustness and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a moderately creamy and smooth mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice Scottish ale. All around good balance, complexity, and robustness of malt and yeast ester flavors; and very smooth to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Bottle to taster
Nutty, oak, and white chocolate. Clear amber with a thin white head. Whiskey, roasted grain and oak. Whiskey ales aren't my thing, but this was enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours fairly clear reddish brown with a small tan head that quickly dissipates. There is plenty of bubbles in the glass and a film that stays on top. There is a trail of bitterness on the finish. The palate on this is quite nice and adds a nice heft to the experience. This is not a style that I have much experience in but this seems pretty tasty,

Bottle from Mikkeller & Friends. It pours a great deep golden brown with a beige head. The aroma is a full of lovely malt sweetness (caramel, chocolate) with an overlay of citrus. In a side by side tasting with Old Chub. It is smoother than Oscar Bluess Old Chub but that has a slightly fuller mouthfeel. Seriously these are both great examples of the style.

FROM NOTES: July 22, 12
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass and enjoyed with Barnaby Struve of 3Fs. 

A: Caramel, roast, and cream. Its slightly buttery, but its in a good way. 
A: Pours a light brown with dark yellow hues around the edges and about a half-finger of head that settles quickly. Minimal lacing as it drinks.
T: Nice toasted malts with a nice sweet toffee taste as well. Whispers of a coffee blanket in the middle that moves towards a very little citrus fruit finish

O: This beer is beyond reproach. While the USA fights and claws its way to the top of the hop mountain, Ill sit back and drink this omniscient nectar of the Gods and laugh at the futility of such endeavors. When I pray at night, I will thank God for The Bruce, as the course of my life is forever altered due to it and my path in life revealed to me in a malty dream.

The beer pours a nice dark and syrupy ruby-brown with a little head of miniscule, light tan bubbles that fizzle away to the smallest of rings around the glass. In body, the beer is clean of particles, but dark and a little murky, like looking through a bottle of Aunt Jemimas syrup. On the nose, the beer smells richly of bready malts. Brown sugar-coated raisins mingle with soft peat smoke and light bacon scents atop the rich, caramel bread smell which gives this beers nose a backbone. There is a light touch of sweet alcohol, and definite rich biscuit, chocolate, and bread notes as the beer warms. On the tongue, this beer tastes richly sweet with malts. The beer finds balance through light bitter roast and light savory bacon flavors from the smoked malt. Ever-so-soft herbal hops also gently bitter the tongue beneath all of the other tastes, while slightly cloying alcohol does touch on the middle of the sip. On the tongue, the beer feels medium in body with a lightly chewy, yet velvety mouthfeel and a very soft carbonation and prickle on the tongue. As the beer warms, the mouthfeel seems to thin out a little, which is too bad. The flavor begins as sweet raisins and light bacon and peat smoke, slowly moving slightly towards a cider-like flavor and then swiftly to warm caramel bread with a touch of cola. Faint herbal bitterness can be sensed throughout the sip, and the beer finishes with a nice long touch of bacon-like flavors and a touch of chocolate and bread. The aftertaste lingers with smoke and caramel sweetness while the tongue feels oddly scraped and dry. Slight maple syrup flavors can also be sensed. Overall, this is a nice beer with great malty complexity and a terrific transition of flavor as the beer warms. The closer you get to room temperature the more maple syrup notes you get from the malt, but you also get a touch more the herbal hops. A beer to try for sure.
Deep caramelly brown pour, with a small tan head. Aroma of burnt caramel, raisins, malt extract, licorice. Taste is heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness. Full bodied, long finish.

From 12oz bottle.

12oz bottle pours dark brown with a tan head. Sweet malt aroma. Caramel bready malt taste

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2013 People that give this tepid reviews must just not like the style, because if you have any taste or appreciation for scotch/scottish ales you have give the bruce its due. To my taste, its the best of the genre in the world (not counting imperials like backwoods bastard..) Flavor is like oatmeal mixed with toffee, dark chocolate truffle shavings, light bourbon, dark fruit, and hazelnut coffee. One time I actually poured it straight into a bowl of plain oatmeal, and it was the best oatmeal I have ever had.

i dont know if this is overrated or my review is underrated because of the previous beers. this felt quite light tasting and basic aleish.
Bottle from mikkeller and friends, copenhagen. Dark reddish brown color, white head. Aroma is malts, rice, rye bread. Medium body, rye bead, sweet malts, some hops. Its like drinking rye bread.

Excellent chocolate-brown color with a smooth, smokey flavor. The nose is smokey as well with maybe a very faint hint of plumb. The highly regarded Three Floyds brewery delivers in a big way with Robert the Bruce.

Bouteille de 12 oz. Merci beaucoup à Dany! Arômes complexes de malt toasté, caramélisé et terreux. Quelques notes de tabac (le houblon?). Robe brune et limpide, légère dentelle et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, on retrouve une belle extraction de saveurs maltées, toastées et délicatement caramélisées. Malgré tout, le corps demeure relativement svelte, ce qui contribue à rendre la bière facile à boire. Finale délicatement amère. Une création intéressante, qui pourrait également être classée comme Brown Ale.

When Scottish ales are like this I am not that into them. AROMA woody, soy sauce, smoke, earthy, basement aromas, caramel, cereal, roasty, toast, APPEARANCE orange, brown, hazy, minimal head, white foam, TASTE medium bitterness, sweet, musty, PALATE full body, thin feel, fizzy, bitter, dry finish. OVERALL I didnt really care for it and I am Scottish! It wasnt horrible but unless you love Scottish ales I wouldnt recommend it.

Tap at Nano Brew, a nice malty beer to ease off the hop bombs I was drinking, good looking beer, hints of smoke and caramel come through as well.. solid

Bottle to pint.  Looks good; a dark ruby-brown with a small tan head that dissipates quickly. Smells malty with notes of brown sugar, caramel, and a bit of dark fruit. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel.  A good example of the style.
Pours brownish red with tan head that fades quickly. Smells of dark brown sugar fig and camp fire. Tastes hear thy dark fruit with tons of roasted malts. Small hop backbone to balance the malts.
Bottle.  Taste is malt, roasted nuts, caramel and charred wood.  Smooth finish.  Nice.

Iced Tea brown color, bubbly, little bit of head that quickly disappears. Sweet brown sugar scent, some dark fruit, fig, raisin, caramel malt. Salty at first with low carbonation, gives way to a light sweet caramel, vanilla, brown sugar, wood flavor, in mid palate with an after taste of mostly sweet caramel malt, bread. Pretty good session beer, enough flavor to keep me interested but not ground breaking. Does its job well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a very dark amber/brown with a creamy head... Kind of reminded me more of a porter... Very malty.  Was hoping for a little more of a hop taste because of the FFF name, but looking back I probably shouldn't have expected hoppiness in a Scottish ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Medium brown, reddish tint. Medium to small white head, mostly lasting. Aroma is malty sweet, a bit fruity, caramel. Medium body, malt, caramel, and fruitish sweetness with hop bitterness which I found personally to be in good balance here. Roasted malt is present as well. Very enjoyable and easy to drink

hints of malt, caramel, a little sweet.
taste-initially malty, turning to sweet, then caramel, ending with a very slight bitter aftertaste.

Great beer! I sampled it on draft. Im not a hop lover. I like malt centered beers best... And this one suits me very well! Theres not much aroma, but the taste....sweet malt hits you immediately, followed by an immediate hop bitterness that is nicely balanced. The head was thin and dissipated quickly. The 7% is well hidden in this brew. I will be drinking this again.

Pours a dark reddish-brown, with minimal head & medium carbonation.  Aromas of coffee, caramel, nuts & hops.  Flavors of caramel, bread, coffee, chocolate.  Sweet and slightly spicy.  Very full-bodied and tasty, indeed!

Bottle thanks to rxeight. I love the look ok all of the FFF beers I have had so far. From bottle to pour they have been near perfection. This is no exception. While this isn't my favorite style it still was a joy to drink. I don't think I'll seek it out but I'd gladly drink this again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark mahogany with a thin off white head. Nice roasted malt/toffee nose. Creamy malt is the name of the game here.Very smooth on the tongue , hint of vanilla, followed by some subtle hop bitterness. Best Scottish ale Ive ever had. Worth the asking price.

On tap, pours a medium brown with frothy light tan head. Aroma is malty and roasty little bit of chocolate. Flavor is earthy hop and good balance of base malt with the sweet crystal and roasted malts there is a lot of malt complexity but it works well. Full body Medium carbonation and smooth mouth feel. Overall I like this beer a lot very drinkable with interesting malt flavors I like this one a lot, great brew.

Clear brown with some hits of red on the edges. The nose is of toasted malts, honey, semi-sweet chocolate, and sherry/booze. Flavor is of toasted biscuits, toffee, caramel, and just a hint of alcohol. Very smooth mouth-feel and leans heavily towards the malty side. Slightly over carbonated, but not bad. Medium bodied.

Pours a deep brown/red with a medium off white head that settles slowly into a thick, creamy film.  Aroma is somewhat muted...some roasted malt, hint of hops, not much going on here...kinda weak to be completely honest.  However, the flavor is much nicer...lots of roasted malt, some hop bitterness, toast/biscuit...pretty good.  Palate is very nice and creamy - very smooth - top notch!  This is an odd one...I really like it overall, but had some problems breaking it down - maybe a re-rate some day.

Murky maple wood color. slight gusher, 1 finger tan head. Smells of burnt malts, oak and amber and birch syrup. Taste is very sweet, not boozy, nice balance between malts and bitterness. Loving the sweetness but one bottle is enough.
Amazing beer:.:....................one of the best scotish style ale Ive had. ,...............

The aroma of this beer is subtle, but the vanilla and nutty hints are to die for. The beer itself is purely brown with a minimal white head, and, once sipped, the beer is of a medium sweetness, a slight saltiness, and a slight hint of umami. Furthermore, the palate of this beer is quite nice, for the medium body, thin texture, soft carbonation, and long finish coat your mouth in a way that leaves you wanting more of this beer.
Brownish red with an off whote head. Aroma of malt and roasted nuts. Taste is malty with caramel poured over a pine cone. I like this beer.
Pours dark amber white head. Aroma is very malty, little roasty. Lots of rich malty flavors, caramel, toffee, some roast malt. Little piney hop bitterness but not much. Pretty good.

Great aroma. Very tasty.                         
                                                                

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From bottle - minor head - nice clear redish hue taste is OK but lacks character a bit weak for a scottish ale needs more substance
Bottle. Pours dark copper with no head. Aroma is lots of malts and spice. Flavor is malt forward with nice spice to finish.  Solid.

Dark brown color with a light tan head. Nose of sweet malt and hint of caramel. Nice mouthfeel with medium body. Initial taste of sweet which moves into a nice hoppy bitter that lingers. Nice lacing on the glass as you drink. Seems a mix of Scottish ale and German märzen.  Good

This has been my favorite beer since I first had it in July last year. The flavor and finish are exquisite. The presentation grand, and the bottle simply awesome! Thank you- 3floyds

Semi clear brown with ruby highlights.  Decent head and little lacing.  Aroma of caramel maltiness with hint of brown sugar and bread.  Taste sweet malt and some dark fruit with burnt sugar flavor. A bit of spiciness.  Full mouthfeel but semi dry.  Good Scottish ale.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Pours translucent brown with red and orange highlights. Little to no head.  Very light smell of malt with some roasted characters and a slight sourness.  Taste is basically malt and hops.  A little roasty and a little bitter, in harmony.  Some bread and a little sweetness underneath.  Mouthfeel is medium with some slickness.  Not terribly complex but smooth and well balanced.  Makes a good casual drinking beer.  Very good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Small off white head, dark amber color, good lacing, mostly diminishing head, malty aroma, good beer
Finger thick slow fading head, dark caramel brown.  Bready nose, with some smoke and toffee.  Good scotch ale...not outstanding-wonder how fresh this was?  Probably the least impressive FFF Ive had.

Wonderfully roasty flavors, smoke, peat. Lots of malt sweetness. Pours a nice amber brown. Had it on tap at World of Beer Easton. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Wow, talk about exceeding expectations. This isnt cloying or overly malty at all. Delicious. Yay 3F!
botle. pours brown with solid white head. aroma of bakery bread and hops. taste is fresh baked bread with grassy hops. sweet caramel finish
Pours a dark reddish brown. Aroma is malty and deep. Taste is malty with a touch of smoke and a clean finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 Purchased a somewhat pricey 6pack at a local Chicagoan grocery store. Absolutely adore the label artwork. Reminds me of a flyer one pick up at a rave. But the beer itself pours a rusty brownish-red with an ascending fluffy tan head that left a fair amount of lace on the brim of the glass. Started off three to four fingers then gradually sank to just a fingernail in length. The description wasnt lying: it is indeed malty on the nose and in the mouth. Smells instantaneously caramelized with hints of raisins, toffee, fudge, pumpkin seeds, soybean oil, rose water, hibiscus flowers, salad greens and brown pottery clay. Tastes fulfilling which was of  course on the malty-side: refined sugar, leather, caramel, and buckwheat honey. It then balances the sweetness with vegetation, dandelions, wood and copper. Ends slightly tart and buttery.
Hands down best scotch ale Ive had! Just wish I could get it more frequently! All the toffee and caramel in the aroma and taste/palate! Spot on!
19th March 2011Clear brown beer, no real head. Nice depth of malt, not quite barleywine territory but getting there. Trace of hops. Mild carbonation. Quaffable malt led beer.

Golden brown with a small pale head. Aroma is raisins, muscatelle, plum, cooking chocolate, hint of sherry, caramel and dark fruits. Sweet on the palate with a lot of well balanced fruitiness and a hint of citrus hop. Taste is raisins, fig, malt, dates, ice wine. Delicious.

Pours a clear ruby brown with no head. The nose is toasted malt and honey. The pallet is biscuit, malt followed by a little bitterness/astringency and finishes with a malty sweetness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 oz bottle from the brewery. A solid scottish export style, strong malty taste, dark and clear appearance. One of my favorite winter ales.
dark caramel color. Thick one finger white head. Caramel malts on the nose. Excellent caramel malts, a touch of finishing bitterness. With neither of those being overpowered.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2013 Pours an ultra clear dark amber color with a perfect 1 cm head that lingers a bit and never completely goes away.  Aroma is mostly caramel and toasted malt with hints of chocolate, figs, tobacco, cherries, and bread.  Taste is great.  Malt forward, mostly caramel and toast.  The finish brings out a light chocolate and fruity taste.  Very smooth and creamy, perfectly soft carbonation.  This is not a style I usually like so Im surprised I like this so much.  Really good and easy drinking beer.
Bottle.  Pours deep brown, lightly cloudy, thin beige head.  Lightly roasted, sweet dark malts, chocolate, plums, toffee.  Really solid for a Scottish ale.

Tap @ PP Carlsbad.  Aroma is malt, soft dark fruit ,and light, dry peat.  Taste is a nice combination of roast, sweet fruit/malt, peat, and caramel.  Smooth mouthfeel and very balanced from start to finish.  Awesome.
pint at Heaven On Seven, Naperville. caramel, herbs, very deep amber, cloudy, minimal head, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, lively.
I havent been a fan of Scottish Ales, but this one is pretty good. Dark chocolate aroma with a very rich taste.  Not what I expected, but Three Floyds can polish a turd

Bottle to nonic pint. Pours deep brown with malty aroma. Taste is malt bomb, some chocolate, alcohol at the end, smooth bitterness that is present throughout. Feels more like a wee heavy and higher hopped then class but tasty.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Another enjoyable experience from Three Floyds! A fun little tangy scotch ale. By no means their best work, although a lot of fun to drink. A beer that you could honestly sit down and have a six pack of. Pours with a sizable, foamy, head. Very enjoyable.

Pours murky brown with a tiny beige head. Smells of roasted malts. Taste is malty, bready, like sourdough, and has a very tiny touch if citrus tang. Medium bodied with a smooth, silky texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Three Floyds Robert the Bruce finishes with a nice, malty sweetness.

Aroma of roasted coffee and malt and dark cherry.  Pured into a specialty pint glass, dark beige clingy head whcih never really disipates. First appearence is dark bron, when held up to the window its a dark mahogony red which you can still barely see through, very clear opacity too. Creamy rich entrence, hops right off the bat , and even throughout. Flavor of choclate covered raisens to me, but dark choclate not the sweet kind. Very well balnced, full bodied, alchohol warmth comes in at the end but is not harsh. It is almost November here in Chicago, and cold and grey, so this really fits the season. Excellent all around.
UPDATED: APR 3, 2013 Awesome! Very rich, copper color; perfect blend of hops & malt. My first Three Floyds!

Pours a murky brown with 2 finger head and medium lacing. Rich caramel malt with mild and not overwhelming scotch undertones. Bready. Tobacco. Grassy hops. Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Mild bitter and mild sweetness which continues throughout and finishes out the beer with medium length.

Aroma- massive caramel, some dark fruits, breadiness, roasted notes
Appearance- deep dark red/brown, slight white head
Taste- some caramel, cinnamon, bread, sweetness
Palate- fair body and mouthfeel, all solid here
Overall- Good for a Scottish Ale.  Aroma was quite enticing and the taste was better than most that Ive had.  That being said, it didnt blow me away and I wouldnt seek it out again.

On tap at Brew Pub.  Pours a dark deep chocolatey brown color with a creamy white head that settles to a thin cap.  Sweet malt aroma with a bit of fruitiness and earthiness.  The taste is sweet and very malty. Caramel and smoked peat dominate the flavor, with the creamy sweet malt behind them. A bit of bitterness shows up in the finish.  Full bodied and very smooth.

Had a 12 oz. bottle of this at Emersons Ale House. Served in a pint glass.

A: Pours a solid brown body with dark, see through amber edges. a 1.5 finger light khaki head forms on the pour and stick around for quite sometime. It leaves nice sticky and splotchy lace once it receded to a thin collar.

S: Sweet toffee malts with subtle undertone of light bitter bakers chocolate. There is that nice little pop at the end of the typical grapefruit/citrus like hops that FFF imparts on a majority of its brews.

T: Nice toasted malts with a nice sweet toffee taste as well. Slight is slight coffee blanket in the middle that moves towards a very little citrus fruit finish.

M: Medium bodied with a nice carbonation and prickly mouthfeel on the palate.

O: A very good scotch ale. I enjoyed the slight hoppy undertone Ive come to love throughout the FFF beers. Very well balance.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-11-2011

Pours dark brown   aroma of caramel and chocolate   flavor is excellent, chocolate caramel with a mildly roasty finish that has a subtle bitter english hop bite. Body is perfect for the style  great beer ! And i dont normally prefer this style
Ahhhhh.   Robert the Bruce.  I tend to grab this anytime I can find it.  A great Scottish Ale.  On par with Founders Dirty Bastard, which I also love for its complex, engaging flavor.
Sweet malts, fruity, chocolate, maybe a little caramel. A little flat, still smooth.

Pours a brown, copper color. Thin white head. Amazing aroma with notes of caramel, spice, sweet malt and resembles a malbec. Nice body but not thick. Taste has a nice sweetness from the malt but not overdone. Damn good Scottish ale and I would buy this again

Ruby brown body with off white head. Aroma malt sweetness,  little smokiness and acidic notes. Taste caramel awesomness, cola, nice slight bitterness finish. Medium body, crisp and Deliciousness that sticks around. Mathematical Scottish ale!

Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Nose is mossy wood, brown sugar, soy sauce. Taste is sweet with good bitter. Mouthfeel is crisp and clean, medium body with a long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Rich brown without too much head. The aroma and flavor were very clean malt with hints of smoke, chocolate and spicy and aromatic hops.  Its not overly sweet or heavy on the palate. Very well balanced and super drinkable.

Bottle from Breeze Thru. Pours tannish brown with a slight head. Aroma has caramel, toffee and hints of chocolate. Taste is sweet caramel, some roasted malt, brown sugar and alcohol. Finishes sweetly long. This one will need to be a retry sometime, as I have had better versions of this, I am certain.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 Pours dark ruby with 1 finger fluffy white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is roasted malts and dark fruits. Taste starts roasty but fades to a wonderful caramel note and a prominent alcohol punch. Amazingly smooth palate with just enough carb to keep things interesting.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
6-pack from brewery.  Pours almost clear black, with thin lacing.  Aroma of smoke, spruce, and dark fruits.  Mild smoky taste, with dark fruit, nuts, and a mildly bitter finish.  Medium-bodied.

Pours a clear dark amber with a decent tan head.  Aroma is all roasted malt.  Taste is caramel, roasted malts and just a touch of coffee. It's a very nice scotch ale and is very drinkable.

Clear dark amber with persistent off-white head and swirls of lace.  Taste begins with semi-sweet caramel malt that grows, then allows a little bitterness at the finish.  A big taste, somewhat bloating, but quite drinkable.  Recommended.
Gotta love this beer and love the name. Very affordable and tasty.  What else can I say I am Robert the Bruce.

A: Smells like roasted barley and dark fruit.

A: Pours the color of maple syrup with a lasting pillowy head.

T:Roasted barley, dark fruit, booze, and bubblegum

P:Medium bodied with low carbonation. the finish is slightly harsh and dry.

O: I like this beer and would have it again.

Opaque deep walnut brown pour with very dense, very tall beige head. Scents include malt balls and licorice/sarsaparilla and has a chalkiness to it.  Taste is well blended, reminds me of a brown ale more than a scotch ale. Not too strong and ever so slightly watery. Mostly malt and a little roasty. No scotch effervescence to speak of. Finish is basically just bitter but not brutally so, and not piney.

An above average beverage. This is a very relaxing drink. It goes down nicely, has flavor, and wont hurt ones palate. To me this is a beverage anyone can respect, from the avid beer lover to the guy who just likes to have a beer. If youre into 3 Floyds Im sure you will not mind drinking this.

Ar: TOASTY!
Ap: Deep ruby/brown
T: Interesting - toasty caramel malts, slight alcohol - bitter
P: Light to medium body - lively carbonation
O: Great scottish ale, just great.

Pours dark brown with a thin head. Aroma of caramel malts and dates. Taste follows, lots of dark fruit, really malty, a bit sweet. Not very enjoyable to drink, not a great representation of the style

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Pours deep amber with ok light tan head. Aromas of toffee, toast, caramel, pitted fruits and spice. Med light body, complex muddy malt profile with a touch of cola on the semi sweet finish.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Three Floyds XV Anniversary imperial pint glass.

Pours a reddish dark amber bordering on brown with a two finger off-white head. No lacing evident as the head recedes. Notes of caramel, chocolate, and roasty malts on the nose. Opens with the taste of toffee, cocao nibs, bread, and a bit of smoke. Roasted malts join in as the hops that have been present, but in the background, surface to add a bite of bitterness on the finish. Smooth Medium body and a medium level of carbonation. Malty goodness, but not quite as peaty as most other Scottish/Scotch ales.

Poured deep amber. Bottle claims to be a Scottish ale rather than a scotch ale. Some carbonation in taste I wasn't expecting. Not as rich malt as I hoped. Not bad. Not great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A very sweet and malty beer, lots of toffee, some biscuit, very forward with the alcohol, low bitterness and a slightly sour finish. Expected more from this.
Warm malty aroma, maple and straw. Dark brown/red colour, with white head (fades). Taste is sweet and malty, dried fruit. Medium palate.

It poured a clear ruby color with an off-white head.  The aroma was of toasted malts with a sweet caramel note. A little touch of bitterness, but overall pretty crisp. The taste was similar to the aroma. This was really tasty.

Pours a brown with a small beige head.  Aroma is malty, with nuts, caramel, toffee, and bread.  Flavor is well balanced.  Caramel and toffee on top, with coffee and roasted nutty undertones.  I notice hints of chocolate as well.  Has a bit of a hop zip to it as well.  Medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation.  Slightly bitter with a nutty aftertaste.  This is different than most of what Three Floyds offers, but still quite good.

Bottle...  Poured deep reddish/mahogany with an off-white head.  This was awesome.  Im not typically a fan of the style but FFF nailed it here and wouldnt mind drinking this regularly.  Dark, toasted sugars like caramel and coffee.  Worty with a solid bitterness for a lively palate.  Dark fruits, and dense dessert like qualities.

Pours a ruby red with a small off white head.  Aromas consist of heavy malt, some subtle smoke and a cherry sweetness that is very pleasing.  Taste is smooth, sweet but not cloying.  It is full bodied.  A very nice ale, indeed.

Bottle at the Mikkeller bar Copenhagen. It's nice when you smell a beer and it's that impressive that you need to put it down right away. The aroma is something special. A little on the sweet side with a caramel aftertaste. A really awesome beer and nothing like any Scottish ale I've ever tasted. Will drink again!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at Mikkeller bar.  Pours dark brown with a small off white head.  Aroma is massive caramel, toffee, toasty sweet malt, chocolate and nuts.  Flavour is medium sweet and light bitter, big on the toffee with a nutty background.  Full bodied with moderate carbonation.
Toasted bread and chocolate aroma.  Light, brownish red appearance,  Not much head, but a near perfect balance of bitter and sweet.  Tried with Jay in 2012.

Brewed w/rye & 35 pounds of Thai palm sugar per batch. The sugar brings a fruity, vanilla-like flavor rather than much sweetness. A new hop variety called Summit is really showcased here; the beer is heavily dry-hopped w/Simcoe. 7%

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Typical for a Three Floyds in that the amount of ingredients is off the charts, this time with a special focus on slightly sweet malts. And I swear the warmer it became, the more it smelled like a Tootsie Roll. A very nice draught beverage.

On tap in a shaker. Pours a brown ruby with a thin beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is barley, toasted malts, caramel, and molasses. Taste is dark malt, slight coffee, smoke, and citrus hops. Thin mouthfeel and no alcohol present. Real good.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2013 Has some really nice sweet caramel/toffee notes. Taste is similar to scent with a nice roast backbone, awesome beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great beer. While I find many of the 3F beers to be too hop dominated, this was a nice surprise...a little sweeter, with a strong malt presence. It tasted more like a great brown ale with a scotch subtlety than a true scotch ale...either way, Ill take it, it was delicious.
12 oz bottle. Pours dark ruby. Rich hops, fruits and nuts dominate the flavors throughout. Alcohol is also prevalent throughout. Stronger ale than expected. One of the better scotch ales Ive had.

Bottle at home. Poured a clear brown with a red tint and small khaki head that quickly dissipated. Aroma is hoppy, vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, cocoa, and nuts. Taste is vanilla, caramel, malt, burnt sugar, roast, and coffee, with a lightly bitter finish. Mouthfeel is creamy with medium carbonation. Very smooth and easy drinking with a lot of complex flavors and aromas, almost like a sessionable barleywine. Another winner from Three Floyds.
Not as smooth as you might hope, and very hoppy, almost to the point where it overpowers any other flavors.

Bottle. Pour is dark plum shade. No head but had a small amount of syrupy lacing left behind. Aromas of caramel, walnuts, vanilla, rye bread, toffee, floral hops. Taste is of roasted malts, chocolate nibs. Boozy and warming in the belly. Finishes mildly hoppy bitter. Excellent scottish ale from 3 Floyds.
Bottled. Small head.  Red brown coloration.  Aroma is mostly malts and the taste is a deep sweet malt. Light bitter finish.

Bottle @ MIkkeller Bar. Deep red color with no head. The nose is sweet cherry malt, deep nuts, spices, christmas cake and banana bread. The taste isd tingling light spiced fruits, mulled wine, jammy spices. Light body, prickly carbonation. Overall, a decent beer. Though I must admit my palate was knackered after a massive session.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2012 Pours a reddish, medium brown, moderate head and carbonation. Aroma is pretty low, consisting of subtle roasted malt notes, and not a hint of hops aroma. Flavor much different than I was expecting, consisting of fairly light roasted malt and only a touch of hop flavor. Very balanced. May be true to style, I dont know, but a bit too simple for my palate. Still, glad to have finally tried this one.
Great Beer. Bruce has a great overall taste. Malts are sweety yet strong. Smooth finish leaving you wanting more.
UPDATED: OCT 1, 2012 One of the better scotch ales that I have had. No one flavour dominated the nose or palate. Very complex and very well balanced.

Flaska på Mikkeller bar. Brunröd, lätt grumlig öl med lätt beige skum. Dofta av malt och kola med lite jästa frukter. Söt smak med kryddighet, malt, lätt rostade toner och fruktig alkohol. En riktigt fin öl.
deep amber with medium head. sweet and very malty. hint of caramel. alcohol noticeable, but not unpleasant.

Bottle. Pours a rich amber/brownish color. Aroma has a ton of caramel and malt in the nose. The taste continues the malt and caramel throughout the beer. Finishes with some nice malt flavor as well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 355ml.
Pours clear brown, with good beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of malt, caramel and toffee. Taste is of malt (roasted), toffee, alchool. Sweet. Bitter finish. Full bodied, nice balance. Surprisingly rich, nice mouthfeel. Malty.
Yep, everything I thought it would be. Not available in my area. So it was a treat. Sweet and rich with a small alcohol background.
Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Redbrown beer with a offwhite head. Malty, toffee aroma. Malty and toffee flavour with some nutty notes. Really a nice beer :-)

On tap at local restaurant,  pours a reddish brown with a decent off white head, aroma has some caramel and malt, straight forward,  the flavor is sweet on the front end with a heavy finish of malt, kind of reminds me of a black olive, not blown away by any means.

Bottle 355 ml. Pours light brown with copper reflect. Little beige head. Aroma: malt and caramel. Taste is roasty. Alcohol is discernible. Bitter aftertaste. Creamy texture, medium bodied beer.
Bouteille 355 ml. Brun pâle avec reflets cuivrés. Léger collet beige. Arome de malt et de caramel. Lalcool est perceptible. Arrière-goût amer. Texture crémeuse, ronde en bouche.

Bottle 355 ml. Thanks to dountcounttoday! Pours copper with a thin light brown head. Aroma of malt, caramel, toffee, roasted/burnt malt. Taste is sweet. Caramel, toffee, roasted/burnt malt and spices. Slight bitterness. Mouthfeel is creamy but end dry due to bitterness. Alcohol is not well hidden. Nice caramel/toffee bomb! A very good beer!

In bottle at Craigs. Pours an amber brown colour with a lacy beige head. Aroma of treacle, caramel, grassy hops and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Mildly bitter with lingering treacle and Weetabix malt. Nice.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2012 Clear brown pour, small head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt and peet.  Taste of Caramel, peet, Raisin, Fig, a slight bit of chocolate, fairly earthy.  Lower carbonation.  Very drinkable.

(Bottle) Pours deep reddish brown with a sand colored head. The aroma holds dark bread, toffee/caramel, roasted nuts, herbs, raisins, prunes and figs. Light oxidized and robust nose. The flavour near medium sweet, light bitter and tiny acidic with notes of dark fruit, dark bread, caramel/toffee, herbs, bread spices, nuts and earth. The mouthfeel is soft, round, chewy,  and light sticky with a light carbonation. Syrupy, earthy and dark fruity finish. Medium bodied.

Had a full pint of this from the draft at the brewery. Poured a clear ruby color with a slightly off-white head. Aroma was toasted malts, with a slight sweet caramel note. Touch of bitterness, but overall a pretty crisp and enjoyable brew. This is pretty darn tasty.

Pours a rusty dirty brown to dark tan color. Nose is malty, sweetly and fruity. No head, and poured in a sniffer. Taste is all flavor, malty sweet and no bitterness. Finish is dry and short, refreshing and easily drinkable. A great. Scottish Ale from one of the finest microbreweries in the nation. Hats off once again to the team. Quaff Score ( drinkability with hearty enjoyment ) 9 / 10  Bravo !!!

Pours amber with almost no head and sweet aroma of malts and fruit. Taste is sweet and toasty, of malts, caramel, bread, and fruit notes with a dry, sweet, malty finish. A lot of flavor in this brew, very good, smooth, drinkable scottish ale.

12oz bottle. deep brown in color with some red highlights. tan head that doesnt last long. nice lacing throughout. roasted malts, toffee, caramel and bread on the nose. malty sweet flavor with some smokey hints. lingering finish.
Deep brown, a bit of red in the light.  Aroma of caramel malt and some earthiness.  Tons of malt, but really really nicely balanced.  Sweet caramel with some peat and chocolate.  I really enjoy this.
On tap at Jimmy Greens.  Pours deep brown, with ruby hints.  Big frothy light tan head.  Big smoky malt taste and aroma.  Solid Scotch ale!
Pours brown..brown head..  good aroma of caramel..taste is malty toffe. ?.good

Bottle. The pour was a deep mahogany brown with an average sized (1-2 finger) light tan creamy head that reduced in the first few minutes down to a thin cap and medium collar, which in turn created some excellent sheets of sticky spotty lace.

The aroma was nice and robust with a roasted biscuit malt and a sweet yeast with notes of caramel, a mild coffee, light chocolate, dried fruit (figs and dates) and a mild alcohol tinge.

The taste was a very smooth malty sweet with a hint of caramel and a mild coffee presence at first, with the finish being sweetly acidic and having a good dose of dried fruit and a decent alcohol ending. The flavor lasted a good long time after the swallow, leaving behind a mild alcohol fruity taste.

Mouthfeel was medium in body and had a creamy dry texture with a moderate carbonation.

Overall a nice bold fruity sweet Scottish Ale with more of an alcohol presence than the ABV suggests...

Pours a dark mahogany brown.  Aroma of malt with hints of caramel.  Taste the same as it smells
of, strong malt and caramel flavor.  Very delicious.

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber/brown.   Medium off white frothy head.  Some lacing.  Stong aroma of peat.  Lots of malt.  Flavor of caramel, peat, and moss, just what youd expect.  One of the better scotch ales that Ive had.
12 oz bottle pours amber with a tan head.  Aroma caramel malts, yeast , and a bit of pine.  Taste is the malts, a little grassy and a bit of hops.

12 oz bottle into a 3F pint glass.

A - Pours a dark brown body that lets some light through. Thick and fluffy four finger high light khaki head settles down to some really dense foam.

S - Roasty caramel malts, coffee beans, caramelized sugar, toffee and some smoke. 

T - Roasty and smokey. Plenty of caramel malt with a peaty and earthy finish. No hops detected but a slight candied sweetness is present. Fairly dry but highly carbonated. Light to medium mouth feel.

O - Tatsy, but not very inspiring. It is a really easy drinking malt and smoke forward beer though.
Chocolate and coffee are the first things that come to mind.  Certainly a nice roast.
Medium amber color lighter than expected for a Scottish ale. Slightly bitter carmel flavor with a hint of vanilla. Not the best Scottish Ale I have had, but is a good one.

Hazy reddish amber pour off white head ..... aroma of toasted, biscuity and caramel malts .... taste is of sweet caramel malts, toasted, biscuity, light chocolate and lightly nutty ... finish is dry and malty ... abv hidden well good brew easy drinking
UPDATED: APR 24, 2012 Bottle @ Mikkeller. Reddish, transparent brown. Caramel, malts, bread. Sweet, of course. Light on the palate, smooth.
Lots of roasted caramel flavors coming across in the aroma. Pours a darker brown with a quickly disappearing head. Somewhat hoppy taste that sticks with you.
12 ounce bottle. Very sweet and lots of caramel flavor. Scottish ales often have a chemical flavor, but this one was very drinkable. Sweet and floral aroma.
Rich, malty and perfectly hopped this beer is one of my favorites because of the smooth and extremely balanced flavor.
Bottle pours a clear red with a thin off white head. Scent is sweet caramel. Taste is same with a bready, grassy note.

Pours a deep amber colour, almost brown, clear with a small creamy tan head. Aroma is predominately of caramel sugar and malted grains, some vanilla and a little alcohol scent as well. Taste is quite sweet through the finish with a few bitter notes. Medium body, soft carbonation, and a smooth creamy mouth feel. A very enjoyable beer, excellent overall.

This is the thickest of the Scottish ales I've tried thus far. Great dark black color that fades to a rich red amber at the bottom of the glass. Great head retention, which gives it a nice feel down the throat. Very malty flavor which probably explains the thick feel. Very solid beer that gets more complex as it warms.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is straight malt which is great! Smooth overall taste very much a roasted finish. Great drinker with a little kick.

Bottle from Matt McQ. Pours dark bown with nice head that lingers. nose is mild with bready notes followed by a nuttiness. first sip is malty delicousness. perfect balance of hops and malt. finish is smooth. great beer!

Location: 12 oz bottle from jcos, 3/14/12


Aroma: The nose has lots of sweet malts, caramel, roast, chocolate, yeast, and bread

Appearance: This one pours a brown color with some hints of red, and a small white head

Flavor: Tastes fairly sweet, theres a good amount of malt complexity, the bitterness is non-existent

Palate: The body is medium, the mouthfeel is a little sticky, average carbonation, and a roasty finish

Overall Impression:
