This beer is really freaking malty.  It is rather sweet without really any bitterness for balance.  This wasnt bad, but it certainly wasnt my favorite Three Floyds brew.

A - pours nice hazy red mahogany with high white tight bubbled head. S - very malty aroma, some grains, barley perhaps. Hints of dried fruits. M - medium bodied, high carb brew. Very bitter on the back end. Lingers. T - strong malts up front, caramel and toffee. Grassy, grainy, dried fruits on the palate. Quite bitter. Lingering bitter un appealing ending. O - complex and deliberate, but too bitter and the end tastes don't work. 6

Bottle. Medium brown, a little muddled hue. The malt character is pleasant but it's not well developed enough and has not enough sweetness. Has too much sawdust character. But it's balanced and drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a style compliant dark amber brown with thin tan head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of toasted malt, dark dried fruits, slight caramel.  Flavor matches well and is enjoyable, but nothing I am ever going to crave.

Robert the Bruce has a lot of depth in flavor and a wonderful aroma.  I am not a Scottish ale drinker usually but this is a still a delicious ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a clear brown with an off-white head. Sweet with some malty dryness. Malty aromas of caramel. Hints of perfume.

Pours a hazy mahogany with ruby highlights and thin tan head which quickly dissipates. The carbonation is moderate and mouth-feel is smooth. The nose is caramel malt, dark fruit, vanilla and Oak?. Taste is caramel, roasted malt, burnt sugar,  tangy dark fruits, good bitterness and vanilla towards the end. Its well balanced and very drinkable.

Pours dark Mahogany with very little head. Smell is sweet and malty, almost a bit spicy. Scottish smell for sure. Some black licorice. Taste is super malty, sweet maple. Woody texture. Wet and viscous at the same time. Super drinkable. Outstanding.

Pours a ruby/tea colour with a decent tan head. Aroma is malt, slight hops.  Taste is nicely roasted, smoky, a slight bit of coffee and dark chocolate.  a bit sweet, a bit bitter,  well balanced. like this one a lot.

Pours a dark mahogany with red edges, topped with a one to two finger creamy tan head, leaves webs of lacing. Roasty aroma, dark bread, caramel, and earthy, lots of dark malty notes.  Roasted taste, full of malt - nice and robust, toast, biscuit and leather, the ABV does not show itself at all.
Figues, dattes et demerara avec un mordant floral particulier. Assurément unique comme interprétation dune scotish ale.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2012 From notes.  First reviewed 12/22/2008.  Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.

Robert The Bruce has a very deep coffee color, with a hint of cherry. A small head quickly recedes but leaves some small lacing on the glass.

The malt, which is heavily toasted, is the most obvious smell. It is smokey, with some light caramel and toffee notes.

Some nice smokey toffee notes lead out the flavor, with almost no fruit or alcohol present. A nice spiciness fills the middle of the sip, with a brief hop introduction, and then more malt at the end. 

This has a medium body, but the sweetness makes it feel heavier. Medium carbonation. Slightly chewy, due to the malt. 

Even with the heavier body, this is a reasonably drinkable ale. The balance of malt and hops, with the malt pushing ahead, allow it enough sweetness to drink one or two easily. After that, the sweetness catches up to it, and the heavier body is somewhat prohibitive.

On cask 2/1/2011.  Served from a gravity pour cask into a pint glass at Fountainhead. (6/3/7/4/15)

On cask, Robert the Bruce pours a dark walnut brown with a ruby tint throughout. This looks more transparent than I remember out of the bottle. A rocky tan head does not retain very well and leaves no lacing to speak of.

Overall it is fairly soft on the nose, with the various aromas blending together. Caramel malt, some dark and orchard fruits, lightly spiced, with soft earthy hops. 

The flavors smooth together, losing some of their crisp edges. Smooth caramel malt, with a hint of cocoa, raisins and plums all carry the load. A soft spice kick and a light finish of earthy hops and peat.

This drinks fairly light on cask. The feel is creamy, more from the beer than from the carbonation, which is obviously not present. 

This was very easy to put down. The carbonation was delicate and light, and the beer itself is solid.

On tap at Jackie-Os, for $5 a pint. Clear red-brown color, foamy clear-colored head that persists, leaves great lace. Nice, scotchy-sweet taste. Caramel aroma, spicy hops. Really tasty, high quality beer, and I dont even usually like Scottish styles... Some good recent examples however, like the Jackie-Os and the Dark Horse, are starting to make me think differently.

Bottle from BrewDog Online Store. Dark muddy brown colour, not much head. Treacle chocolate malt aroma. Sweet chocolate, caramel & malt flavour. Sweet aftertaste, quite smooth. A good example of this beer style but not really my thing.

This one poured a nice rusty body, and had a thick sudsy head. Aromas were thick with toffee and dried fruits - all pretty roasted and mellow. The malt character of this beer is bold, again with toffee and also spices with a touch of hops at the end. Finishes with a faint coffee aftertaste that is filling.

An interesting beer. Thanks Chipalsa. Nose is tootsie rolls, some roast and some caramel. Nice. The body was of a light molasses color with a light brown/gray colored head. This one tasted like prunes and some light chocolate malt. Cherry notes were evident as well as plenty of roast. A bit spicy. Good stuff.
Very good tasting dark beer, but on the sweeter side. The color is very nice with little head. Overall really good, sweet beer
Bottle as shown. Pours a clloudy copper with no head. Faint honey aroma. Sweet malt and tea flavor. A decent Scottish ale from Three Floyds.

Bottled.
Sweet, malty, a bit nutty. Bitter almonds. Nice bitter tail, but too much on the sweet side overall for me.

Pours a very dark reddish brown with a nice tan head and good lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and some caramel. Very nice roasted malt flavor with caramel and a hint of dark chocolate. A bit of bitterness. Really good.

Bottle poured into a snifter.  This is all about roasty malt.  Caramel, chocolate, roasty, aroma.  Nice slightly bitter finish, can taste a bit of hops, but very low on the hops for a Floyds brew.

Nice beer to enjoy,
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2012 Like everything else Ive had from 3 Floyds this is absolutely delicious.  My favorite scottish ale.  Very smooth and drinkable.

Bottle. Pours clear but dark brown, a bit of ruby tint. One or two fingers of khaki head, reduces but never goes completely away. Nose is big on the toffee malt, a bit of smoke, and a hint of milk chocolate as it warms. Tastes a bit smokier (especially in the sinuses), with a slight hop kick complementing the natural spice of the style. Quite good.

Dark caramel pour. Malty aroma with a very slight hop nose. Very smooth. My favorite of this style and my favorite Three Floyds so far.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: APR 29, 2012 Dark smooth perfection. Tried it cuz of the name and had no idea Id fall in love. Three floyds knows how to make beer.

Date: January 17, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: Crown Liqour Description: Translucent brown with large amount of head.  Aroma is roasted malt, caramel and maybe some chocolate.  Taste is similar, but has a touch of spice, splash of alcohol and mild bitter finish.  Not a big fan of the style, but this one is tasty and it wont let you down like with William Wallace.

Bottle.  Pours dark mahogany with beige head.  Good lacing.  Big malty, caramel, chocolate.  Taste has a creaminess to it; very smooth.  Taste is similar to smell with an emphasis on big caramel roasted malts.  Very nice.
Dark thick malty goodness. Everything I like in one bottle. Not sold in my area so experiences with Three Floyds are too rare.

Bottle purchased at the Three Floyds brewery. Pours a ruby/ brown colour with an off white tanish head, splashes of residual sugar like drippy spots on the glass walls. Aroma is caramelized malt, chocolate and coffee, and alcohol. Tastes sweet, bitter and a little boozey. A little tongue numbing. Really quite nice.

Bouteille de 12oz. Un gros merci Patrick. Bière brune qui ne fait pas de mousse dans mon verre et une belle tête de mousse dans lautre. Le nez est efficace avec ses effluves de caramel, un léger fruité, des raisins secs et un petit côté fumé fort agréable. La bouche est bien constituée, le caramel et le fumé se combinent pour un petit boire savoureux. Le gaz carbonique est bien présent et pique la langue. Un succès.

Bottle from madvike.  Poured a dark mahogny without much of a head.  Aroma was rich caramel malts with a hint of smokiness.  Subtle yet rich at the same time.  Flavors were similar, lots of caramel, light smoke and an earthy hop character that lingered.  Mouthfeel was medium with light carbonation.  Great example of an old worldd Scotch ale with a nice caramel sweetness that finished dry with just a bit of smoke.  Nice.

From a couple months ago. I did not enjoy this. It wasnt necessarily bad looking, rather thick and dark red to brown with a creamy khaki head. The nose just turned me off and made it very hard to finish. Three Floyds yeast character is distinctive, working well with a lot of their hop forward beers, but detracting from the experience in a malty offering like this. Id like to give it a shot on tap maybe, to see if I enjoy that more than the bottled version. It might be a while before I try, though.

(Courtoisie de JulienHuxley)  Une petite tête brune flotte sur un liquide à la robe acajou.  Au nez, les malts qui sont caramélisés et même chocolatés développent un profil fruité.  Une légère fumée qui se cache derrière la richesse des céréales.  Les saveurs sont très peu éloignées des arômes : les malts sont opulents, le caramel est épais et fruité, des notes rôtis qui voyagent avec quelques noix écrasées.  La bouche est solide, bien pétillante, huileuse.  La finale est douce : un véritable bonbon qui roule sur la langue.
Good roasty nose from a dark mahogany pour. No lacing, great dark roasted malt flavor.  Great Scottish ale.
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2012 Pours a dark deep amber with thin white head. aroma is sweet and earthy.  Flavor is smooth and sweet with a bit of spice in it. nice.

Always a sucker for Scotch Ales, this one is a prized possession in this category. A pleasantly sweet brown sugar nose rises from a deep mahogany body with little to no lacing (possibly bad bottle as it was the last sixer). However, give the beer some time to warm and all the classic malt flavors of toffee and caramelized nuts flood the palate. While not the best Scotch Ive had (AleSmith Wee Heavy cheers to you!) this is a beer you should not pass up. RTB can keep my cellar company!

Bottle. Pours a ruby reddish. Has smaller head. Smells of caramel, bread, roasty, alcohol, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, average carbonation,  Going of a tasting about a month ago. Really liked it had lots of flavor

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 This beer pours a dark brown with excellent head retention and lacing. Smell of the beer is roasted caramelish malt with a nice doughy/bready finish. I am very happy they did not elect to go overboard on the chocolates with this beer.

This beer is a display of fine toasted malts at their best. I would have rated it a little higher if it was in the 8%+ range of ABV, but I wouldnt hold that against it....its a near-perfectly concocted brew that is every-so-smooth to consume.

I received a 12oz bottle in a trade with a guy named Robert. I poured it into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Opaque maroon so dark it borders on black. Forms a large, tan, creamy head which retains and laces well.

Smell: Subdued nose of bready malt, dark fruits and a hint of smoke.

Taste: Robert The Bruce is a Scottish style ale, not to be confused with the stronger, more robust Scotch or "Wee Heavy" ales. Considering this is a Three Floyds beer, its surprising they didnt opt for the latter style. So what we have is a beer thats definitely tasty and well balanced, but seems like so much more could be done.

It begins with pretty big fruity/malty flavors - the same youd get in a Belgian dark ale, but without the actual Belgian quality. I notice a cherry sweetness and tartness is quite prominent, followed by a plum flesh. The back end is slightly bitter with bakers chocolate and toasted malt. The finish is slightly sweet, but leaves a clean aftertaste. A good palate as a whole, but its not amazing and unique like most beers from this brewery.

Mouthfeel: Thick, soft, wet, cold, low carbonation, creamy texture with a mostly clean aftertaste.

Drinkability: What Three Floyds Robert The Bruce lacks in energy is makes up for in drinkability. The thick density and creamy texture make it extremely smooth. The 7% ABV actually seems a little high as there doesnt seem to be a lot of energy or weight to this palate. This beer probably works better as a meal companion rather than a beverage on its own. Still, its not a challenge to drink at all and would make a good introduction to the Scottish style.

12oz., No date. A friend brought it back for me when on a trip to Chicago.

Poured and ruby red with almost no head, it dissipated very quickly. 

Has a bit of lacing. 

The aroma is very bready, caramel, and a bit smokey. It smells of a Malt BOMB.

The taste follows the nose. It is very smooth with a medium mouth feel. Biscuty, malty, caramely smoothness. Its glorious. 

Excellent!

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar, during 3Floyds Night 2011.Finally an elusive Scottish ale, my last beer style ! Amber colored with a medium creamy head that quickly disappears. Aroma is fruity hoppy, and less caramel malts yet the flavor is mostly sweet malt based and the hops are in teh background. Nice one though and quite enjoyable.

An incredibly satisfying beer that is balanced perfectly. A curious amount of malts. For someone who likes hoppy brews and wants a change of pace, this is a great beer to drink without the citrus snap of IPAs.

The experience starts with bitter malt and a bit of peaty aroma.  As a Boilermaker, it saddens me to say that this is the perfect color of cream and crimson I have ever seen (such a shame from a Northern Indiana brewery).  The head requires a violent pour to generate and it doesnt last long before retreating to the sidelines.  Clean malt character on the tongue is punctuated by cherry candy, caramel, and a touch of toffee.  Sweet throughout and only slightly balanced by a low lying bitterness either from the roasted malts or hops.  A bit cloying at the end, but perhaps that is to be expected from the bigger Scottish ales.  The medium bodied and lightly carbonated beer goes down smooth but leaves behind a slightly sticky coating.  Quite a nice beer.  Well made - as I always expect from Three Floyds - but not as good as the Three Floyds obsessed raters would suggest.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Chocolate color (with a hint of red) that has a thin light tan head.

Aroma: Toffee, cherry, floral hops, and a touch of peat.

Taste: Malty and somewhat sweet upfront with toffee, cherry and plum. Turns more peat-like, floral and spicy toward the finish, with a long, lingering bitterness that is out of place.

Palate: Moderately high carbonation, medium full body, dry finish.

Overall: Pretty hoppy for a Scottish Ale, giving it a little more complexity than most. However, I feel that the bitterness is a distraction from the malts.
Great beer. Again not my style and though it would be like a guiness. Not at all.  A lot more flavor and lighter.  Would definitely have again

12 oz bottle. Clear reddish brown with a tiny head. Aroma of dark fruit, toffee, wheat bread and light smoke. Flavor is malty sweet with a light bitter roast and some alcohol. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a smooth, oily mouth feel. Nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2011 Bottle. Poured mahogony reddish orange brown. Would be clear without the yeast floaties.
 Aroma has english tones with sweet rich malt nutty and with dark fruit.chocolate also.Some floral. Good grainy malt aroma.Minerally butter raison english yeast and sortof oktoberfest like.Mild  tart yeastyness almost a vegetable corn likeness very faintly
 Smooth sweet malty with same flavors as aroma,some yeast , light roast.fiinishes chocolaty sweet carmel with a light tart almost citrusy/herbal bittering. Pretty good for its style,not my favorate style ,not really enthused about having a sixer of it really. Then again its nice to have a sweet nutty malty beer every now and again,ill enjoy this randomly,no doubt.
pour is a brownish copper with a frothy decent head. Smell is raisins butterscotch and straw. Taste smooth apricot ripe peach cardamom light light coffee and brown sugar. great mouthfeel.

This one was on tap at Shubbas in Chicago.  The ruby red color and long lasting small bubble head (pushing with nitrogen?) made a great appearance.  The malt had a caramel base with a nice toasty chocolate thing going on.  This was well balanced with the medium herbal hop package.  This really does the style credit.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Smuggled back from the backer christmas show in chicago.  Pours a beautiful clear red plum hue with good near white head. Delicious malty earthy sweet smooth anise. About damn perfect for what I think of for this style.  Really loved this one.

two month old bottle from brewery.  my first review... and I happen to be drinking it while i type this.  Very full, sweet and rich yet potentially sessionable.  reminds me of a lighter old ale.  wonder if they ever barrel-age it, itd taste great.  Still havent found a Three Floyds I dont like

Pours very dark brown with frothy light tan head.  Aroma of caramel and coffee.  Slight funk with warm malt, cocoa, and oats.  Frothy mouthfeel and light carbonation.  This particular bottle might be slightly past its prime, but its still quite delicious.

On tap at the Brewpub, October 21, 2011.

Pours a reddish copper color with a medium slightly tan head. Really a lot of malt both in the aroma and taste. Also a lot of caramel, some notes of smoke, chocolate, roasted malt. Nice beer!

Poured on draft into an imperial pint glass. Appearance is a dark brown to black with a nice sized head of beige foam. Aroma is filler with coffee, vanilla, biscuits, and a little bit of figs. Taste is a good deal more coffee heavy than I expected, but its not a bad thing. I sill get the biscuits and vanilla, but tshe coffee is still the dominant flavor here.
Pours a reddish brown color.  Aroma of malts.  Taste is sweet and creamy malts with some nuts on the back end.  Excellent.

on tap @ Greenhouse Tavern during a Three FLoyds beer dinner. pours hazy brown leather, brief tan head. biscuit malts, milk chocolate, dark fruit, esters on the nose. roasted malts, brown sugar, chocolate, faint coffee acidity on the finish. this is such a balanced and smooth Scotch ale. the more you sip, the more nuanced I find it. possibly a bit of cinnamon in there as well. Great beer and sessionable.

Bottle. Pours dark brown almost black with a tight foamy kahki head that fades to a whispy film and collar. Aroma is chocolate tootsie rolls and malt, molasses and vegtebles. Taste is more rich chocolaty malt and vanilla with some molasses and finishes with a subtle bitterness. palate is medium/full with a slick sticky dry finish. Really nice scotch ale!

Living in Chicago, I am a big Three Floyds fan.  This is one I dont buy as often as some of their others, but it certainly has its merits and lives up to their "not normal" slogan.  It pours darker than I expected - more brown than ruby.  Not much carbonation, but it has a pleasantly thick body.  The aroma is sugary hops but the taste is full of roasted malts and perhaps chocolate and caramel.  The finish is short but satisfying.   I have no complaints with this brew, but dont find it as outrageous as some of Three Floyds other offerings in other styles.

Pours deep garnet, not a lot of head, maintains very tight, fine lacing. Mouthfeel is creamy, smooth, good carbonation. Sweet, nice caramel notes, biscuit, mild roast, with mild earthy hops on the finish. Really nicely composed and lots of delicious malty goodness.
Dark Chestnut pour with medium head, fades quickly.  Carmel, toffee, chocolate on the palette.  Fairly malty.  Looking forward to the colder temps so I can enjoy more of these.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2011 This beer is really good. The color is alright, head retention was kind of weak. Not too much hop complexity, but a nice tough of smoke or peet. One of the better wee heavys Ive had.

Dark ruby brown with a small white head, fades relatively quickly... quite malty with notes of chocolate, fresh lightly citrusy hops, light roast, the choc is the most notable aroma... lively, medium to medium thin body, lightly slick... chocolatey flavor, some mild roast, light coffee, i would call this an american brown ale, seems more hoppy than i would expect from a scottish ale... complex as it can be... nice nice nice beer

Nose has heavy malt sugars, some biscuit like qualities. Flavor is very rich English Biscuity like flavors, the richness and complexity of the malt bill used really makes this a world class beer. Laser show!

Pours dark copper with sweet roasted malty smell and some alcohol. Taste is a big malt body, sweet with light floral hops and a lot of spice, from both grain and hops. A bit hoppy for a scotch but still grainy. Pretty drinkable still
Pours a chestnut brown with a quickly fading head. Slighly smoky, sweet without being cloyingly so and peated tasting with a medium full bodied mouthfeel. Appropriately subdued hop character.

Bottle drank before the Vikings are about to lose.  Fuck my life... Caramel and toffee in the aroma.  Pretty much assumed that would be the case.  Taste is caramel, toffee, slight grassy hops, maybe some coffee.  Underwhelming.

Pours a reddish copper color with a huge light tan head. Nose is malted barley and a whiff of hops. Nice viscosity and mouthfeel. Taste is full of flavor - barley, malt, caramel, and hints of coffee and smoke. Very pleasing finish of muted hops and licorice. Overall, an excellent beer and one of which the Scots would be quite proud. Pairs well with smoked salmon on wheat crackers.
12 oz bottle, pours clean auburn w/ minimal off-white head, aroma is awesome blend of caramel and smoke w/ some esters, rich caramel flavor without being cloying and a lightly oily finish, very tasty

Pours a chestnut brown color with a medium tan head...lively looking.  Aroma is roasty with notes of vanilla, toffee, and chocolate.  Flavor has significant roastiness and a hint of chocolate...very malty.  Mouthfeel is silky with a roasty dry finish that lingers.
Very smooth and drinkable malty ale.  Mild bitterness.  Mild sweetness.  The chocolate malt adds some nice flavor, but I wouldnt say chocolatey.  Robust, yet refined.
Bottle. Malt, fruit, chocolate aroma. Clear brown with a small, quickly dissipating head. Flavor is full on malt, a little molasses and dark fruit. Smooth medium body. Nice.

Bottle in a pint glass - pours a very dark amber with beige head and light lacing.  Nose is apple sauce.  Aroma is strong malts of coffee flavor and mild pine hops.  Taste is sweet with mild hoppy aftertaste.  Not what I was expecting from a Scottish ale but what do I know?  Intriguing beer with a certain er I dont know quoi.

Glass, 5-ounce, on the premise, savoured on July 7 2011; eye: mahogany, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of off-white head; nose: malt, nutty, light roasted, slight scotch; mouth: malt, nutty, light roasting, light caramel, slight scotch, finale in malt with slight presence of alcohol, medium body, good carbonation, mildly sweet, lightly velvety texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS 

Verre, 5 onces, à la brasserie, savourée le 7 juillet 2011; il : acajou, limpide, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse blanc cassé; nez : malt, noix, léger rôti, léger caramel, très léger scotch; bouche : malt, noix, légère torréfaction, léger caramel, très léger scotch, finale en malt avec très légère présence dalcool, corps moyen, bonne carbonatation, moyennement sucrée, texture légèrement veloutée; en résumé : bien

I really like this one.  Pour is an amber/brown color with little white head.  Taste is malty sweetness with notes of light roasty malts and caramel.  Light hops prevent too much sweetness and balances it out perfectly.
Pours clear brown with no head or lacing. Sweet roasted woody dark malt aroma. Taste is rich toasted malt with a carmel sweetness. Round rich finish

The carmely chocolate taste is distinctive yet smooth and creamy. The aroma is pleasent but not over powering. The dark appearance makes it look like a heavy malted beer. Taste is genuine. The beer does not make you feel bloated; you could have more but you know when to stop. 
It is a tastey beer.

12oz bottle, unknown date.  Served at around cellar temperature.

Pours somewhat hazy reddish brown with a small light beige head that quickly recedes.

Aroma is fruity and lightly smoky with apples, golden raisins, some dark fruits, also a good deal of toasted bread, toffee and caramel.  Good strength, could be better.

Flavor is dark fruits, cherries, raisins, some apples, good dose of caramel and toffee, a little chocolate, rather sweet although some hop bitterness comes through on the finish along with a bit of alcohol.

Mouthfeel is on the light side of medium bodied, somewhat sticky with prickly carbonation.

A very robust and tasty Scottish Ale.  Big thanks to Eric for bringing this treat by!
Nose is heavy caramel malt, cane sugar, little rotten fruit, sherry bite, cedar, feel Is medium, carb is quite low, taste Is weak, soft alcohol, heavy caramel, chocolate note, late soft hops bite.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted caramelish and slight breadish. Sweet caramelish, lig acidic fruity, just a touch of it. Lasting sweet and roasted caramelish finish.

355 ml bottle. Dark brown and somewhat hazy. Very small off-white head. Rich raisiny malty nutty aroma. Hints of chocolate and gingerbread. Sweet malty flavours with chocolate, caramel and raisins. Fairly low carbonation level. Not much hops as it is fully malt driven. Mellow texture and soft flavours. Very drinkable. The carbonation is a little too low.

12oz bottle - thanks Matt. Light brown with red hues, quickly fading cream head. Malty and sweet, faint chocolate and caramel, plum. Light carbonation and fairly light bodied, sweet, touch of bitterness at the end, nice dry finish with malt, some peat, keeps on giving. Good.

355 ml bottle, from Ølbutikken (or was it Høkeren?), Copenhagen. Mahogany coloured beer, moderate cream-coloured head. Malty aroma, some woody and caramel notes, also roasty notes with hints of cold coffee, also hints of smoke and chocolate. Rich malty flavour, fairly sweet with notes of caramel and chocolate, also mild roasty notes in the finish, just a touch of smoke, very moderate hops. Pleasant to drink.

Tap at the pub pours razor clear brown red with a 1 finger khaki head and great retention.  Aroma is very rich, but very faint with notes of chocolate, raisins, and toffee.  Taste is mild coffee, toffee, a hint of chocolate, and dried fruit.  Body is medium-full, low carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. Overall, I feel that this great brew is lost in the mix of all of the fantastic creations that the Floyds put out, but lacks none of the quality and depth of flavor of the brewerys other offerings.

Small beige head.  Deep red body with light carbonation.  Raisiny
roasty dusty aroma with lovely rye crisp bread edge and earthy
fruity strawy notes.  Incredibly harmonic and vivid.  Dry-sweet
earthy strawy grainy taste with rye crisp bread notes.  Soft,
mild, smooth mouthfeel.  Dryish earthy caramelly toffee rye crisp
bread aftertaste lingers for a long time.  Excellent! Highly
drinkable, and incredibly vivid flavour.  (0.355l bottle,
Ølbutikken, Copenhagen.)

Poured amber brown. Nose was a whole lot of nothing. Very small amount of carbonation. Very little head with spotty lacing. Taste was a malty caramel notes reminds me of a heath bar. Very subtle chocolate notes in the finish. Mouthfeel was oily that went down pretty smooth. Reminded me of a brown ale but with a clean finish. Shared with AirForceHops.

Got in trade with a non-Ratebeerian.  Pours a clear dark brown. Super thin, off- white head that had a bit of lace down the pint glass.  Smell is malty and sweet. Taste is very malty with chocolate malt to include a toffee like flavor. This has a very smooth, light and creamy mouthfeel. Has a certain chugability to it. Kind of slick going down, it just slides down the hatch.  Well above average for the style.

A brown-black beer which forms a slight white head which soon dissipates. Rich chocolate and dried fruit on the nose. Roast coffee and tobacco in the thick body. Good legs on the swirl of the glass and rich alcohol and vinous fruit in the finish with a slight bittersweet  chocolaty end.
sweet plum toasted aroma,brown golden, clear, light brown foam,light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, soft carbonation, nice finish.

Dark, almost black and clear. Has an off-white head, mostly lasting. Aroma is sweet, caremel, faint smoke and perhaps a roasted note. Flavor is mainly sweet, moderate bitter finish. Creamy texture and soft carbonation.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark amber colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Dark fruity notes. Very slightly smoked. Light sweet and moderate bitter nice flavor. Roasted notes. Long moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Well-balanced beer.
a dark red pour with a small off white head.  malty aroma, hint of brown sugar.  slightly sweet and very malty.  nice roasted flavor.  very good for the style.

0.33l bottle from BrewDog webshop shared with ClubGonzo. Pours a unfiltered deep red/brown body with a thin sidesticking off-white head. Aroma is not extreme. There are dark malty and burned caramel tones combined with some mild nutty-hints. Medium-bodied, its average carbonated and has a sticky texture. Quite sweet and malty on the flavors. Roasted caramel wrapped in a light acidic and nutty flavor with a really nice bitterness towards the end, and its leaving a mild sweet caramel-aftertaste. Nice enough.
Bottle from Cavie.  Dark brown pour with a small off-white head.  Aroma is a little roasted, peaty, and almost grapes.  Taste is chocolate, peat, a little bitter, raisins, and really malty.

Bottle. Pours a clear reddish orange color with a white type head. Aroma is big caramel malts and sugary sweetness. Some bits of smoked peat can be detected. Flavor is nutty with some peat moss. Sweet malty flavor. Sugary finish. Pretty good.
Light malty aromas.  Caramel, chocolate and peat flavors.  Rich mouth coating flavors.  Overall a very good scottish ale.
36cl, no mention of ABV, American brew, thx to Jeppe!, complex Scotch, malty and slightly roasted, easy to drink, yet balanced, clear, small head, good brew

Fra flaske, tak Plovmand.... :) dufter dejligt ristet malt, mørk chokolade... flot mørke brun med flot hvidt skum... smager af chokolade, mørke frugter og ristet malt.... sød eftersmag.... en dejlig Ale....

Bottle. Pours clear brown with a medium to small off white head. The aroma is bread, sweet  malt, toasted caramel and some dark fruit. Light toast, toasted caramel, bread and dark fruity flavour. Long caramelish finish.

Bottle. Pours a nice dark copper/brown color with a small beige head. Aroma is super malty, with loads of caramel, toffee, rye, some roast and breadiness. Flavor is again hefty on the malts, some spicy rye notes, toffe, chocolate malt, caramel, (rye) breadiness and some molasses. The body is medium with a creamy mouthfeel. Overall a really nice Scottish Ale, and a hughe malt bomb.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, courtesy of - and shared with - Palme. Pours out a deep cherry-hued brown body with a small off-white head. Nose is dark syrup, burnt caramel, dark malts and hints of sour-like rye-ish tones which is hard to pinpoint. Taste is caramel, burnt sugar, deep malty tones, molasses with hints of honey and nuts. Pretty smooth and sweet without being sticky about it, but seems to lack a bit of complexity somehow; I think this is a bit overrated.

Flaske: Mørk orange klar øl med et stort skumhoved. Ekstrem maltdomineret øl, med masser af malt i både duft og smag. Desværre er der ingen røg eller let brændthed til at give en smule kompleksitet, hvilket gør øllen til en noget endimensionel affære.

Bottled. Pours clear and deep amber with a little, short lasting, off-white head. Nose of caramel.Swet flavour with caramel, toasted bread, nuts and chocolate notes. Soft carbonation and creamy texture. Medium bodied. Ends up more dry and with a little bitterness. Pleasant and enjoyable.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph.
Pours a nice, deep, ruby red with a fine, staying, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, some cellar and a bit of metal. Some toasted caramel as well. Medium carbonation, fairly nice creamy and frothy palate. Flavour is mildly sweet, fairly malty, some toasted caramel and a milky edge. Fairly good malty elegance in flavour but quite a bad aroma.
Pours super dark, nice and sweet in taste.  This is a malt lovers dream.  I found this to be pretty well balanced and easy drinking.  3Floyds does it again.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 My feelings about this beer are just as complex as the beer itself. It is really, really well brewed, with a perfect body and a lot of complexity in terms of aroma and the resulting flavors. There are plenty of chocolate and malts, which are decently roasted, with some hops as well. The result is a very sweet beer, perhaps too sweet for me, whose overall feel I could only describe as gingerbread-esque. I am not familiar enough with the style to assess whether Three Floyds nailed it or not (it would appear so, judging by the fact that its currently the top-rated beer on the style); Ill just say its a very well done brew, regardless of its intention, that is just not for me. Try it, though, because I can see how this is a malt-lovers (and, may I add, chocolate-lovers) delight, as FFF claims it is.

Aroma: nice and heavy on the malts; lots of dark caramel, biscuit, toffee, some coffee and roast, ripe dark fruits.  Very inviting aroma, delicious.  Pours a very dark ruby/amber with a thick tan head, several minutes of retention and a bit of lacing.  Flavor is sweet malts, caramel, toffee, toasty, roast and chocolate, hint of coffee.  Definitely a slight kick of hop bitterness in the background, but it doesnt distract from the malts very much.  Nice medium-full body, creamy and smooth, medium carbonation.  Really great beer, just a killer malty aroma and flavor.
Bottle @ Mikkeller. Dark brown/red with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, sweet, yeast, fruit, hops, caramel, little bitter and nuts.
Clear dark reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, heavy malty, caramel and nutty. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Light sweet finish. Smooth and full bodied. 250511

A 12oz bottle from Chucks poured into an English Pint. 

Small amount of dark white head that dissipates quickly. Dark nut brown in color. 

Scent is very malty. Caramel and roasted nuts. Cant smell much from the hops on this one. Something else is there too. Maybe raisins...

Taste is light sweet and light bitter. I can taste coffee and some kind of funk on the aftertaste. 

Medium bodied with a creamy texture, overly fizzy carbonation and a slightly longer than average coffee finish. 

Overall, Im not a huge fan of this beer. Maybe its because I was expecting a lot for for my first 3F experience or maybe I got a bad bottle. Something here just doesnt measure up in my book for this to have such a high rating. Hopefully the 3F Arctic Panzer Wolf that Im going to drink tomorrow will be better.

Pours a dark brownish red with tan head and above average lacing.  Aromas of caramels, chocolates, roastiness with notes of molasses.    Taste is sweet but not overbearing as the roasted grains provide some bitterness.  Not a hoppy bitterness, though.  The palate is medium bodied, creamy with some stickiness.  Overall, this is a very tasty beer.  The maltiness, sweetness blend so well together I feel an explosion of flavors as soon as it hits the tongue.   A good one from 3F - shocking.

Bottle courtesy of arminjewell. Pours a gorgeous red-brown with a light head. Nose is honey, chocolate, toffee, and a touch of roast. Sweetness on the tongue -- incredibly rich, with all sorts of candied flavors tied together with a ribbon of rich roasted malt. Finishes long and amazingly lush. Incredible, and makes me miss living in Indiana.

Compared and Contrasted this with Ale Smiths Wee Heavy.  Brown, tan head.  Flavor has a somewhat toasty finish for a scottish ale.  Nice grass and hay (from the grain? not the hops).  Lighter bodied and drinkable.  Not very sweet or smoky either.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar.
Clear orange red coloured with a small off-white head.
Fruity aroma of caramel and berries with notes of dried fruits.
Fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits, hops and grass.
Hoppy finish.
clear amber, smooth offwhite head3  pretty mild aroma, faint caramel faint flowers5 flavor is malty nutty, caramelly faint woody bitter.7

(12oz bottle courtesy of Fata2683!!).  Pours clear mahogany with massive tan head.  Active carbonation and some lacing developing.  Aroma has caramel, dried fruit (apricot and dates noticeably) and some florals.  Taste is sweet with caramel malts and dried fruit again.  Medium bodied with slick texture and very smooth finish.  A really easy beer to drink.  Nice!
Bottle Full flavored beer with a delectable body very smooth. Big malt flavors with sweetness and alcohol. Wonderful beer. =)

had this beer both on tap and from a 12 oz bottle.  pours a clear dark brown.  smell is malty and sweet.  Taste is very sweet and full body.  This beer is delicious wow.  This is a graet beer thank goodness I brought some home with me!!

Apr 23, tap @ 3F brewbar. Pours deep clear mahogany with small tanned head leaving some lace. Aroma is sweet malty. Round, medium malty mouthfeel. Flavor is nice; malty, sweet, some dark fruits and fruity. Medium malty palate. Finishes short with good roasted and tart adtertaste.
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2014 On tap at Fountainhead. Toasted malts and citrus hops in there. Smooth and malty. Easy drinking. Well done for a boring style
POurs deep amber with bread noites.  The bread notes show in the palate which give rise to hints of toasted grains and mild notes citrus and bitter hops.

Pours a deep reddish brown color.  Moderate carbonation and medium bodied. Nice and malty with a hint of fruity sweetness to it.  Long malty finish to it.  Malty aroma with some raisin. This is the first beer Ive had from Three Floyds. Not bad at all.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2011 Got a six pack in a trade with vw73182.  Bottle poured into a tulip.  Nice deuce finger white head.  This certainly is a malty beverage as described.  A bit of alcohol in finish.  Good kicking around beer, nothing too special.  Oh man, I can still taste that Hopslam, blech!  

Tried this again and was much better.  Having this immediately after the Hopslam influenced the taste too much, was much better as my first beer of the night.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Malts and raisins aroma. Brown, beige head, good lace. Sweet (light sugary), very malty, light bitter to bitter in the finish, raisins. Full, sticky, lightly warming. Highly drinkable, not overwhelming nor exceptional.

Big thanks to Sendsilk on BA for sharing this gem. Light brown color with virtually no head. Slight oily lacing. Aroma was pretty much dominated by honey, thats pretty much it. The flavor was great as well but I couldnt get over the honey in it. I absolutely loved this beer.

Pours a dark brown with a small head that vanished fairly quickly.  Nose was toasted malts, peet, toffee, and a little smoke.  Taste was roasted and chocolate malts.  It was less sweet than other scotch/scottish ales and obviously not as hot as a scotch.  Finish was very clean and quite tasty.  Certainly worth purchasing in six packs.

Bottle (09 notes, Indianapolis).  Pours with a lightly tan head, and cola colored body.  Nice malty aroma that has some raisin, toffee, and roast malt.  Flavor is not as sweet as I would have expected, with some nice earthiness, roast, and toffee.  Medium body, bubblier carbonation.  Good brew.

27 March 2011, bottle. dark brown, clear, no bubbles, no head. great nose. meaty/sausage, roasated barley w/ slightly smoky aroma, some soft black coffee notes. very complex nose. full body and mildly fizzy, slightly syrupy. great beer! roasted chocolate and cherries. slightly raisiny, sweet alcohol flavour w/out huge alcohol punch. really great.

(draft 3/14/11). Dark brown color. Medium tan head. Malty caramel aroma. Flavor of the same with light chocolate/coffee and very light smoke/roast character. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Good lacing.

12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is a deep dark brown color with a hint of reddish amber; small, off-white head.  Aroma is complex with dark fruits, caramel, roasted cereals, alcohol and a hint of vanilla.  Taste is predominately a battle between the roasted malts and the sweet dark fruits giving it a nice balance.  The hints of vanilla, caramel, and perhaps a touch of chocolate also come through but not as strong.  This beer sits really nice on the palate.  Its medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a soft, silky mouthfeel.  This is a wonderful brew.

It pours a disappointing ugly dark brown with a light brown head, that barely shows itself and goes away quickly. Minimal lacing. 

It smells like sweet malts.

This beer has a very interesting taste, almost stoutish by mild, but yet at the same time a very big mouthful. There hints of tea, and hops at the end. This beer is so-so couldnt drink a ton of it.

Aroma is caramel and toffee. Subtle smokiness. Taste is malty and sweet with a rich caramel flavor. Nice balancing bitterness, hops are able to be detected but this beer is all about the malt. Body is rich and full.  A nice break from the hoppy beers I drink...well, everyday of my life.
was not what I expected...tasted more like a porter than a scottish ale, deep malt with a sweet taste, maybe raisin or dates, very nice
Pours a nice dark, coppery brown with a mid-sized, tan head. Nice roasted malt aroma and strong roast malt flavor, with some sweet chocolate and coffee in the background. Interesting.
On tap at MacNivens in Indianapolis.  Pour is dark brown with off white head atop.  Chocolately, Malty brew... Slightly sweet.  Good sessional scotch ale.  Not crazy though

Pours a dark brown with an off white head.  Aroma of wood, malt and caramel.  Taste is a strong malt backbone with caramel and wood characteristics.  Slightly resinous and a great balance.  Nice beer, thanks Santa.

Bottle from Brewdog. Pours dark copper with a tiny head. Strong malty aroma. Taste is strong malty caramel and moderate sweet chocolate/toffee. Soft carbonation. Nearly oily mouthfeel. Lingering malty aftertaste.

Pours dark reddish brown, off white head.  Aroma has notes of chocolate, earth, caramel, and toffee with a touch of smoke.  Taste is caramel, toffee, chocolate hints, some earth and smoke, finishing slightly dry and bitter.

Three Floyds has a winner.  Aroma of chocolate and caramel.  Pours a somewhat hazy amber with a fizzy tan head.  Carbonated complexion throughout the glass.  Taste has the caramel tone of a brown ale, but the bite of a stout.  Great finish of chocolate.  Nice outing from FFF as this one strays away from its more popular names

Hand pull FFF. Pour mahogany brown with decent head good lacing. Aroma very malt forward with caramel and toffee. Taste big malt, touch roasty, caramel, wood, chocolate. MF very little carb medium body. Overall a tasty brew.
I just drank one of these the other day. Pretty good beer for the style. There might be better Scottish ales out there, but this is a strong effort from FFF. Worth a taste.
Hoppy for the style, average beer. You arent going to find may Scottish ales that are this vibrant and hoppy.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2011 Had it On The Engine ( hand pull) at the brewpub. It was malty and sweet. finished malty and sorta spicy. i loved it. a mans beer with a full body, heavier and smooth. a prize. i love it. roasted to the core. FFF destroying it. I like this cause it isnt overly "smokey" from the roasted malts...its nice balanced. Perfect mouthfeel. Juicy and full.

Bat 17, Evanston, bottle: Pours a mahogany brown like color with a pretty well formed head. As the label promises, this beer is full of malts. The aroma is full of malts, but there are fruit notes, sugar notes, and perhaps some toffee. The flavor is pretty similar. And to be perfectly honest I dont know Scottish Ales (that is not Scotch) all that well, so I dont know how accurate this is to the style. Medium-full bodied with a good amount of non-cloying sweetness to it. For my first Three Floyds beer, I was not blown away, but I cant say that I didnt enjoy it.
This red has a little ginger raisin to it and is easy to put away. I found my way through a six pack fairly quick.

355ml bottle from Brewdog Bar, Aberdeen. Pours cloud mahogany with ruby highlights and thin tan head which quickly dissipates. The carbonation is moderate and mouth-feel is smooth. The nose is caramel malt, plums, cherries, vanilla and wood. Taste; caramel, roasted malt, burnt sugar, wood, liquorice, nuts, tangy dark fruits, good bitterness and vanilla towards the end. Its well balanced and very drinkable.
On tap at Craftheads, Shibuya. Dark copper brown, small head. Malty nose. In the mouth a nice mix of caramel and chocolate. Nice.
I first had this at the Three Floyds tasting around Savour in 2010 and then in Chicago and at home.   One of the hopier scotch ales around.  Nice brown appearance, very malty with some chocolate.
Classic Scottish Ale with a strong malty flavor and not much hops.  Three Floyds did well.

The beer was poured into  LaChouffe glassware. It has a beautiful medium brown to reddish brown body with a creamy tan head. Very rich notes of malt, caramel and has a sweet undertow. I really enjoy the hint of alcoholic taste to the Scottish Ale. This is a very drinkable beer and would recommend you give it a try.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 Pours a beautifully clear deep mahogany color with a huge bubbly off white head that sticks to the glass all the way down. Smells of caramelized malts, a bit of mineral, some apples, strange smells abound. Tastes of sweet malt, caramel and some alcohol. Mouthfeel is thick and sticky, full bodied with loads of carbonation. Sweet brew, even for the style I felt it to be too sticky and sweet. Very little if any hop presence here. Not the best FFF beer Ive tried.

12/16/2011
Received in trade from phisigben, thanks for the opportunity.
Pours a slightly cloudy deep reddish brown color with a thinnish white head that quickly dissipates to wisps on top with spotty lace on the way down. Smells mostly of caramelized sugars with hints of alcohol raisins and prunes. Sweet and malty with enough hops to keep it from cloying. Sweet dark and caramelized sugars mixed with some dark dried fruits with just enough hop and ethanol to keep it from cloying, Medium to thick body with a light to moderate level of carbonation and a sweet sticky bubbly mouthfeel. Wow this seems like a very different beer than the one I reviewed in 2008. I really enjoyed this beer this time, I guess the last time I tried this maybe I got one that was "off".

Poured into a pint glass.

3.0 A: Clear medium brown color. One finger of off-white frothy head that falls quickly and leaves moderate lacing.

3.5 S: Sweet caramel and bready malts. Nice tinge of alcohol, molasses, and toffee.

3.5 T: Bready malts first of all. Caramel and molasses. Nice taste, but seems watered down compared to some of my more preferred Scotchies.

3.5 M: Medium body. Reasonable creaminess and good carbonation.

3.5 D: No big flaws, but not show stopping either. A decent brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-27-2009 02:51:11

Bottle; 33cl, Brewdog.com

Wowee malty! This is pure mad yaldi malted goodness. Aroma is grains; malt, barely, kilt leather fabric, I really want to say short bread but its not the case as I would be pure chico on the shortbread. 

Taste is coffee; chocolate, wee toffee, syrup, rye bread, leather  tobacco roasted malts, it is really black, nutty and very nice bitterness. Fascinating wee drop to mellow to. Nice.

On draught at Nicks in Bloomington.  A beautiful light brown color with a light tan head in my mason jar.  The aroma is of sweet toffee and bitter hops....and the taste follows.  Notes of cocoa, toffee, and buttery.  The hops come through to provide a nice balance.  The alcohol is hidden, but comes through as the beer warms up.  Overall a delicious offering from 3F...one of my favs.  Wish I could get it in MD.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2011 3 Floyds Robert The Bruce. 12oz Bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a chocolate brown with a 1-finger, beige head.

Aroma is caramel and coffee like roastiness.

Taste is a pleasant malty sweetness. Caramel and toffee up front. A little sugary on some sips. A lightly hopped, roasty finish.

Smooth. Medium-bodied with a nice drinkability

Recommended for those seeking a maltier beer with little hop presence. I usually like my beer very hopped up and I found this brew to be a very nice change up.

Thanks to Gcurlow for the bottle! It pours reddish brown with a tan head. The aroma is mostly over ripe fruit with a touch of chocolate malt. The flavor is the same with noticeable alcohol. This seems more Belgian inspired than Scottish to me. The finish has a hint of toasted malt.

I poured this into a pint glass thanks to Kirkpjr. I was greeted with a finger worth of tan head on top of a ruby brown colored body. The aroma was nice and malty sweet with a little toasted note found in there as well. The flavor was sweet toffee and lightly roasted coffee with a slight alcohol heat. There also was a slight bitter present as well. The mouthfeel was medium with light carbonation. It was a easy to drink high ABV scotch ale. I think I could have drank a couple of glasses of this, but I might run into trouble with anymore.
Pours a dark brown almost black with a frothy off white brownish head. The aroma is coffee and chocolate .Flavor is mildly sweet with some cocoa notes

355ml bottle, trade with Craig, cheers. Ruby brown body. Fast fading, beige head. The smell brings nutty malts to the nose. Coffee-chocolate malts in flavour, hints of honeyed malts, too. Mellow hops on the swallow. Velvetly smooth textured (hotel room, 03.12.2010).
Dark Brown pour little to no head. Aroma of dark roasted malts and caramel. On the palate the beer is very balanced with flavors of cocoa and caramel.
I love this beer.  The roasted malts warms up your taste buds for more. You cannot go wrong with this purchase.

The aroma of this one is a mild roasty malt mixed with notes of chocolate. The off white head settles without much left on the glass. The brew itself is an alluring reddish copper. The taste is more of maltyness than chocolate, landing smooth and silky. It leaves a pleasant aftertaste of chocolate for some time, making it impossible to not want to take another sip. This is a most enjoyable Scottish Ale.
Bottle.  Pours brown with an inch thick head.  Aroma is chocolate malts, and flavor is sweet chocolate and dark bread.  Another excellent brew from FFF.

Goblet pour at Zippos. Decent aroma with a generous poured head, dark body. Flavor is well balanced with a nice malt to hop ratio making it very drinkable. Decent body with pleasant palate. A fine ale.

I poured a 12 oz bottle into a snifter. There, it sat in its brownish-ruby glory under a thin bluish-white head. The head quickly dissipated and left little lacing, which meant no interference for the thick aromas of peat, campfire, and deciduous bark emanating from the glass. These aromas interwove with alcohol burn and whisky in the finish. This is nice and light-bodied rather than the heavier iterations of the style; no tendency toward syrupiness will be found here. This is not my favorite style, yet I cant imagine a Scots ale I would like better.

My 48th rating on the day that Jimmie Johnson and the 48 team win their 5th Straight Sprint Cup.  I guess it was just meant to be.  Congrats JJ.  The pride of East County!

Poured from a 12oz bottle from Manny57.  Thanks Ryan.  Pours a very dark brown/dark copper.  Smells of brown sugar and vanilla.  Loads of maltiness.  Not too much sweetness.  Very drinkable.

Pours a deep amber red with a thin tan head that was gone fairly quickly.  Very nice chocolate notes on the nose followed with a bit of booze, but in a warming sort of way.  The aroma is predominately milk chocolate, which Im really liking.  Very sweet on the palate.  The alcohol is fairly noticeable, but this also has a touch of chocolate (not as much as the aroma was telling of however), very minimal hop presence, and a brown sugary/maple syrup quality to it.

12 oz, thanks Illinismitty. Nearly opaque chocolate with red tints and a small, enduring topping of cream. Spicy-sweet chocolate, toffee and light coffee aromas are joined by a hint of earthy char. Flavor is sourish chocolate toffee with raisins, almost tamed on the finish by roasted walnut and earthy smoke. Medium body is sweet, but has the roast-acidic astringency to cleanse the sugars, and is smoothly carbonated.

Draught at Craft Heads. Clear dark brown - white head. High malty. Licorice. Light oak notes - from what ???  Malty/oakey acid/sourness. Nice but light hoppy. Fruity. Sweetness. Dark fruity. Roasted. Sweet malty. Nice.
Very malty aroma and flavor.  Almost a "light" stout.  Very slight bitterness in the background.  Pretty well carbonated.  Not quite for my taste, but decent nonetheless.

12oz Bottle from Sendiks Whitefish Bay.  Pour is a deep, dark brown with a thin white head.  Aroma is a beautiful roasty malt.  Taste is a nice sweet malt with a nice medium feel on the palate.  Another excellent beer from FFF.  Nice work!

A very tasty dark brown brew with good carbonation and nice malty aromas. Flavor is balance better with the hops that other Scotch or Scottish ales I have had, which are usually too sweet. Nice roasty finish. Thanks much to sherm1016 for this one!

On draft at village tap. Pours a deep copper with a decent white head. Has a roasty malt aroma with some sugary fruit aromas. Nice toffe, brown sugar, raisin flavor with a bit of subtle hop spice. A nice malty brew with a good hoppiness to balance. Good for a cold day.

Notes from Saturday, July 03 2010

Ar: A bit of roasted bitter chocolate and light alcohol on the nose.
Ap: Poured into a pint glass during fireworks.   Deep brownish-black pour with a two finger white head that diminishes quickly, leaves good lace.
F: Some very nice burnt sugar, toffee, molasses notes, but the sweetness is a bit cloying.  Surprisingly noticeable alcohol burn on the finish complements the room quite well.
P: Quite thick, very syrupy.
O: Enjoyable, but somewhat of a letdown from FFF.

12 oz. bottle from Woodmans in Madison, WI.  Dark reddish-orange pour with virtually no head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts and light floral hops.  The taste is not as sweet as expected.  I suppose this is sessionable enough and for the style its one of the better Scottish Ales.  For me, I am just not a big fan of this style.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Trade by cgarvieuk ]. Clear medium to dark brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, chocolate, wood, tobacco notes. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101008]

Bottle at Block Party. Pours amber-brown with a moderate, off-white head. Sweet, malty aroma with dark fruits and bread. Flavor is even sweeter, with caramel, fruit and bready malt notes, along withs subtle bitterness. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Finishes sweet with some spices, fruity hops, and plenty of caramel malt. Great stuff.
Deep brown pour, roasty malt aroma. Full bodied, roasty malts, chocolate, and light fruitiness, a lightly bitter finish. Very well balanced and smooth palate. Really damn good.

A: snifter. solid mahogany color with a ruby hue and some haze. creamy tan head with a good retention rate and good lacing.

S: very sweet aroma. nice roasted malts, very syrupy aroma. a lot of fruit in this, some banana(overly ripe), raisins, and some peat. small hop aroma, more resiny.

T: Wow. amazing scotch ale flavors, nice roasted peat and malt flavors. some solid banana and raisin flavors, along with some clove.

M: very robust. good mouthfeel. medium body. solid carbonation level.

D: An amazing scotch ale. I will definitely recommend this to anyone who likes malts brews. Very subtle for 7%.
Tan head, very ligth and gone fast, sweet caramel malt aroma, deep red mahogany brown, sweet caramel and roasted malt flaovor.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2013 This is an amazing and delicious beer that everyone should drink. Pours a root beer-like color with a dense medium head. Aroma is caramel, roasted malt, brown sugar and some scotch-like smoke. Taste is brown sugar, caramel, roasted malt, and a hint of something that lies between bourbon and scotch. Smooth and sweet. This is a great beer.

The color is as dark as can be while still being able to see the ruby red glow shining through the middle of the glass. A one-finger fizzy head forms with the pour, but it disappears after a few minutes, leaving only the dark, reddish liquid that looks like a glass of Dr. Pepper. The aroma is grainy with an underlying caramel sweetness. The flavor is relatively smooth and mild but is still quite sweet and bready, especially as it warms. The texture isnt very robust, with only a very fine carbonation saving it from being too thin yet almost syrupy.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to the Cad.Very red brown with a thin off white head. Rich malt, some whisky character, lots of toffee and sugar. Some wet card. Some yeast. Mostly a cheap whisky style beer. Malty and uneventful. Seriously folks, this is in the top 97% of 100,000??? How? This means that going by averages, more than half of what I have rated, is not as good as this. I just cant agree with that.
bottle pour a dark amber color the foamy head dissipates quickly. a sweet malty flavor with a light touch of spice. a wonderful scottish ale.

12 oz. bottle from phaleslu, I think.  Thanks for this treat of a beer.  This is why I trade.  Dark brown with red tints.  Creamy malty nose with a hint of spiciness.  Taste beautifully complex with lost of movement.  Sweet and malty and hints of chocolate.  Smooth and enjoyable.

a damn nice scottish, very tasty and smooth. more complex than expected in great ways, very nice choclate taste and creamy body make it go down very easily. nice stuff, great scotchy cocoa aftertaste. yum!
UPDATED: JUL 15, 2015 This is quite good. Rather earthy a bit of caramel, sweet but not too sweet. Not quite as good as Stanley the Vincent but good. Serving: Bottle
More good stuff. The Scots know their Ale, and I may be a descendant of Robert the Bruce. No, probably not.

Dark brown and nearly as black as porter with red highlights.  very small light tan head.  Nose is blended strong munich type malts, caramel, toffee, herbal earthy hops, and maybe just a little roasted character.  Taste is similar but dominated by malt and carmel.  Some hops come through in the taste as well.  full bodied and sweetness does not linger and is not cloying .  good beer.  Not my style but good.

Growler poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of carmel, earthiness, light fruittiness and a hint of smoke. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of carmel, earthiness, toasted malt and a hint of smoke with a smooth lingering carmel finish.

Bottle.  Pours a brown amber with a beige head.  Nose is fairly sweet with medium roasted malts, some nut, caramel, and slight chocolate.  Medium body, smooth, quite sweet with some caramel, medium malts.  Hops just peek through towards the finish.  Finish is still slightly sweet with some bitterness and more caramel.  A little too sweet for my liking, but still a good beer.
12 ounce bottle .A brown pour beige head. aroma and taste of thick roasted carmel malts,chocolate,sweet lite hop finish

12oz bottle in a thistle.  Pours rich ruby/brown with a thick, beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts with a little hops.  Flavor strong of roasted malts, chocolate, and some coffee and toffee.  Hops balance out this perfectly.  A great beer.
This beer is an easy drink with a great full flavor.  I prefer ales, yet I thoroughly enjoyed drinking this for a change.
Dark in color.  No head to speak of when poured from bottle.  Delicious fresh aroma.  Smokey, vanilla and nut flavors.  Very malty.  Im drinking in th summer, but it feels more like a winter beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a small tan head.  Fabulous aroma of caramel malt, toffee and a hint of hops.  Tastes of sweet caramel malt, fruit, hops and a touch of chocolate.  Very well balanced.
Warming.  A delight.

On Draft at FFF: Dark amber pour with mild tan head; smells like raisins or currants, Initial flavors of smoked malt, nuttiness accented by berries, finishing with heavy malt and chocolate. Mild sweetness and medium body. Love it.
had on draft at FFF brewpub, served in a pint glass.  pours fairly dark, with nice head of foam.  caramel, buscuit and bread dough noted.    balanced quite well.  Bought a six pack to-go.

Pours a cloudy dark amber color with little to no head. Caramel malt aroma, smoke, and fruity/grape-like esters. The palate is light in body, almost flat carbonation with a short finish. The flavor is malty and sweet. Caramel malt, cookie dough, with some slight smoke and wood. Flavorful, but average overall. Ive had better.
Incredible malt aroma, nice caramel notes, easy drinking bright sweetness with a hint of sour and a light bitter finish.
Tons of malt, not much hops, medium to full bodied, carmel smells, dark fruit and dark red color, smooth. 8 of 10 Chicago 2010. 93%

Rating 500. On tap at the Purple Pig in Chicago. Pour is dark brown with a solid one inch head. Smells of spice, nutmeg, cinnamon, mellow cinnamon. All the spice notes are mellow and not hot. Malty and well carbonated. Rich yet clean for as big as it is. Especially for a scottish ale. its not too cloying at all.

2010 Bottle - Pours a dk and clear amber with a small khaki head...aroma is cocoa and grain, light roast and plum, vanilla...flavour is lightly astringent, roasty and lightly smokey, dry toffee, nutty and dk fruits...nicely subtle hops playing the back, this was pretty tasty...not your typical scotch, but pretty enjoyable...
Mmm mm good malt bomb without being heavy in body or too sweet.  Dry malt flavors dominate, with enough bittering hops to balance.
Very nice Scottish Ale. Not too bitter. Very drinkable, yet still hearty. Notes of roasted malts and a slight hop finish. I will grab some more of these soon.

A decent offering, well worth the money and id definitely get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. Not my favorite style, but this one is very drinkable and complex, without being too big, cloying, or boozy. quite nice.
notes of caramel, bread, chocolate, and raisin. medium sweetness, lightly bitter, oily feel, medium body, average carbonation, long finish. great beer.
draft.  Brown color.  Medium carbonation.  Earthy hops with pine and grass.  Carmel malts.  Was expecting a smoky scotch flavor, but did not detect one.  Thick and sticky.  White lacing.

Let me start by saying I am not a fan of scottish ales.  However, this was a pleasant surprise.  She filled the pint glass with a cola color and almost no head.  The beak was hit with pleasant aroma filled with malt and carmel.  It floods the old cake hole with a smooth malty, carmel, toffee, kinda molasses taste.  Its silky and might be a little too sweet for some.  As a matter of fact, might be great with pancakes in the morning.  Anyways, I suggest you take a week off and try one.  Itll change your view on the head greenskeeper in Caddyshack and Rowdy Randy Piper....

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours a nice opaque medium brown with almost no head.  Has almost no lacing and is lightly carbonated.  Taste is malt (caramel, toffee, maple, and molasses).  Pretty good beer, but not quite as good as I expected.

Bottle.  Pour is clear deep brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is light toffee malt and a light resin hop character.  Really pretty rich and smooth.  Also notes of maple.  Flavor is fairly true to nose with an emphasis on the toffee malt.

12oz. Bottle:  Very faint caramel malt aroma.  Poured deep amber/chestnut brown in color with a tiny, tan head around the edges only.  Cloudy.  Slightly sparkling.  Full of tiny, and a few medium-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, caramel, nuts, slight hops, and a hint of roasted grain.  Medium body.  Smooth, then slightly dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, caramel malt finish.

This stuff blew me away.  Pours dark brown with a brown head, looks like a coke or something.  All malt and sweet nose and coffee and carmel and is very sweet.  I cant say Ive ever liked a sweet beer before, but I really liked this one.  I dont know much about scottish ales but this was an impressive beer!

Smells of chocolate and booze. Pours medium-deep brown with a small, lighter-than-expected head. Taste is similar to nose, not bad, could use some more hops. Mouth is extremely slick and heavy, not really my thing but unusual to say the least. More like a straight up brown ale than an American Scottish interpretation. Decent, not one of FFFs best offerings, but definitely drinkable.
Bottle. Pours mahogny. Small white head. Smells resin. The taste has notes of resin aswell. Also some cholote. Lots of malt. Smooth. Reminds me of double bock.

(last) Bottle at Monks Cafe Stockholm.

Pours mahogny with a yellowish head.

It is very malty with sweet tastes of gingerbread and fudge

Sampled at the 3 Floyds event at the Brickskeller.  Pours a hazy, mahogany brown with very little beige head.  Aroma is nice and malty, brown sugar, a little maple, sugary smelling.  Flavor is sweet, light maple, light chocolate, brown sugar, tree bark.  Has a pronounced malt flavor, just like wet grains.  Full bodied and sweet on the finish.  The components are all nice, but theres a bit of a disconnect.

Bottle. Thanks to mikesgroove for this Ubercool extra. Dark but clear brown colored pour. Aroma is quite sweet, reminds me of other american malt bombs like alesmith wee heavy. It leans towards molasses, some candied fruits, strawberry and also some peat. Taste is quite sweet, with a nice peppery touch from the alcohol. Palate is light and sessionable, some alcohol warmth. Glad I rate this style with the best, thanks a bunch Mike!

12 oz bottle from the brewery, served in an English pint glass. Pours hazy brown with a small, creamy tan head. Head quickly fades, leaving almost no lace. On the nose, aromas of roasted malts and chocolate with some caramel and maple. There is also a touch of earth and hops. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with a mild bitterness entering towards the end. Mildly acidic. The finish is medium-long. On the palate, medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. The finish is subtly astringent. Overall, a decent Scottish ale, but a bit too big for my taste. Sweetness was pleasant initially but cloying by the end. The appearance was unappetizing. 2010-05-28
Bottle, thx tarheels. Pours amber with an off-white head. Flavor is caramel/toffee, chocolate, malty sweetness. Great Scotch ale although not far off from Founders Dirty Bastard.

355mL courtesy of SpencerDB. Uh FFF just destroys the style category with this one. Really just kicks the crap out of all Scottish ale. I mean it is excellent- first beer in the style that hasnt made me gag over the moldy tasting toffee and bags and bags of crystal malt that seem to define the style. This rather is rich, buttery, loaded with milk chocolate, and all the malt forward character is not too sweet or cloying. Aroma here is malty, brown sugar, milk chocolate. All around excellent.
I only rate it here as its just not my style. High alcohol taste, really just a serious beer. Once it warms it is almost too hardcore to drink, not a bad thing, just not my style.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 I drank this before I really got into Scottish ales, so this would probably rate better for me today. Some spruce, maple, brown sugars and molasses. Rated 8/13/02

Re rate thanks to Rando7. Pours dark brown. Nose of whiskey malts and oak, some molasses. Taste is dry molasses and oak. Re rate: 3.3 5/22/10
Brown with little head but some lacing, great malt caramel and toffee flavors and still a clean finish

Robert the Bruce is a smooth Scottish Ale, it has a hint of sweetness, is robust and somewhat malty but not overwhelming. Its red in color and smells good, supposedly it smells like malt, alcohol, and coffee, but all Im smelling is pure greatness.

12 oz bottle from Casanova.  Deep caramel colored pour with a fluffy head that eventually settles down.  Sweet, malty, slightly boozy aroma.  Flavor is also sweet with some nutty, caramel notes.  Mouthfeel is thick and sticky and the finish is very smooth.
Bottle. Pours a clear burnt orange with a thin gray head. Aroma has notes of roasted malts, cereal, nuts and a touch of dark chocolate. Flavor is malty throughout, with a nice roasted note.
caramel, roasty, spruce, cheese, alcohol, leather, brown, hazy, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,
Amber caramel color on pour.  Nutty, malty aroma.  Heavy malt flavor, little sweet caramel.  Clean malty finish.  Love this beer...
A super malty bomb.  Not much balance in my mind, this is all malt.  Very quickly dissipating non-foam.  Im drinking it with food and thankfully.  Otherwise, a tough drink for me.

(Bottle, Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm) Dark brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, nose with notes of dried fruit, caramel and toasty malt. Malty taste with chocolate, dark bread, dried fruit, caramel and raisins. Medium body, slightly sweet. Balanced spicy bitterness. Solid and well made.

bottle pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is corn, rye, some brown sugar.  Wow, this really hits you with rich sweet bready malts, light roast, and some candy sugar and pepper in the finish.  This is good stuff, they knocked this style out of the park!

Three Floyds Brewing Company--Robert The Bruce Scottish Style Ale--2000 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV--28 IBUs.  (3.75 /5.0)  Clear rich copper amber color.  Mldly hopped fruit malt front.  Toasted caramel malt body with medium sweetness and malty fruit ale flavor.  Creamy malty medium body.  Clean mild Scotch spice malty end.  Sampled 2/2/2001.

An amber pour with a nice tan head. The aroma is super sweet malty with notes of fruit and roasted nuts. The flavor is very sweet. Complex with caramel, roasted nut, with only slight bitterness. The mouthfeel is very smooth and soft.  Finishes sweet.

On Tap at Club Tavern in Menasha, Wisconsin. Pour was deep golden with an aroma of a lot of toasted bread, a slight nut character, a little bit of roasted malt, and maybe some toffee. Flavor was real smooth with more bread and roast along with just a little bit of hop character poking through the malt bill. Real nice blend of flavors and a perfect medium to full body. Nice brew!

Archer was out of Brian Boru, so Im celebrating St. Pats weekend with a Sottish Ale instead!

Pours a rich mahogany with a thin, fizzy cream-colored head that quickly dissipates to nothing.  Aroma is big malts, caramel being the most pronounced, with a bit of raw sugar, scotchy peat, and fresh bread.

The first sip bursts with complex malt flavors, and the chocolate makes an appearance.  A tiny hopy presence smooths out the chocolate up front and leads into more standard malts, as bread and caramel fill the palate next.  Something is hiding in the depths of the flavor, maybe a touch of maple syrup?

Smooth, a bit creamy, but not heavy.  ABV is just right, unnoticeable but enough to give the beer a backbone.  Seems like it would go well with any kind of stew.
Bottle pours a dark brownish-red with a thin beige head that dissipates quickly.  Taste caramel and burnt sugar, a little bourbon maybe?  Minimal hops in a smooth finish.  Very solid beer.

Appearance: Pours a black iced tea color with a small head, that quickly subsides to nothing.

Aroma: Slight but distinct smokey peat, sweet bready grain and cola.

Taste: Smokey peat, cola, bitter hops and finishes bready with burnt sugar.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with modest carbonation.

Overall: A really nice medium bodied malty beer with a little kick to it.

Draft @ Three Floyds, Munster, IN. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with some spicy hints. Roasted malty caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty caramel finish with some spicy hints in the aftertaste.
Pours mahogany red-brown. Aroma-grains, yeast, sweet. Taste-grape, grains, sweet malt. Finishes clean and malty, on the thin side.
Medium to light bitterness,red in color,malty smell.carmel flavors,little to no head.The malt hides the 7.2% abv really well.

Big thanks to MOTOTODDHEAD.  this was an awesome beer to say the least.  Huge malt with caramel taste.  Very smooth mouthfeel  I have been on a scotch ale kick lately and this was a nice beer.  thanks TODD

12oz bottle.  Pours very dark red with very little to no head.  Malt, caramel and sour gumdrop aromas.  Toasted, nutty malt flavor with hints of cocoa bitterness in the finish.  Very smooth from start to finish.  Creamy texture and light carbonation.  Simple but enjoyable.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2015 Searched high and low for this brewerys stuff, and finally found this.  Pours deep red brown with tan head that flattens to a murky surface. Aroma is sweet malts, light roasted malt, ripe fruit, and alcohol.  Deep malt complexity with a roasted malt flavor that lingers.  Smooth and refined with no afterbite.  Nice middle of the road mouthfeel.  Light hopping to balance.  I was pumped to try my first Three Floyds brew and I was not let down.  Looking forward to scrounging up a different one.  Re-rate.  Almost 6 years later.  Solid beer for the style.  Great mix of dark fruit nutty malt and just a hint of roast.  +1

Bottle at Wilde.  Pours a dark red-tinted brown with a luxurious tan head of tight bubbles.  It smells of oats and malt with a good hint of buttersotch.  Smooth and sweet with a hint of sourness and a smooth rich finish makes this a nice scottish Ale

Pours a hazy looking dark brown with not head and a very thin white film around the rim. Aroma has a very deep malty aroma- some very nice toasted malt, mild caramel and toffee, light chocolate and a mild yeasty ending. Flavor has a very creamy malt flavor, overall a very sweet strong toffee and caramel sweetness, strong toasted malt middle and finishes with the sweet maltiness again. Moderate to heavy density for this brew with a creamy, mildly oily feeling and an overall low carbonation. Overall a great brew with a lot of solid malty, toasted notes. Very well balanced and all the flavors really work great.

Pours a semi clear amber brown with thin tan tinged head. Aroma is a mix of  hay, bread dough and caramel. Flavor is mild notes of cacao beans but balanced by the tangy malts. Body is light with fair carbonation.

Id tried this at the brewery way back when, but hadnt rated.  12oz bottle my wife got for me for Christmas.  Dark brown pour with a red tint and a thin tan head that disappears quickly.  Somewhat muted malt and brown sugar aroma.  Sweet caramel malt, dark fruits and nutty flavor.  Balanced out perfectly with the hops for a crisp slightly dry finish.  The texture is low on carbonation and is very slick.  Goes down a little too easy - didnt save much for my final score.  Great stuff.

Pours a dirty brown color which has a ruby/pink sheen to it in the light.  At first the taste and aroma is a turn off.  Aroma is your typical one-way malt-driven Scottish ale, but this has hints of cocoa and alcohol.  Taste is light cocoa, caramel malts, some dark fruit, and some earthy peat type taste.  I cant believe Im liking this!

Bottle from a sixer purchased at the brewpub. Pours a clear red/brown with a medium tan head. Malty and dank in the nose with some grass, caramel and peat. Caramel malt flavor with some peat and complex sweetness before a bit dryer finish.
Poured dark brown with a small head smelled of roasted malts and hops tasted sweet with slight hop taste not the best three floyds but does not dissapoint

A: Pours a nice reddish brown hue with a nice khaki head. The head dies down but a ring with an island does remain.

S: Nose of roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, and brown sugar.

T: The flavor was sweet malt, caramel and chocolate with a really enjoyable hop finish. Nice hopped 3 Floyds offering.

M: Medium bodied brew that finishes dry.

12oz bottle shared at a tasting thanks to bret27.  Medium-brown color with a small off-white head settling to a little foam.  Aroma is caramel, nuts, earth, and maybe even a little scotch.  Flavor is somewhat simple but good, with caramel, nuts, vanilla, and earthy peat.  Medium bodied with average carbonation.  Drinkability is very high.  This is great for the style.

Dont remember where this bottle came from but I suspect bret27. Pours a dark brownish amber color with a medium beige head. Aromas of bread crusts and caramel, simple but not bad. Flavor is similar but a little less robust than the aroma. Toasty with a hint of nuttiness. About what I would expect for my first Scottish Ale.
