(bottle) Pours dark reddish brown with a light tan head that quickly dissipates to nothing.  Aroma is really big on tootsie roll, with a pleasant undercurrent of roasted peanuts alongside it.  Further warming displays some toffee and a hint of vanilla.  Freshly made peanut brittle as well.  Flavors follow suit, with some of that tootsie roll character initially, but this is quickly edged out by the more dominant roasted peanut and caramel flavors.  The chocolate returns on the finish, but its far more dry here, with a possible hint of smoke as well.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is borderline spritzy, but not enough to detract from the palate.  This is quite a straightforward and simplistic beer, but it doesnt need to be anything else, as its quite good in its current form, and is sessionable to boot.
bottle: dark brown with a thick frothy white head, chocolate, malty aroma, taste is sweet, fairly malty, dry finish

Really good brew here. Pours a dark ruby/amber. Lots of smokey roasted malts of the nose. Palate has lots of malt presence. So much flavor to this one! Finishes crisp with some lingering malt aftertaste. Really well made. Definitely worth a try.

Bottled at Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a clear dark reddish brown with a rich sticky off-white head. Big fat malty nose of caramel, peat, fusge and dried dark fruits. Nearly full-bodiedn with notes of caramel, milky chocolate, fudge, peat and tobacco. Long fat malty sweet finish offidge, caramel, sweet licorice and peat.

Barn dust on in the aroma, light leather. Flavor has a big chocolate roast malt heart, raisins too. This is a fantastic beer, i can very well see me enjoying this in an irish pub. Three Floyds has won me over again.

Bottle 12oz. - Poured dark mahogany color with thin off white head.
Aroma - musty, damp basement mixed with leather and grape blowpop suckers.
Flavor - lightly sweet, tastes like grape blowpop and old woodsy oak.
Palate - medium bodied beer with slick texture. Carbonation is average and finish is dusty and has little aftertaste.
Overall - Awesome Scottish Ale!! I dig this style and this is done very well. Another bonus is this beer is 7.2% ABV. and tastes more like 4%!

12 oz. Bottle. Pours a dark brown, with a slight head that continues to live on the glass. A hearty woody/hoppy aroma. A medium to heavy mouthy feel. A warm, slightly alcoholic finish. Roasted malt is quite evident but balance of hops serves this great offering well.

On tap at the Three Floyds on 7/21/09.  Pours beautiful dark amber with frothy head and great lacy.  Nice roasty caramel aroma, touch of smoke.  Very smooth balanced sweetness of brown sugar with a fantastic finish.

In a pint glass out of the bottle at a restaurant in Chicago.

Pours a clear mahagony with a white head that does not linger.

Aroma is mostly malt with currant, raisin and spice. I get some esters on the end. Well balanced. 

Mouthfeel is full and bready with some viscous nature to it.

Full flavored malt taste with very little bitterness.  Some cherry on the finish. Well constructed.  I have only tried a few of the Three Floyds brews and this is my least favorite, but it is still a good offering.
Red-brown, beige color head with simple lacing.  Aroma is roasty, cocoa, toast, smoke.  Taste is sweet, caramel, cocoa, pine hops.

In short: A superior Scottish ale.
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed when about 6 months of age.  Sent to me by Shawn213, thanks a lot Shawn
The look: Clear light ruby-bown topped by an off-white ring of foam
In long: Light nose of fruity caramel.  Taste is straightforward caramel, toffee, dried fruits, milk chocolate, green peas (not unpleasant), tree roots.  The beer is sweet but doesnt feel heavy thanks to the woody hops that dry it out nicely.  Medium body and medium carbonation.  Name after a former King of Scotland, Englands northern suburb.

Amazing. Pours deep ruby color with a little off white head.  Smells of malts, caramel, and chocolate with a hint of dark fruit and nut.  Flavor is big and malty with subtle hints of chocolate, nut, and roast.

Aroma of chestnut, brown sugar, toffee and cloved honey. Appearance is ruddy brown with creamy head. Flavor had some mild hops up front, with caramel, toffee, dark chocolate and rum cake as well. Palate is creamy with a little liveliness. Delicious.

12 oz. bottle from City-Wide in South Bend.  Pours a dark ruby-brown color with a small tan head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of raisins, brown sugar, caramel, fig, and malts.  Flavor follows suit well, with notes of all of the above, as well as wood and roast.  Sweet and smooth, with a syrupy mouthfeel and medium body.  Really nice.
We can finally buy Three Floyds in Wisconsin!  This is the best Scottish Ale Ive had and I cant keep it in the fridge long enough!

Bottle, last of 36 beers I picked up at the brewpub in September. Not much head to speak of, but I cant remember if thats consistent with how its been. Dried fruit aroma - prunes, raisins, dates - chocolate, cherries, coffee. Flavor more of the same - this is definitely mellowed, but Ill rate the beer Im having, not the beer I think it is. Pleasant bitterness overwashed by a powerful sweetness going down. Bit of cola, bit of barleywine.

An absolute symphony of malts, wrapped in a beautiful deep red color and creamy mouthfeel. My brain cant even fathom all the malt complexity - roasted notes, chocolaty notes, dark fruit and maybe some peated malt. Just incredible.

3 bottles acquired via trade. Poured out a medium brown with a light tan head and minimal lacing. Aroma was roasted malts, chocolate, peat and caramel. Flavor was primarily smoke, peat and caramel with a smidge of chocolate and some light pine hops. Pretty good example of this style.

Bottle thanks to vferg.  Pours an amber body with an off white head.  Sweet malt body caramel, peat, light wood notes, toffee and a mild warming.  Light peat y roasted malt and a bittering end.  Nice offering.

Bottle as a generous extra from CanIHave4Beers... which reminds me, I owe him a box!  Pours dark reddish brown.  Complex lovely nose of earthy, sweet malts. Very slight smoke and a kiss of peat, but this is mostly about the malt. Bit of roast.  Comes through a little sweet, almost lactic or something on the palate... just a bit weird, though I think true to the style -- maybe I just wasnt it in the mood.  Still quite good.

Bottle from a trade with StFun. Pours dark brown with red highlights and a tan head. Aroma of toasted malts and chocolate with some earthiness. Moderately sweet roasted malt and chocolate flavors with a musty aftertaste. Medium body with soft cabonation and a chewy mouthfeel. Thanks Josh.

There is not much head on this reddish brown brew, and it quickly dissipates.  A slight aroma of chocolate greets my nose, but not much else.  Sip after sip affords a smooth malt flavor, with subtle hints of chocolate.  I cannot imagine a session with this beer, but it is a comforting occasional treat.
Nice smoky aroma.  Caramel in color with a thick head.  Taste is sweet and bitter with a lingering good aftertaste.  Overall very good Scottish Ale.  Another great beer from 3 Floyds.

Aroma is smoke, chocolate, caramel, and hops.  Some cardboard is also present, and tinniness.  
Taste is slightly sour, smoky, chocolate, and caramel.  I get more cardboard.  
Slightly old and funky, with a touch of hops.
Solid, but nothing mindblowingly amazing.  
For a Scottish, this is very good.

Pours brownish red with a thin tan head.  Pleasing roasted malt, chocolate and peat aromas.  This beer starts sweet with malt, caramel, and a little chocolate then finishes with a warming alcohol/bourbon flavor.

Served with a medium, off-white head and no lace. Color is a very dark amber with brown highlights. Aroma is very malty, sweet, a bit roasty, a hint of peat, caramel, toffee, and nice. Flavors about the same. Perhaps with a touch more peat. Body is perhaps very slightly thin and good carbonation. Finish is pleasing; with a tad bit o booze. Nice drinking beer. Seems like its tamer than it used to be.
Pours a dark amber color almost brown with next to no head. Has a nice malty brown sugar smell. Has about the same taste with a nice smooth finish to it.
12oz bottle, Thanks to Allstar for this one. Pours copper in color with thin tan head. Aroma roasted malt, brown sugar and caramel. Taste roasted malt and caramel with bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours dirty, murky brown with minimal beige. Nose is brown malts, brown sugar and faint molasses. Taste is smooth and slightly carbonated with some nice dark red fruit along with sweet malts and a nice spice character that adds a superb touch. I really thought this was great...will have to stop by Macnivens and get the tap.

The first time I had this I LOVED it.  I had to re-rate as I knew it was overrated because of the style.  That said it is still a very sold beer that I will always recommend.  Pour is redish brown with no head.  Aroma has strong malts, caramel, toffee and a small but of vanilla.  The first time I got much of the same flavors as the aroma, but the second I got a mix of that and hops.  Either time it is still a solid beer.

Cask draft at Birrerria Paradiso.  Ruby red-brown color.  Big head.  Big and malty.  Some fruity amber richness.  All out cask feel, probably a little differnet than the bottle.  Very thick and rich.  Strikes me as way thicker and richer than a "real" Scottish Ale.  Probably deserves a re-rate, as I had 3 Belgian beers right before it.

Bottle - Solid but not amazing. Deep ruby pour with no head to speak of. The wife pour very carefully, so I swirled it up and got some nice bubbles going. Took a whiff and got some rich, deep lactic malt--sweet with a hint of booze and peat. Taste is smooth chocolate malt with a touch of whiskey, light hops, and a bit of lactose and caramel. Feels smooth, creamy, and chewy in the mouth.

12 oz bottle from the brewery.  Pours to a fairly opaque brown with a one finger beige head.  Nice lacing.  Nose is roasted malts, carmel and a slight hint of chocolate.  There isnt a hint of hop presence.  The flavor has a huge malt backbone, with just the right amount of carbonation.  Its got a great roasty profile, while remaining fairly sweet.  The hops are doing their job well by preventing cloying sweetness, but going undetected from taste.  Loads of carmel. This is an excellent beer - I will be making the 200+ mile trip to get more soon!

Pours dark brown with a medium tan head. This beer has strong notes of chocolate, sugar, and caramel. Its a little too sweet for me, and I tend to look for higher ABV in a Scotch ale. However, it is extremely well-balanced and delicious. The aroma and flavor has lots of great malt and toasted grain. Medium bodied and very smooth. Overall quite good.
Dark pour with a fluffy head. Aroma is nice and sweet, chocolate, mellow spice and brown sugar. Flavor has molasses, spice, caramel and some toasted pecans. Very smooth, nice body. Great beer.

Bottle, courtesy of cexshun.  Poured dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is full of caramel with notes of roasted malt and a touch of vanilla.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouth feel.  Semi sweet flavor with notes of caramel, chocolate, spice like cinnamon or ginger, and fruity hops.  Bitterness from the hops balances out the malty sweetness.  Very smooth and well made, finish is mildly bitter.

Rounding out my top 5 at the GTMW: First beer I tried at the fest. After it settles, youre looking at a hazey mahogany coloured brew with a light brown head. Instant richness in the aroma. Caramel, some bourbon and raisins on the nose with flavours of honey, fig and black cherry with a deep earthy finish. Incredibly tastey beer, definately one of my favorite offerings from 3F.
Chicago Street Pub, Joliet- dark ruby brown, kinda smokey/malty, slight sweet, complex. very chewable.  good for sittin n drinkin.

(Draught at Ale Emporium in Indianapolis) pours deep brown/ruby, nice lacing but little head. Nose of cola, candi sugar, and toasty, taste is very toasted malts, sweet dark malts, cola flavor, and quite nutty. Palette linger is sweet, slightly smoky and full of flavor. Pretty heavy but solid scottish overall.

Bottle in motel room in middle-of-nowhere Indiana.  Pours extremely dark red/brown with a thin beige head.  Nose is peaty smoke and molasses.  Taste is more complex, with vanilla, peat, roasty coffee malts, banana.  Full-bodied and creamy with a scotchy vanilla finish.  Tasty.

12 oz bottle courtesy of secret santa. Thanks Rudy. Pours a dark ruby-brown color with a small white head that soon dissipates. The aroma is soft with roasted malts, hazelnuts and toffee. The flavor is malty and earthy with toffee, brown sugar, wood, nuts and a hint of hops. The mouthfeel is smooth and silky, with weak carbonation. The finish is long with lingering burnt brown sugar. Overall: a very nice, but ordinary, brown ale.
Had on tap somewhere in Madison.  Solid, but a bit on the sweet side. Had on tap, maybe should grab a bottle.

12 oz bottle.  Pours red amber with a small off-white head.  Mild aroma of nuttiness, a bit of roast, smoke, maybe some caramel and raisin.  Flavor is a mix of nuts and caramel, fairly sweet, with a touch of smoke.  Fairly clean finish at first, though a peaty smoke builds after a while.  Pretty good.

What a fine brew this is! A deep dark pour from a 12oz bottle  one of the last Indiana Craft brews left from a trip down there in June. The aroma is delightful malt, butterscotch, malt, Borkum Riff, malt, chocolate, malt, a bit of hops. I dipped my nose into the froth trying to take it all in.  The first sip is a little death. Complex but satisfying flavors of roasted malt, butterscotch, coffee, cocoa, and a subtle smack of hops on the back of the tongue.  I should drink nothing but this stuff .

O gude ale comes and gude ale goes; 
Gude ale gars me sell my hose, 
Sell my hose, and pawn my shoon- 
Gude ale keeps my heart aboon!
-	Robert Burns
Bottle. Aroma of sweet malt, brown sugar, maybe a hint of grass. Flavor of sweet malt, maybe a bit of earth, hint of metal. A bit cloying on the palate for me. Yep, its another bland Scottish Ale!

Bottle.  Pours a dark redish brown with a thin head.  Aroma is strong with roasted malts.  Notes of tobacco, brown sugar, sweet malts, and a tiny bit of hops.  On the palate, this beer is strong, but still smoith.  The flavor really brings out the tobacco type flavor, but the roasted malts still dominate.  A great beer for a malt lover.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2009 Bottle, trade bonus courtesy of mattmc1973. Pours a deep, deep red, only slightly translucent, with a small head. Aroma is initially of apple juice, then follows with honey, brown sugar, and malt. Flavor: Again with the apple juice, faintly this time but at the start, medium roasted malt, a little dark fruit, exempli gratia prune (juice). Dead mouthfeel. Couldve been a bit bolder all around. Overall, good minus.

Bottle thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum.  Pours brown with a small ring of white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, nuts, and peat.  Flavor of sweet malt, some vegetal notes.  This is the top Scottish ale?  This confirms my previous opinions about Scottish ales...meh...
6/4/6/3/12 (3.1/5)
clear brown with a small off-white head.  sweet, nutty, caramel aroma.  very brown.  slight flavors of hops with lots of complex malts caramel and nuts.  medium bodied.  smooth palate.

On draft at Pizza Paradiso (DC): Slightly hazy toffee brown. Roasted malt, dough and cherry aroma. This brew brings huge and complex malt flavors, then finishes bready with a slight but brisk hop finish.
Nice color and carbonation, but it tastes like someone dumped a bunch of soy sauce into the keg.  A common problem with this style.  A reformulation would be in order.
Bottle thanks to blutt59.  Pours dark black.  Aroma of caramel and burnt malts, flavor to match.  Nice smokey flavor.

Reddish-brown pour with a tan head. Nice malt aroma that comes out nicely in taste also. It also has a little smoke to it and some sweetness from the malt. Very tasty. Nice lacing on the glass. As the bottle says, if you love the malt flavor, try this one.

I always have at least a sixer of this in the fridge. Pours dark brown with some purple hues if held up to the light. Aroma of caramel, sweet candy, no hop presence. Flavor is super malty and sweet. Loads of crystal malt seems to be present, but it has a slightly spicy finish that keeps it from being cloying. One of my regular favorites.
On cask from PP Real Ale Festival. Brown amber color without much head. Sweet malt aroma. Flavors of roasted malt, earthy smokiness and brown sugar. Good finish. Pretty decent.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip.  Dark brown with a ruby tinge, with minimal off-white head.  Aroma of sweet roast malt, chocolate, and smoke.  Taste is sweet malt, and a hint of hop bite.  Body is light to medium, lighter than say, Founders Dirty Bastard.  Pretty good!
Pint draft.  Nice head, deep brown.  Malty sweet aroma, no noticable hops aroma.  Tastes malty sweet, caramels, nice hop bitterness.  I will drink this again.

12 oz bottle.  Pours deep dark brown with a nice tan head.  Smells of dark roasted grains, malt, and roasted almonds.  Tastes very roasty, caramel, and sweet malt, flavors of softwood smoke in the aftertaste.  Some hops give is a spicy, bitter balance.  Very nice brew, as I would highly recommend to everyone.
sample at Ale Atlanta 6/4... pours a dark brown.  sweet malts on the aroma which carries through the mouth.  medium body with aged malts and some caramel from front to back.  pretty smooth stuff.
12oz. Bottle. Pours clear brown with a lacy off-white head. Sweet toffee and nut aroma. Taste of nuts and malt, like the inside of malted milk balls. Light bitterness, a pretty sweet finish.

Poured from the bottle to a dark brown with a hint of red, a thin off-white head that lingered thru mid-glass and okay lacing. Nose was malty chcolate, a hint of roasted nuts and alcohol. The mouth was a bit on the thin side, and the flavor picked up the malty flavors, but the alcohol was most noticeable. Finish was short, a little bitter (the hops finally made themselves known) and a tad watery.

Not bad, but FFF has done much better./

pours dark brown with medium white head. aroma is very malty with some rich sweetness coming through and a little bit of hop floating around there. drinks smooth and malty with some caramel and nutty flavor and a sweet finish.

Bottle from StFun.  Thanks man.  Pours a ruby brown dark enough to be almost black.  Medium light tan head.  Touch of smoke and malt on the nose, and a bit of hops, with a hint of vanilla.  Thin to medium body.  Nice smoke, roast, and malt on the finish.  Pretty tasty.
On tap. Dark brown with tan head. Malty with some faint hops in the mix. Not terrible, by my least favourite of 3Fs so far.

Cask @ the Map Room. Tastes a lot better than it does out of the bottle and even on tap. Very dark amber w/ a bubbly white head; malty aroma with hints of smoke and caramel; flavor is malty w/ nuttiness and a light hoppiness- the cask version was very mellow and rounded; ends quite smooth, medium-bodied. Tasty on cask, but middling otherwise in my view (although this may be a function of my indifference to the style)

On tap at DLD 09.  Lighter, but nice aroma, much more leafy European (not quite noble hops) compared to the standard 3fs affair, though they are there.  Much more pronounced malt in the smell as well with butterscotch and some malted dark grain malts.  A foamy, medium sized caramel cream head, amber brown in color, medium appearing body, light carbonation.  A nice, smooth and good flavored feel with some minor carbonation.  Sweeter at the start, and drier at the finish.  Butterscotch is a big note, also toffee, malted dark grain malts, English pale malts, mild leafy grass, with a more citrus bitter in the finish.  Well balanced, and this one definitely grew on me more as I drank it.  A very solid brew, and about as good as it gets for beers of similar style.  A good way to start the day.

On tap at FFF during DLD 09. Pours a murky, mahogany brown body with a finger-width, light brown, creamy head that dissipates slowly and remains very lacy and creamy throughout. Aroma is loaded with English malts, butterscotch toffee toast, light scotch, and plenty of hops. I love FFF for adding hops to everything, especially the styles that generally dont have an abundance...like this one. They really make the boring styles something to behold. The flavor is similar to the aroma, but I get more of a light roasty chocolate than I did before sipping. A nice scotch flavor and lots of smooth English maltiness resembling ginger bread cookies. Good amount of hops that have that standard FFF citrus to it, but definitely leaning more towards the European side of things. The palate is full and very creamy. Is this really 7.2%??? I had absolutely no idea. Overall, a very fine beer to kick off DLD 09. Glad to have finally had the opportunity to rate.

On tap at the brewery on DLD. Pours a reddish dark brown with a tan head. Aromas of caramel and some bread. taste is caramel bread, fruit and some nut flavor. Mouthfeel was a bit thin as I expected something stronger, but nonetheless its a very good beer.

Pours a deep nut brown with a small beige head that rapidly becomes a thin coating over the top of the beer. Aroma is all Scottish ale; bready cereal, and caramel malts with chocolate undertones, nutty and sweet. Flavor is similar to the aroma with sweet malts upfront, and faint hop bitterness on the finish. As far as Scottish ales go, this is world class.

Bottle, from Bram.  Celebration of my finished thesis!  Pours dark brown with a small wispy head.  Aroma is nutty and malty.  Primary flavors of softly sweet caramel malt, earthy/peaty notes, and nuts.  This is my first Scottish ale, and for what its worth, I think FFF did a nice job with it.  That being said, this isnt a beer that is going to blow your socks off.
very pleasing kickass malty smell, light caramel and magic chocolate muchrooms .. . very mellow yet still a malt-osaurus!  .. "its coming right for us!" .. sweet and enjoyable ..
UPDATED: JUN 18, 2010 A good beer for noobs to the beer world to try if their  palettes havent adjusted to the joys of hops.

On tap.  Clear dark reddish amber.  Thin beige head, minimal lace.  Lasting aroma, lots of apple peel and peat smoke in the malt scents.  Flavor similar, lightly roasted malt profile, slightly peaty, lots of cider and apple peel elements; actually the aldehyde character gets a bit heavy on the chemical heat end of things.  Medium bodied, lightly chewy.
Clean chewy caramel wood character, sessionable scotch, very nice.  Shared at Liquid Sunshine
Dark pour with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and some coffee. Flavor is roasted with some nice caramel taste. Low carbonation with a medium body.
Another good Three Floyds brew, odd in that the palate is a mix of olives, toffee and a hint of chocolate, but it works out perfectly.
BOTTLE: amber pour, aroma of green olives dominates. Taste is more olive, malt, and bread. Pretty darn good.

Appearance:  very deep amber; very clear; light tan head that lasts forever

Aroma:  good, above average aromas typical of style, but may lack intensity

Flavor:  malt, but not too much; also has caramel accent; picture-perfect balance

Mouthfeel:  medium body; low carbonation; creamy, but dry with noticeable roasted barley; basically they wrote the textbook on this style

Bottle from TearsforBeers, cheers Nathan!  Aroma has notes of caramel malts, smoke, wood, and toffee.  A very deep amber burgundy hue with an average off-white almost tan head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is sweet and malty with a trace of bitterness.  Palate is full bodied and oily soft.  Very malty brew with nice roasted malt flavors.  Delightful but could be so much more.  The maltiness never really goes anywhere and ends with an earthy grainy finish that isnt that great.
light coca cola pour.  dissipating head.  a distinctive green olive aroma is evident.  mouthful is of olives, some residual sugars, touches of toffee.  Very full body, slightly creamy.

Pours clear brown  with no head. Aroma is Aroma is green olive, caramel malt, and dark fruit sweetness. Flavor is a malt bomb with the slightest roast and toffee. Palate is a tad thin, but full for the style. Great balance and complexity.

pours like a dr. pepper, small head. Aroma has an odd green olive quality, as well as some bread, biscuit, and definite malt. Flavor isnt robust, but quite tasty- definite spice and malt. Not my favorite, but very good for a lighter flavored beer- complex, good palate, very well crafted.

Bottle from Archer Liquor. Dark reddish copper color with a decent tan head. Rich malty aroma. Near full body with mild creamy carbonation. Flavor is very malty with touches of toffee and treacle. Theres a little something hot - like hop spice bits. For all the malt its not sticky sweet.  Certainly not dry either. It is a wonderful thing to drink.

Ive quite a bit of this one, both on tap and in the bottle.  Not a special beer, but very drinkable and well constructed.  A complex taste of caramel, toffee, and a touch of spice.  Refreshing and great with food.  Medium bodied, brown with a thin head.

Bottle shared.  Pours dark brown with a small tan  head.  Aroma of hops, caramel, toffee, bitter malt.  Taste is similar, with some spice.  The hops are more forward than is typical for this style.  Finish is bitter.  Mouth is medium bodied and carbonation is average.  Overall, an enjoyable hoppy scotish ale.

12oz bottle at Birreria Paradiso.   A darker shade of brown with a thin head.   Earthy caramel, toffee and hop aroma.   Sweet malty flavors of caramel, toffee, lightly roasted coffee, and some light hops for balance.   Medium bodied with lower carbonation.   Seemed good, but didnt do a whole lot for me.

bottle at home ... thanks to iowaherkeye for whats the last style i need (for the 2nd time) ... who would have thought my last style would be a Scotish ale... Deep brown ...  light dark fruit nose   ... sweet toffee slightly bitter burnt malts ...light spice ... quite robust ... could be quite heavy going ... but quite pleasent ... medium heavy carbonation ...

Pours dark red with almost no head. Aroma is malt and hops with a bit of nuttiness. Strong malt flavor with a balancing bitterness on the finish. Strange cinammon tingling sensation, as well as caramel, spice, and whiskey flavors. Good.

Apportioned with a lovely scotch color and a light glimpse of head. Lusciously malty aroma with some dark fruits. The flavor mirrors the aroma with dark fruits and malt soaking the palate. Perhaps tastes a bit strong than it actually is. Deep alcoholic maltiness. Some peat and dry woodiness. A tasty, complex  Scottish ale.

Pours a dark copper red with a small beige head. Peaty aroma of slightly roasted caramel and oak. Flavor is instant scotch. Very woody with sweet caramel notes and a little charred flavor. The finish is mildly sweet and sticky.

Bottle.  Poured a small, foamy, off-white head.  Dimished quickly.  Clear, deep amber/light brown color.  Heavy malt aroma with roasted notes and some toffee.  No noticable hop aroma.  Nice, sweet malt flavor with a distinct prune characteristic.  Some definite but not overpowering roastiness is accompanied by smokey undertones.  Some mild hop bitterness to balance out the sweetness, but no real hop flavor to speak of.  Medium body and softly carbonated.  Lingering but pleasant flavors.  Overall a very pleasant beer to drink.
Dark copper in color with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet malt and so is the flavor. Very sweet.

Pours clear with a very very deep reddish orange color.  The head is fairly small but retains a little head with a little lace.  Aroma is very nice with deep sweet malt notes, some good roastiness, rye bread, and some fruit. Flavor is very good, Immediately some candy like sweetness that is whipped right into shape by peaty and roasty flavors. A little bit of fruitiness mixes well with a mild hop bitterness.  The alcohol is warm and leads to a full nice palate.

12oz bottle from beer reserve, transfered happily to a pint glass. Poured a clear, brown tone, with a bubby, light tan head that diminished to a small ring rather quickly, although it left some good, clingy lace. The aroma was definitely roasted and malty. It also sported some other subtle notes of brown sugar, caramel, maybe a touch of toffee and molasses, and some underlying chocolate. The flavor added to these  more intense roasted notes and a pleasant hop bitterness. The  alcohol warmth followed nicely. My benchmark Scottish.

Pours with a thin light brown head. The beer itself is a deep amber-red color, and is pretty clear. Aromas of dark fruit, malt, and a hint of alcohol waft from my glass. The taste is sweet, malty and fruity as well. Some of the fruit seems to be hop derived, though the hops are fairly subtle here. There is a hint of roast malt in the finish, which adds a nice stylistic touch. This is quite a malty brew, with notes of caramelized malt, cherries, and raisins. This is most definitely a good straight forward example of a Scottish ale.

Tap at BarC: Pours deep amber with a tan film of head. The aroma is sweet smooth malts- dark fruit notes underneath lots of sweetness including vanilla, toffee, dark caramel and ripe prunes. Slick feel- richly malty flavor. Sweet but smooth with lots of caramel, light vanilla, toasted maple and graham cracker. Finishes relatively clean considering its sweetness. Pretty solid. I just like a bit of peated malt character in the style, which I didnt get in this.

Tap at Barcade.Poured a med brown with no head. The nose was light, with some sweetness, and licorice hints. Nicely balance, with good malt flavors, tasted some licorice, maybe some mint, and a good hint of the abv. Not my favorite style, but a seemingly good example
Dark brown with a huge, fluffy head. Malty nose with a touch of smoke. Flavor is sweet malt tempered with a touch of peaty smoke and a touch of hops. A bit on the thin side, but enjoyable. Good.

This was a really nice Scottish Ale.  It seemed to have a more smooth and slightly sweet flavor.  Not surprised that Three Floyds would take a style of beer and make it better.  Nice aroma, color, taste from beginning to the middle and sadly to the end.
Great Scottish ale. Smooth and well balanced with delicious roasted malt flavor

On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown/red, clear with no head.
The nose is malty and mild. The taste is roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and a little sweet.
Mouthfeel is mild, with low carbonation, which brings out the malt even more.
All around a great scottish ale. 7.2% is a little high, but thats how I like it!

About as good a Scottish as Ive had.My bottle could be a year or two old. If so, it held up well. Comparible to Old Chub, but not as roasty. This features a typical caramel flavor with hints of raison and dark chocolate.
Pours a dark brown. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and light coffee.  Flavor is roasty malts, caramel, chocolate with a hint of hops.
Because its a Scotch Ale, I avoided it for some time. Im glad to have tasted it finally. Sweet and malty, a well balanced and drinkable beer. Felt like a higher ABV than listed here.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 Deep, dark brown with a red-tint. Has a complex, porter-like aroma of coffee, raisins, roasted barley, bread, and chocolate. A surprisingly smooth, mellow blend of caramel and roasted malts envelope the tastebuds, while a hint of hop spiceiness dances in the background. Velvety mouthfeel; low carbonation. Whod have thought such a big and malty beer could be so drinkable! Truly a superior brew.

On tap at Chumley’s

Pours a resplendent brown with small white head.  The aroma is sweet and roasty.  The flavor is roasty, mildly sweet, and lightly bitter.  The mouthfeel is creamy, smooth, and lovely.  This is easily one of my favorite beers.

bottle into snifter.  Nice chocolaty roasty malty aroma that is almost sticky and sappy.   Great dark but crystal clear amber brown color with a nice offwhite head.  FLavor is very balanced and drinkable with some nice vanilla and oaky/woody notes, almost like a very refined and smooth bourbon.  Outstandingly drinkable. Medium body with medium carbonation - smooth.  Overall: dont have much experience with this style, but this is a very enjoyable brew.

Great aroma as soon as I popped the top.  I will leave the flavor description to others better versed than I.  Nice color, although the head was a little weak.  I think I would have preferred a tiny bit more hops, but this is one of my favorite beers.  Will put you in a good mood after work by the end of your first glass.
Deep reddish brown color with a thin off-white head. Caramel and chocolate in the aroma. The flavor is caramel, molasses, and, chocolate. Thick and a little syrupy. Nothing wrong with that.

One of my favorites.  Pint from the bottle.  Thick dark walnut color, with a small white head.  Milk/dark chocolate aroma, smooth and toasty.  Burnt chocolate flavors, with toasty malt, some semi-sweet chocolate.  Foamy smooth mouthfeel.  This beer is a crowd pleaser, even with my friends’ varied tastes.

Thanks to TearsforBeers, my Secret Santa, for the bottle!Ruby color topped by thin tan head. Sweet malty nose of roast malt, caramel, and plum. Syrupy sweet malty flavor, again heavy caramel, with slight bitterness and grain. Moderate body, sugary syrup finish. Not very impressive.

12oz bottle pours a light amber to dark brown with little to no head, but does leave a minuscule collar.  Aromas of caramel, toasted malts and quite a bit of citrus fruit notes.  Flavors are toasty malts, coffee, and more dark fruit.  Palate is a bit creamy yet thinner than expected.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2009 On cask at the Clark St Ale House  in Chicago. Pours light brown with a slight red glow. Nice creamy off white head. Aroma is very sweet with some nice sugar cane and caramel maltiness. Toffee and brown sugar are also present with a mellow woodiness. Flavor starts with a thick roasted malt and a very porter-like kick of cocoa bitterness. Brown sugar and biscuit like bread in the middle. Finishes very smooth and creamy with toffee and caramel notes. Medium body and a tasty soft carbonation. The cask really made Robert the Bruce shine and the flavor and aroma were just bursting. Delicious stuff.

12 ounce bottle.  Dark amber red pour with little carbonation.  Aroma was very sweet and malty.  Overall flavor was heavy on the malt, bitter with a little spice on the finish.  Overall a very solid Scottish ale.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2009 Dark ruby pour with a nice head. Malty, caramely, peaty nose.  Sweet, caramel, malty flavor. Big rich palate; no detectable alcohol.  Sweet, sticky, caramelly.  Also, awesome.  Excellent example of a Scottish ale.
bottle thanks to blutt59.  poured a deep amber with ruby hues.  aroma was caramel malt right along with the flavor.  overall not bad at but wasnt real impressed.
Comment of one taster on trying this one: "I see angels!"  I wasn’t THAT impressed, but it was a good example of the style, very malty, no hops at all.  Full-bodied.  Very much worth trying.

Via trade.  Will update this once I remember who it’s from.  Clear dark brown pour with lighter orange and ruby highlights.  Compact off-white head.  Decent lacing.  The aroma was roasty malts, light chocolate, smoke and light tart fruit.  The flavor was a smoky, light chocolate roasted delight.  Medium to thick mouthfeel.  Chewy and enjoyable.  Very nice.
bottle, dark almond color with no head, malty raisin nose, peat and smoke flavors with dark fruit, mellow caramel finish

Bottle from Kabutomushi.
Aroma: sweet, slightly roasted, caramel, molasses, dried fruits: dates, raisins. Dark brown color with a orange tint. Small, fine head quickly going to lace. Fruity, caramel and molasses flavor. Lots of dried figs, raisins, dates. Slightly burnt at the finish, like burnt brown sugar. Very nice. Finish is dry and full. Nourishing, thick and rich without being too sweet. Great balance. A fine beer.

Bottle thanks to blutt59. Pours with a small off-white head and a dark brown body. Aroma of dark malt, maple and brown sugar with a touch of smoke. Taste is sugary, dark malts, and caramel. Some what syrupy mouthfeel.
bottle thanks to blutt59.  great malty nose with smoke and caramel.  easy on the palate with a very malty/smokey flavor and a finish of caramel.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 12 ounce bottled shared by cdumler. Thanks! Pours a clear ruby red color with a small almost nonexistent head and only slight visible carbonation. Aroma is caramel and earthy malts with some peaty notes. Very dry and earthy taste. Mostly malty with some subtle chocolate and hop notes. Coarse and herbal finish. Medium bodied.

Pours a very dark, ruby brown in color. About a quarter inch of head on the pour, but is quickly gone. Smell is malts, licorice and some dark fruit.
Taste is caramel, some heavy malt and some more dark fruit. This is very creamy and smooth on the mouthfeel. Would like to see a bit more carbonation, but the flavor is very nice. Good solid, regular offering from FFF.

Bottle thanks to Optigon: Poured a deep reddish brown with a thin tan head. The aroma is caramel, roasted nuts, malts and hint of chocolate. Taste is smokey with roasted malts some soft sugary caramel or chocolate that adds to the enjoyment. This style has eluded me until this point (luckily I obtained this in a trade), since this now completes all styles for me I can actually say this was a great one to end on.

(10/14/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Munster. Dark amber color. Aroma of slightly smoky malt, caramel and some fruity notes. Sweetish flavor, a bit smoky, with malt, caramel, some bread, biscuit notes and hints of alcohol. Medium to full-bodied.

Another solid brew from 3F.  Thanks to msante79 for the pour. I really enjoy this style of beer. Pours dark amber and looks great in the glass.  Malt very present in the nose.  Exceptional taste, this stuff goes down so smooth.  Perfect carbonation and easy finish.  Would drink again and again.

Admittedly, sometimes half the fun in discovering new beers is the names that they are given. Granted a name doesnt make a beer, but if it is enough to intrigue and catch my attention, it has a good chance of going home with me, for better or for worse. Vice versa, a plain and unassuming bottle of beer has just as much potential of grandeur as a funky bottle, but lets face it, we are a visual people and what catches our eye first is more likely to be our first consideration. While Robert the Bruce ~ Scottish Style Ale wasnt a beer I picked up myself, but instead one that was shared with me by a fellow beer geek and friend, I nonetheless love the name and find myself rolling the r’s and saying its name with a silly grin on my face. Im also easily amused, but that is beside the point. Scottish Style Ales are a newly budding love of mine so I look forward to seeing how Robert the Bruce fairs.Three Floyds Brewing is one of those elusive and magical breweries who craft mind-blowing beers but also play hard-to-get. Robert the Bruce poured an earthen amber with faint ruby-red hues glinting where the light shines through. A small head fades into miniscule puddles of foam and bubbles, though she does puff up rather nicely with a swirl or two. Her nose is light nibs of chocolate, sweet caramel and toffee with crisp apples and spice notes. Candy apples? Not as heavy as a scotch ale, I am pleasantly surprised by just how light and effervescent Robert the Bruce is. She practically explodes in my mouth with bubbly wonder. Clean with a sweet finish which leaves a thin film of caramel and toffee in my mouth. As she warms, her mouthfeel grows ever chewier with soft and warm doughy pie-crust notes while the apples and spice linger in the background. Pleasantly thick without being cloyingly sweet or overbearing, instead creating a well-balanced medley of caramel, toffee, apples and spice wrapped up in warm bread with pie-crust notes.Robert the Bruce was an excellent if not a bit different scotch ale, though my range of experience with this beer style is still rather limited. Hopefully it will continue to grow exponentially while at the same time I savor that which I have enjoyed. A good Scottish Style Ale from Three Floyds Brewing. Hopefully, I shall come across another bottle of Robert the Bruce so I can savor her kilted depths once more.

Resiny, piney aroma with hints of toasted cocoa. Radiant ruby red colour. Medium bodied. Piney U.S. hop flavour with some nutty/chocolate malt flavours underneath the predominant hop flavour. Definitely and American take on the Scottish Ale

Pours a dark amber color from the bottle with mild carbonation and athin off-white head.  Smells and tastes of cedar chips, sourdough, sugar, and faint pete moss.  Nice, but nothing amazing.  As this one warms it really starts to tastes more like barley and stewed tomatoes.

not a scottish ale fan usually. but this one is an exception... black with decent foam, nose is bready and malty, with some alcohol and chocolate. good hop flavor wwell balancing the sweeter dark malts. smooth mouth feel.

Picked it up at the brewery with Honkeybra.  Crushed with Jakebra.  Not much nose.  Sweet malt, some scotchiness.  Flavor is pleasant but nothing special.  Not much finish, a little scotchy.  Hope sitting in the growler didn’t detract.

Bottle via trade with 1_2many.  I am really developing a fine appreciation for all things FFF.  Dark brown pour with a thin tan ring around the edges and no lacing.  Aroma is mostly caramel malt and some maple syrup.  Very balanced flavour with roasted malt, a hint of molassas, and milk chocolate. Just enough hops and acid to tickle your tongue at the end.

Pretty good beer here...deep copper pour produces an eggshell head.  Brown sugar, molasses, toffee and caramel in the aroma.  Flavor is all candy shop...with the exception of the hop kick that hits in the finish.   Another good beer by FFF.

Bottle from guyinchigago.  Thanks!! Nice dark brown pour.  Small tan head.  Aroma is full of nutty malts, dried fruit and some brown sugar and syrup.  Flavor is a total delicious malt bomb....caramel, syrup, and finishes with a slight dry and very slight hoppy finish.  Very nice beer.  VERY!

Bottle from StFun.  I love the smell of scottish ales with lots of malty melanoidins.  Reddish brown color.  Small small-bubble head around the edge of the glass.  Nutty.  Medium drinkability.  Pretty good, maybe very good for the style.

Pours deep reddish brown with a 1 finger beige head that last a long while and leaves good lacing. Aroma is nutty, cereal malts, roast, molasses, and dark fruit, oh yeah and some planty hops. Flavor is very nutty, lots of roasty and toasted bread malts, plenty of sweet chocolate liquor. Finish is roast malts and the perfect amount of bitter hops to make a nice profile. Body is medium to thick and fairly slick, without a hint of stickiness. Overall the best Scottish ale I have had, and fairly available in my area.

Pours a dark brown with a quickly disappearing head.  Aroma is nutty with some toffee and brown sugar.  Flavor is bit better though.  Sweet malts and caramel and nuttiness and molasses there.  Nice rounded body to it.  Finishes a little dry.  Pretty tasty.

12oz bottle from Party Pak Liquors (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a dark brown color with hints of red. Thick, one finger tannish head that settles slowly and laces the glass. Aroma is sweet malt, maple syrup, molasses, some chocolate. Flavor is also sweet and malty but with more prominent notes of chocolate, coffee, ripe fruit, hint bitter hops. Medium to full body with a sweet and bitter finish.

Bottle.  Poured a dark copper color with a thin off white head.  Aroma of malt and a bit of smoke.  Flavor is malty with a creamy mouthfeel and fruity notes as well.  Medium/full body with mild carbonation.

Poured from bottle bought at brewery.  Pours deep copper with a very thin white head which disappears halfway through.  Smells of sweet fruits and malt.  Taste is excellent, can taste malt and apricot with a sort of creaminess to it.  Not much carbonation, by the end it reminded me of a cask ale.  Terrific beer all around.
Getting notebook online. Bottle. Pours a deep red orange. Not much to the nose. Taste is decently malty I didn’t taste the chocolate in the description. Perhaps a retaste is in the future.

Courtesy of Idatetheformula.
Pours dark copper, white head.
Aroma is fruity (apple), sweet.
Taste has some dark fruits going, very sweet, malty and nice roastiness. Nice caramel malts.
Full flavor, one amazing Scottish Ale, very enjoyable and drinkable.

Growler from the brewery.  5 days old so it’s not as fresh as it should be, which is my fault.  Pour is a deep brown with a moderate head that fades away into a ring.  Aroma is malty with dark fruit.  Nice smell.  First sip is very sweet.  Very smooth and very complex sweetness.  Mouthfeel isn’t too thick, isn’t too thin, but is gone rather quickly.  Still good.  Solid brew.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of my Summer Secret Santa.  Pours a hazy dark brown with rusty highlights.  Moderate off-white head disappeared after the first two sips and left spotty lace.  Pleasant aroma of malt, brown sugar and dates.  The flavor is sweet malt with brown sugar and a bit of earthy peat.  Smooth with some caramel silkiness.  Enjoyable.

Pint glass.  Chumleys.  I thought this beer was fascinating.  It had a great smokey aroma.  It was a dark brown hue but had a very thin head.  Great flavor, had a smokey barbeque taste that was excellent, definitely a must.
Pours amber brown with a small off white head.   Aroma and taste are big and malty.

Deep amber-orange beer with almost no head at all.  Aroma is very malty and sweet.  Chewy and lightly fruity.  Some heavy caramel and toffee and perhaps a bit of chocolate.  Smells quite a lot like a UK barleywine.  Toffeeish/sweet flavour with a light nuttiness behind the sweet caramel. No smokiness but a lovely light cherryish sweetness.  The flavour is less sweet that the aroma might suggest (no idea how old this bottle is) but there is a nice lingering chocolate and caramel sweetness.  It’s a pretty nice, easy drinking scottish ale.
On tap at the brewery. This black ale poured with a decent beige head that dissipated right away. There is a fruity aroma and a nice caramel malt base that is quite smoky.
12oz - A fairly limp offering reminiscent of a brown ale.  Little malt, no real backbone.  Forgettable
Clear in look with a red to brown in color and a small tan head.  Malty, bread like, caramel, and sweetness in the aromas.  Taste is again very malty, sweet, caramel.

Has a nice chocolate malty flavor. Pours coffee brown with minimal white head. Like all of the FFF beers these days, it has almost no carbonation. Kind of bland - very malty, but not much character otherwise.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2008 Brown pour with cream colored head, thought this could have been a little darker and heavier appearing.  Some roast malt and toffee/caramel aromas.  Some roast and sweet malt flavors, but more smokey than roast.  Also some toffee/caramel.  Not too much bite and finished a little watery to me.  Maybe my expectations were a bit too high with how highly some of their other brews are rated, but I thought this was a little blah.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text:
chocolate, roasty, caramel
small head with a dark caramel color.
For a 7% ABV beer, you don’t really detect the alcohol that much.  First couple drinks were great, but after a few more the initial fondness wears off.  Refreshing beer, but I couldn’t drink more then 1-2 at a sitting.  Not as familiar with Scottish Ales, so not sure how it stacks up.

bottle poured into a pint glass - so i bought a 6 pack of this at Binny’s.  i wanted to support Three Floyd’s.  i’ve had some of their other beers and wanted to try a new one.  i have to say that Scottish Ale is not my style.  so i wasn’t too into it.  i drank down 2 of them and gave the other 4 away.  it’s a very dark beer with a strong aroma of chocolate and roasted malt.  i’m glad i tried it.  it just wasn’t enjoyable to drink for me.

So Three Floyds definitely competes with Bell’s as my favorite Brewery.  This was another example of a brew that just rocked.  Appearance was a dark clear copper with a small off white head that fades.  Aroma is nice of malts (chocolate, coffee and nuts), hops (sweet), and barley.  Flavor is awesome, and balanced.  Hops are initial followed by malts of caramel and nuts, barley and yeast.  Palate was very smooth and warm.  I wished I lived midway between Kalamazoo and Munster.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2008 roasted malt aroma borders on dark caramel but stays this side of the line.  color is dark for the style as well.  flavor is sweeter then expected, and lacks the alcoholic edge i expect from a scottish ale.  to its own merit, this also means its hiding its 7%+ very well.  roasted malts flavor border on brown ale-like, as i suspected from the nose.  lacks the hop sledgehammer id expect from FFF...hops are present enough to keep things balanced though.  i think i expect a slightly more syrupy mouthfeel, while this isnt totally straight in that regard, there is only but a touch of thickness available to the drinker.  i dont know that chocolate malts belong in a beer this style, while this is nearly a failure for a scotch ale, its a highly sessionable beer that goes down like a brown ale.  amongst all this, its interesting this is one of the handful of beers that FFF makes year round.

12 oz. bottle - thanks to brewczar for the bonus bottle - pours clear brown with no head or lacing; very raw and grainy aromas; almost like band aids; flavors much more enjoyable with some caramel and malty sweetness; doesn’t quite live up when next to Corne de Brume and Dirty Bastard

On draft at Clark St Alehouse in Chicago.

Appearance is clear red/brown hue, thin layer of off-white head dissipates, fair lacing.

Smell is subtle, tones of coffee malts, nuts, toffee, and faint hops, underwhelming for FFF.

Taste is full of coffee malts with heavy nut presence, some toffee, caramel, and brown sugar, grassy hops provide some balance midway, finishes sweet and dry.

Mouthfeel is medium-bodied, smooth and watery texture, mild carbonation.

Drinkability is high, this is a very nutty-tasting brown ale with muted aromas and fair texture, easy drinking and masked alcohol presence at 7%, great "session" brown ale that lacks some of the boldness seen in other FFF beers.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 12oz bottle. Pours dark ruby brown with a small head. Almost no lacing. Excellent balance of sweet roasted malts, with slight hints of caramel, chocolate and hop bitterness. Medium-bodied, smooth, and drinkable.

Pours a deep reddish copper with a minimal off white head.  Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, toffee.  Taste is sweet smoky malt, toffee, milk chocolate.  A medium body with light carbonation.   A very nice scottish ale.

After a great trip to FFF I ended up at Charlle’s pub next to my hotel.  Pint draft pour came  a very rich and deep copper color with a off-white head and not much lacing. Aroma is of flowers and fruit.  Smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is of ripe fruit.  I am not quite sure how they put this one together, but it is really good and easy to drink

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Well made. Does not taste like any other scottish ale ive tried. I will not hold that against it. Whatever it is, its good. Nice hoppy fruitiness on a very dark and malty brew. The combination works out great. Were left with a dark yet sweet and hoppy ale. Nothing like my other favorite Scottish ales but still an absolut joy to drink
A great Scottish ale.  A powerful malt taste and a nice smoked nutty flavor.  Not too hoppy, but has a good Scottish ale feel.  Pretty dark with a great brown coloring.

Bottle. Dark brown color. Chocolate and caramel in the firm aroma. Full bodied, malty sweet flavor with caramel, milk chocolate, licorice and a hint of cinnamon and red berries. Warming, though not alcoholic. Delicious, well balanced beer.

Pours deep copper with a small off-white head that dissipates quickly to a collar leaving only traces of lacing.  Smell is grainy up front with a big caramel malt backbone and sweet toffee on top.   Taste starts with the grain as well and gives way to the caramel and chocolate malts.  There is an underlying molasses sweetness that lingers through the finish as well.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied and sticky with fairly low carbonation.  This is a good example of a Scottish ale and one that I would seek out.

Bottle, yo.  Poured a deep ruby-brown with a wee, quickly disappearing cream head.  Aroma had licorice, peat, and roast malt.  Flavor was dominated by caramel sweet malts with a tiny bit of smokiness. Medium-heavy mouthfeel with little discernible carbonation, but still very drinkable.
FFF on tap- a nice change of pace when compared to the rest of this breweries hop forward line-up. Malty, slightly toasted, and well crafted. Quite enjoyable.
UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 Pours a deep reddish color with tan head.  The taste is slightly sweet with an earthy, spicy, malty flavor with roasted grains.

bottle by way of StFun... dark woody/caramel brown pour with an almond cream colored head. caramel-y aroma with some dry roasty grain, wood and spice. pleasantly sweet on the palate but there’s very little actual flavor... malty grain, wood, caramel, some kind of fruit and a spicy hoppy finish. medium to full bodied. a bit prickly though smooth...

Pours murky dark brown with a light brown frothy head.  Aroma is heavily malty of dark bread, cookies, toasted malts and carmel.  Lightly hoppy  and yeasty.  Flavor is heavly sweet and moderatly bitter great malt character, toasty, roasty, dark fruits, figs and carmel.  finishes slightly more bitter than it starts.  Probably the best scottish ales Ive had.

12-oz. Thanks, Ben! Dark brown with golden amber highlights. Tiny thin tan rim, no lace, no legs. Rich, grainy, husky, almost musky nose. Nice medium body, soft carb. Grainy and peaty mid-palate. Mild nutty finish.

Bottle from STFun trade.  This beer’s the best of it’s kind for me.  Usually, I’m disappointed when a Scottish ale either has no taste or a very odd taste, but this one was full, consistent, and smooth.  Excellent brew.
Bottle. Pours dark brown/black with a small tan head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, and roasted malt, with a bit of earthy hops. Flavor similar. A tasty scottish ale.

Bottle from a trade with STFun. Poured a dark borwn with almost no head. Just like the description says this is a malt lovers dream. Chocolate and carmel hops were the most dominate flavors. Smooth on the palate and an overall great brew.

Tried on draft as well as bottled.  Not a whole lot more to add here than what as already been said.  Amber color with thin head.  Varying flavors but to me didn’t collectively deliver anything that was overly pleasing.  Not one of the stronger 3F efforts but I will likely try again and revisit my original rating.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2008 Pours mirky medium dark brown with slight head that fades fast.
nice spicy taste.  I am not familiar with typical Scottish style ales but there is an interesting taste to this beer.
Not my favorite by 3 floyds but a good tasting beer.

Bottle pours chestnut brown with an off white head. Aroma of sweet malts with notes of figs and other dried fruits with a hint of sour.  Flavor slighty sweet with tons of malt a hintnof caramel followed by a bit of hops. Great scottish ale.

After drinking this brew, I asked myself "why in the he** did I ever drink any cheap beer? ...at all?  ...ever?"  A fantastically full & rich beer that satisfies, fills you up and makes you want more.  Robust finish that thankfully lacks bitterness and has a simple yet sweet aftertaste.  Fantastic on tap, almost as good in a bottle.

Poured a dark brownish red color with a tannish head leaving no lacing. Caramel, toffee, and roasted barley, plenty of hops present as well. Sweet caramel and toffee paired with roastiness, a lingering cocoa finish. High carbonation, medium to full bodied. Pretty decent beer to have once in a while, worthy of a try.
POured a nice brown color with an off white head. Aroma was of maple, nuts, malts, and some peat. Flavor was nice and sweet, like brown sugar with a nice finish of hops like most FFF’s

12oz bottle, courtesy of bwkrieger.  Thanks, Brian!  Pours a dark, clear wooden-amber color; light tan head that quickly fades thin, with decent lacing.  Maple syrup, chewy brown sugar, and a touch of roasted malts in the aroma; not overly forward; sweet, but nothing sticky.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy dried dark fruits, nuttiness, touch of oiliness on the palate; very generous, chewy malty core; drinkable, intricate scottish ale; minimal alcohol, if any, and just a touch of basic bitterness keeping things balanced.  Quite nice.  Lengthy finish: dried dark fruits, maple syrup, and just a touch of chocolate at the end.

Clear brown pour with a red tint.  Very little head.  Sweet chocolate malt aroma with molasses.  A tough of hops as well.  Creamy chocolate milk flavor.  Lots of malt.  Just a touch of sweetness, but bitter roast takes over.  A little bit of alcohol to finish.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009 All-out malt-hop aroma and a dark brown/amber pour.  The nose is piquant and sweet.  There is a funny drawing of Scottish king Robert the Bruce on the label, and the cap is cool too.  Nice flavor - caramel and piney hops, with herbal notes.  Fairly light, and definitely more sugary than anything I tasted in Scotland.  Thanks to Adrian for my first bottle of Three Floyds.  Note: revised downwards in 2009.  Seems to have lost some flavor and some hops.

20 oz. Imperial Pint draft at the Galway Tribes (Frankfort, IL). Poured an impressive deep, dark brown with some chocolate notes and some lighter shades that seemed to let a little light through. Aromas are chocolatey, with touches of vanilla and a very pleasant sweetness. Initial taste is sweet, giving way to a smooth chocolately taste with vanilla and dark roasted malt notes. A decent hop combination that balances well, but lets the malt steal the show. A wonderful darker brew that allows the malt to shine through. Yum!

Bottle, thanks TikiE.  Pours a dark clear amber with thin light brown head.  Aroma is sweet malty.  Flavor is like a light stout, clean taste.  Alcohol is hidden.  This is my favorite Scottish Ale yet.
Bottle: one of my favorite scottish ales! Pours a dark ruby color that is fit for a king. Full of malts in the mouth that lingers on the lips.

Nice dark amber color with a pleasant smell.

Slight bitter taste but it leaves a nice aftertaste of roastet malt.

Would like to try this on tap, to taste the difference.

Drinkable, but not too many at a time...
Bottle:  Dark in color with a thin brown head.  The aroma is primarily of roasted malt which foreshadows the taste perfectly.  I love this beer as a Scottish Ale.  Drinkable and well balanced.

My Mom brought this back from Indiana. I sent her for Three Floyds and she brought back Robert the Bruce and the Black Sun stout.
It is a dark mahogany color with very little head that dissapated quickly. The aroma was mostly roasted malt. The taste is dominated with roasted malt and has a heavy malt balance, which is appropriate for style.
There is a relatively low hop profile with a bite at the end which is accentuated with some dryness and a definate alcohol presence.
I liked this beer, its one of the better scottish Ales Ive had.

Bottle courtesy StFun, pours attractive deep ruddy brown with a very thin oatmeal colored head. Nose is dried fruit, earthy, caramel and molasses. The flavor is similar with a little less complexity. A bit more caramel and molasses. Very smooth and drinkable both in flavor and on the palate.

Amber with a frothy cream colored head, medium sized.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, sugar, bread and nuts.  Taste of caramel, sugar and light toasted malts.  Hides the alcohol nicely.  Creamy texture thats unbalanced to the malted side thus no real bitter qualities.  A little thin.
Draft at the brew pub.  Well balanced and smooth but doesnt stand out.  More of a casual drink compared to others like it, but still very good.
Draft.  Dark brown in color.  Malty flavors and aroma.  A good Scottish Ale.  Not my favorite from Three Floyds but still exceptional.
Poured from the bottle with a dark brown with a slight red tint. Very minimal head. Malty aroma; very slight chocolate taste.

12 ounce bottle. I was really excited for this beer. Everything that I have had prior to this from FFF has been excellent. Pours a beautiful amber color with a one finger width off-white head that disappears quickly. The aroma was VERY bland... the only thing that I could detect was subtle caramel malts and vely light hints of coffee. The flavor was also a bit bland. It consisted of caramel malts, toffee, and a slight hint of coffee. Finished very smooth. The one thing that impressed me about this beer is the 7.2%ABV. I never sensed any alcohol and was surprised to find out that the ABV was this high. Overall, a very drinkable beer... but nothing to get excited about.

Very chocolate-y aroma, with just a bit of hops smell to it. Appearance is a brown, that catches the light, and is what a beer should look like. Taste is kind of boring, just a bit of chocolate to it. Very smooth going down though. Overall good, an interesting beer, and my first Scottish ale.
quite a drinkable beer.  just a little to...fruity....maybe.  i dunno, just not a real standout beer...

Thanks to Mike for this bottle. Pours a dark eggplant color with a thin head. the aroma is toasted malts and some light coffee. The taste is rich and hearty; full of a toasted malt infused with coffee and a lingering chocolate finish. Theres some fruit in there also. Really smooth and no notice of a 7.2% ABV. I really enjoyed this one, just what I expect from Three Floyds, quality and flavor.

The King of all Scottish Ales. I have taken an extreme liking to Scottish Ales recently, and many I have tried have been weak, this however, was everything I wanted it to be. I smells like a chocolate malt at a 50s diner. Its pour is perfect. I got all kinds of deep complex tastes here. Some malt, chocolate, coffee, almond, and the faint taste of alcohol. I loved it and recommend it to all.

12oz bottle poured brown with ruby red hue. Aroma of malt, alcohol, and some coffee. Flavor was some malt, little coffee, alcohol, nut, toffee, and alcohol. I have not had many Scottish ales, but I enjoyed this brew.
Great Scottish ale! Got it on tap at DLD2008. Dark, rich body with a smooth, malty finish. Most Scottish ales are usually too malty for me, but this one was blended perfectly.

Brown pour with some ruby red coloring. Aroma a little weak, nuts, cocoa, malt. Flavor didnt offer much, was really not too impressed with any facet of this scottish ale. Definitely a session ale. On tap at the FFF brewpub.

Pours a nut brown with some ruby red coloring behind it. 

Smells of toffee and chocolate malt. 

The flavor is very malty. The toffee and caramel notes are also present, but the malts seem to dominate. 

Thick in the mouth, a heavy beer with a good balance of sweet and bitter.

Very drinkable, great brew. Im going to buy more of these so that I can pound them down.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 poured brown with orange hue, nice 2 finger head that stayed around.scents of roasted malts and citrus taste of malts sweet choclate and raisens,nice hopping that tones down the sweetness to a  slightly bitter finish,great job 3 fffs

On tap at The Blind Pig (if you are in Champaign, IL and are reading this, you undoubtedly already know about the blind pig!  If not, you MUST go check it out. Excellent, excellent place).  Chlocatey, rich coffee, caramel, toasted nuts, HUGE malt, mild citrus hops, and alcohol.  High ABV, which is typical for the style.  Tastes great.  Full, coating mouthfeel.  Long finish phases into more nut and caramel flavors.  Definitely not for everyone, but you owe it to yourself to try it.  Recommended.

Cask. Clark Street Alehouse. Toasted nuts, butter toffee, mild citrus hops, and a light touch of creme brulee on the nose. Malty and not overly complex but pleasant nonetheless. Cask drawn pours a nice looking thick copper/amber. Plenty of toasted nuts, toffee and caramel on the tongue. Just a faint amount of grassy hops. Silky and creamy on the palate with a lasting nutty, almost sherry like finish

Pours a hazy brown.  Aroma of nuts and chocolate.  Has a pleasant flavor with roasted almond, chocolate, and toffee.  A hint of alcohol in it.  This is sweet without being too cloying.  A well-rounded Scottish ale.

On tap at MacNivens. Deep brown with dark red highlights when held to the light. Didnt take notes when tasting but it was good good good. Malty and smooth, with plenty of palate but not too heavy. Tasty brown beer, not roasty like a stout.

another 3 floyds great beer. Flavor is the the key to this beer. what I would call a flavor bomb. sweet with a hint of nuts. Very smooth one of the better beers on the palate I have had. Would recommend highly.
One of the better browns Ive had recently.  "The Bruce is not to be harmed! That was the arrangement!"  Ill buy this one again...next time Im in Wisconsin.

12oz. Bottle. Pours a dark brown with some ruby coloring when held against the light.  Aroma of toffee, molasses and chocolate malt. Flavor is earthy and completely centered around the malts.  Excellent chewy mouthfeel and very little hop character. Just enough bitterness to keep the beer from being overly sweet.  Crystal, Chocolate and toasted malts are noticeable.  Small hint of peat smoke in the finish.  Fairly simple, but highly drinkable malty beer.  Well done!

Good but nothing to write home about.  Very organic tasting, like plants and dirt or something.  Not a whole lot of hops but they are there, this is just very smooth.  Really nothing stands out in either a positive or negitive way, but it still has enough taste to drink slowly.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle that has been in my cellar for about six months. Simple, clean aroma of toast, watermelon, grape, sweet tobacco, and carob, with a lemon twist. Pours a lightly hazy medium brown with a slight burgundy tint and a brass hue. Nice color but boring. Some suspended particulate in the liquid. Miniscule amount of short-lasting, thin, beige head. The lacing is sporadic and disappears almost immediately. Leathery appearance. Nice, toasted, malty flavor. Nuts (hazelnuts, almonds) and rich, dark fruits appear in the taste. In addition, there are chocolate-covered raisin and orange flavors as well as a touch of peat smoke. Excessively sweet in the finish, and the taste sweetens upon multiple sips. The beer tastes almost like a Belgian ale at times. Lightly dry aftertaste. Medium body. Crisp but low in carbonation. Easy to drink. Three Floyds Robert the Bruce is boring but not unpleasant. Im not a big fan of the style, but the brewers seem to accomplish their modest goals adequately.
On tap at FFF.  The armoas and flavors were slightly sweet showing off the malts along with chocolate, smoke and spice.  The palate was well-balanced and engaging again showing some sweetness.

Although this isnt my favorite type of beer, I still enjoyed this Scottish ale from FFF.  Pours brown with a little ruby if you hold it up to the light.  Aroma is of malt, caramel and a little smoky.  The flavor is very good, tasted a little smoky and you can taste a little fruit and caramel.  I didnt notice much chocolate.  Well done.
Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown color with minimal head.  Nose is caramel and malt with slight alcohol. Palate is caramel, chocolate and malt.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Overall a smooth drinker.

Courtesy of Juiceisloose. Pours a dark brown with a bubbly white head. Aroma is mostly oaked liquor. Tastes of sweet dark fruit, aged wood, some roasted malt, caramel, and little spice. Finishes creamy, with good amount of carbonation. Very clean brew.

Thanks pantanap.  The color was dark ruby, brown.  The head was thin, fizzy, and white.  The aromw as bran, cereal, light roast, and some small spice.  The flavor was bran, alcohol, and spice.  The palate was medium-bodied.  The finish was.

Thanks pantanap. Pours a reddish brown with no head. The aroma is a little peaty, smokey, malty, . The flavor is malty, raisiny, a little sweet, smoky and meaty, some alcohol, some hops on the finish. The palate has zero carbonation and ergo goes down smooth.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a thick off white head. Big malty, fruity, slightly smoky aroma. Malt roasted grain taste with fruit and some sugary sweetness. Very smooth drink with lots of balance. Finishes a little thick, but otherwise, wonderful.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Another FFF hookup from StFun. Not much of a head on this one. Smoky, peaty aroma. Cloudy, dark red color. Delicious, bittersweet taste - smoky malts abound. Perfect amount of hops. Smooth, bitter finish. A really great scotch ale.

Goes down very easily. If you hate hops, this is definitely the right taste for you! I tasted minimal hop flavor with a great "bready" taste. It says it was brewed with chocolate malts, but I personally couldnt taste them in this drink. Overall, a good balance for this brew. I enjoyed it, even though I prefer the hops.
Nice flavor!  Three Floyds has some great beers!  Brown and sweet malt flavor.  Yum!!

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 Robert the Bruce Scottish Ale is very nice. With a great color and better than average head, this Scottish Ale has a subtle sweet aroma and fantastic malty flavor. 

A nicely bitter aftertaste with hints of caramel and roasted malt accompany a smooth and great drink.

12oz bottle.  Beer is a murky, swamp water brown with good sized beige head, some spotty lacing.  Aromas of bitter sweet chocolate, caramel, and some dark fruits.  Flavor was mostly malt with a light hop presence.

Copper to maroon color with some light lacing and a lasting beige head.  Transluscent beer.  Smells of signature Three Floyds hops moreso at first and fades into a light but pleasant mild peaty maltiness.  Taste is smooth, mild maltiness with some tartness and a touch of peat.  Pretty tame flavor overall, I thought.  This one is still pretty drinkable but not to remarkable, I thought.  Good for a style Im not fond of, I guess.

one of my favorite styles and a formidable individual in the category.  big and malty up front and throughout. great satiny mouthfeel.  lost my notes on the notes, will re-review later.
on tap at the maproom, chicago, illinois.

2-5-08 bottle 

Semi transparent ruby red with big white fluffy head and ringed lacing.  Sweet hoppy aroma with an earthy dusty aspect to it.  Not heavy at all.  Flavor is earthy and sweet too.  Not too familiar with style but this seems much better than the others I have tried.  Palate is decent - similar to an amber but not too watery or carbonated - pretty good.

Forgot to rate this guy.  Dark brown with little head.  Lots of malt and dark fruit in the aroma.  Flavor is similar,  very well rounded.  Almost creamy mouthfeel,  little carbonation.  Glad to see this one come back around these parts.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2008 Brown red with no head, a malt-vine aroma with a surprisingly malt-cream-spice-chocolate flavour; great surprise as I have never had a Scottish Ale, Thanks Harry!!
Dark dark brown, with no real head. Sweet, thick malty aroma with hints of baked goods, woods, and raisins. Taste of malt, raisins, figs. Drinkable and very pleasant.

12 oz.  Amber/brown brew with aromas and flavors of sweet caramel malt and a finish that fades to a bitter roast.  Rich and mouth coating for the gravity...enjoyable but nothing spectacular.  Was expecting a little more from 3F on this one.

A beautiful deep ruby but no real head--fairly flat for the style.  Nice rich malty sweetness balanced with just the right bitterness.  Not usually my favorite style, but this is really nice.  Too bad this is one of the last in Iowa.

[bottle] Pours clear, reddish amber with a short white head. Malty, slightly sweet aroma. Flavors are full of caramel malts, slightly earthy... almost smoked malt character. Very subtle. Finishes with just enough bitterness to balance, and some nice alcohol warmth.

(Bottle) Pours a dark red/amber color, smelled malty with a touch hops. Small white head. Flavor is sweet and smooth. Excellent balance between hops and malt. Good scottish ale.

(thanks to stfun for the brew)
Not a big fan of Scottish ales so take this into account.  Has a strange after taste and really dont want this again.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2008 very nice surprise here. had expected not to be too big on this one, but was taken aback. i love stouts, and while this isnt one, it is dark, full of texture, and the aroma and taste have definitie chocolate and roasted malt. alcohol is a little pronounced, but was very pleased. this was my fave of the 3F bunch for a long time, until i had Alpha Klaus. if you like stouts and porters and havent gotten ahold of the rarer Alpha Klaus and Black Sun, this is a good alternative.

My first Scottish Ale.  Pours a dark brown color that glows deep amber when backlit.  A small, dense, foamy, off-white head shows good retention and leaves behind small spots of lacing.  The aroma is very malty and fruity, with little hop character showing through.  Chocolate and caramel malts are accompanied by notes of figs, plums, and a dash of cream.  Vanilla and almonds emerge as the beer warms considerably.  Minimal floral hops complete the nose.  The flavor is very sweet, with malts obviously running the show here.  Caramel, figs, and chocolate covered raisons kick things off, followed by that same nutty, almond and vanilla component.  The medium body is just slightly syrupy and a tad bit over carbonated.  Some alcohol shows on the fleeting, dark fruity finish.  This feels like a cross between a nut brown ale and a dopplebock to me.  Interesting, though not overly impressive.
12oz bottle.  Dark brown, clear appearance.  big light tan head.  Aroma of caramel.  Flavor of smooth creamy malts.  A medium bodied Scottish ale.

Draught at the Maproom.  Dark brown/ruby with thin beige head that disipates to lacing.  Aroma is caramel malt.  Flavor is sweet caramel, with some nuts and slight hoppy bitterness at the end.  Palate is a little syrupy, but very smooth and full.   Not one of my favorite styles, but this is one of the best Scottish.

bottle.  Pours a rich brown color with very little head or carbonation.  Malty aroma that is very rich.  Taste is not as robust as I was hoping and is kind of watery.  Very nice taste but I was hoping for more body.
great scotch ale, poured very deep amber, great malty taste.  Yet another great three floyds beer.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Bottle thanks to pepsican.  Poured a deep amber color with a rocky beige head.  Light malty aroma with hints of caramel and nuts.  Flavor follows suit with a nice malt backbone holding flavors of caramel and nuts that leads into a nice, slightly hoppy middle and ends smooth.  Creamy palate with just a slight bite on the finish.  Another nice beer from FFF.

Dec. 2, 2007; 12 oz. bottle purchased in Chicago, IL.  THRILLED to finally try something from this storied brewery -- cant get this in the East.  Sweet, with a remarkable palate. An excellent example of the style.

Ive had this many times, but rated from the most recent at Gallaway Tribes in Frankfort, IL.  Pours a dark brown/black with an off white head.  Roasted malts, chocolate, and a touch of peat.  Sweet balanced with chocolate, roasted malts, toffee, nutty, fruit and a peat.  Some times the peatiness is a little bit unenjoyable in this style.  But a good representation of a scottish ale.
12 oz. bottle.  Paired with Natural Dirt Half Corona.  Nice  brew, hints of chocolate, toffee, and carmel.  Unimpressive body, but a pleasant aftertaste.  Need to try it tapped at the brewpub.

Pours a reddish brown color. Off white head. Good lacing. Smells of roasted malts and carmel. Taste is rich is carmel, roasted malts and some hops. Drinkability is good. One of my favorites from Three Floyds.

12 oz. bottle received in a trade from GenoG.  Thanks Adam!!  Pours a dark garnet that when held up to light shows layers of color ranging from deep cabernet type reds to  coca-cola type browns. Off white head fades fast forming a small sudsy lace. Nose is full of roasted barley and nutty caramel. Hardly any sweetness which I must say is surprising. Flavor is sweet and mellow with an almost creamy mouthfeel. Lots of malts going on here. Can taste the hops in the finish but they do not take over the beer like some from this brewery. This is my first rated scottish ale. While this may not be my favorite beer to drink, its still very well made and definitely a unique entity in the american craft brew scene.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Acknud ( thank you, Bill ). Pours a caramel color with a 2 finger off white head.  This is a wonderful, delicious brew in a subtle , quiet way. Theres some sweet caramel, but not to sweet, theres a slight hop bite, for balance. Theres enough alcohol to make you know your drinking a serious beer, but it doesnt burn. I wish I lived where I could get this beer more often.
Cant believe this isnt rated higher. This beer has a ton of flavor, sweetness and hoppyness that balance out perfectly with the creamy malts. The best Scottish Ive tasted.

This poured a caramel brown color with a thin white head that dissipated quickly. The aroma was of dark roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, and a touch of smoke. The taste is much the same with the caramel malts and roasted malts dominating. There is a slight flutter of hops in the background. The flavors of chocolate and caramel come through the most with a touch of smokiness in there. It was medium bodied that finished with a sweet taste. I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle. Poured a very dark brown with a decent off-white head that stayed and left a pretty good lacing. Excellent aroma of dark malt and roasted coffee. Flavor of dark malt with coffee flavors and a wonderful earthy taste. This is an excellent beer.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2011 This is a very good brew.  Nice and malty--hints of coffee and toffee-like flavors but SUPER smooth, with a little caramel roasted malt sweetness. If IPAs are your thing this wont float yer boat!  Wonderful  dark amber color.   One of the best "Scottish" i.e. malty, beers Ive had.  Do yourself a favor and get some of this brew.   Kind of similar to a local brewerys Thunderbolt Red, only more malty, and their Heller Bock.   A very underrated brew.  should be 100.  Similar in taste and style to the Germans,s malty Heller Bock.  This beer has an excellent aftertaste.  One of my favorite brews from Three Floyds.  If so desired could be a session brew, but can also be slowly sipped while watching a good movie.  This is too good to guzzle down fast like when your really thirsty after mowing the grass ( stick to wheat beers in the summer for thirst quenching powers!)
