Starts a little sweet but finishes with a nice touch of malt & caramel.  This might be the best thing that ever came out of Indiana.

On tap at FFF brewpub.  Very nice malty body, full of complex roasted nuts and a chocolatey creaminess.  It was very smooth and rich, and was very well rounded.  It also carried a nice bitterness at the end, a quick balancing element that kept this sublime brew in check.

Courtesy of Quake1028 helping me finally fill the Scottish Ale style. Pours a muddy hazy brown with thin tan head. The aroma is nice and inviting, yum, but a little tough to describe. Its sweet with roasted malts and creamy crusty roastines. Then I get some dark fruit notes mixing in there with boysenberry and sweet dark fruity grapes. The taste is sweet with both sweet caramelized malts and dark berry to dark grapes soaking in a syrup of brown sugar. There is a mild earthiness that leads into a nice sweet caramel after taste.

Poured an attractive brown color with hints of red.  Nice slightly off-white head that hung around for a while.  Aroma is of caramel, chocolate, and roasted malts.  Flavor is of the same and taste improves as it warms slightly.  Lacing on glass was decent and mouthfeel was very nice.  Drinkability was good for a beer of 7.2% abv.  Good stuff.

12oz bottle courtesy Stine. Thank you sir. Light brown, almost root beer looking body, tan head that backs that up,very creamy looking. Unfortunately the head is fast to vacate, but does leave a layer of foamy bubbles atop the beer. Nose of malts, dark fruits, roasted beans, caramel and biscuit dough. No peat in the aroma at all, or in the flavor for the most part. The flavor does hold more caramel, big sweetness present, malts and a nice roasty character. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel, slick palate. Finish is more caramel and dough, lengthy and pleasing. Good beer, would like to have a fresher bottle.
Mostly tastes of the caramel and other sweet flavors. A good beer with a good alcohol content you can just faintly taste in the aftertaste, another good one from FFF

Caramelly bubble gum aroma, malty, metal,fruits.  Pours a dark amber, caramel color.  Smooth rich malty flavor, caramel,  sweet, molasses, smooth finish, little to no hops, very rich malt flavor, very enjoyable.

Aroma is a sweet malt scent.  Color is a bright amber with light carbonation and a thin head.  Taste sweet and honey like.  Starting a medium body it goes down smooth.  Finish comes in with a bold sweet caramel flavor balanced off with a nice hop bitterness and very mild hop flavor.  This is a very good beer.
Dark Brown pour with a minimal white head.  Nose and taste of dark fruits, chocolate, molasses.  Medium mouth and slight bitter aftertaste.

From bottle courtesy of jcr as a bonus...what a bonus it is,  thanks john! : Pours deep dark mahogany color with a finger wide foamy white head, that reduces after a couple sips to a nice foamy white ring, and drippy lacing.  Nose of roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, and brown sugar.  Flavor is roasted malt, with chocolate and brown sugar, very well balanced.  Smooth and medium bodied,  that leaves a very nice roasted aftertaste.
Cool mahogany body below a thin white head. Caramel in the aroma, but little else. Flavor is raisins, caramel, chocolate, all very good but a bit muddled. Nice mouthfeel.

Nov 2005 - Beer poured dark brown with red highlights, little head at all and next to no lacing. Rich sweet aroma was immediately noticeable. The flavor was sweet malt, caramel and chocolate with a really enjoyable hop finish. I really liked this one.

In bottle. Pours dark, molasses brown with a thing tan head, quickly dissipating. Chocolate and caramel malt aromas. Medium-bodied and gently carbonated palate. That wonderful sweet malty taste of a good Scottish ale. Light chocolate and sweet malt flavors on the front and bourbon highlights on the end. Very, very nice beer.

Poured into regular pint glass.  Almost no head, pours a dark brown.  as a sweet, malty odor to it, which is mirrored in the taste.  It is a very sweet, very malty beer, with a medium body and a smoky chocolate aftertaste.
Smells like dark cherry. No head, mahogany brown. Cherry Coke is the flavour, supremely malty with a bit of bitterness.
too much alcohol in my opinion. malty, as it shouold be, but the high alchol makes it taste wrong going down. i suppose this is a wee heavy as it was a wea heavy for me...

Poured from a 12oz bottle into an English pint glass.  This beer poured a dark, mahogany brown color with a thin, dark tan head that quickly disappeared, leaving a few patches of large bubbles that hung around a while.  Not much lacing to speak of.  The aroma of the beer was made up of malt notes including chocolate and caramel.  Also some smoke and roast shines through.  The flavor followed suit and was also big on the malts.  Some nice chocolate flavors arrive first, then they were followed up by smokey roasted malts, and also a bit of light caramel at the end.  The mouthfeel was slightly oily and medium-bodied with just a touch of carbonation.  Excellent!  A superbly done brew.

Pours dark brown, not black, with a light tan head.  Smells a bit chocolatey, and even what I would call "dirty" (maybe a better description is "earthy"), but not in a bad way.  Tastes a bit chocolatey, malty and finishes slightly hoppy.  Very nice Scottish ale.
Reddy brown color, amost no head.  Malty with some chocolate and a kind of smokey flavor.  A bit of hops at the finish.
Pours clear, dark brown. Aroma of caramel and roasted malts. Excellent mouth feel with flavors of caramel, darker fruits, and chocolate.

A dark brown brew with no head whatsoever.  Only the tiniest ring around the glass.  Aroma is nice sweet malt and milk that you have to work a bit to find.  Flavor is dry chocolate, and roasted notes.  Alcohol level seems higher than 7.2% and has a bit of a brandy effect in that it you feel like you are exhaling it.  After taste is kind of muddy.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 
Date: November 07, 1997
Mode: Firkin
Source: Brewfest, Real Ale Festival
Appearance: dark amber
Aroma: rich malt aroma
Flavor: rich malt flavor, slightly sour

Date: February 27, 2001
Mode: Draft
Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs
Appearance: dark amber, whispy head
Aroma: sweet carmel malt aroma
Flavor: lots of malt flavor, slight sweetness, well balanced with some bitterness in the finish

Date: November 18, 2006
Mode: bottle
Source: tasting
picking up some nice chocolate flavor and smokey earthy character

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: ** /4

bottle from mcox90: pours a rusty brown with a very small tan head. aroma of deep caramel malts, some spice and small hop aroma. flavour is roasty and caramel with a slight chocolatness. finishes nice and smooth with some spice. quite soft on the palate and very easy to drink.

Thin, disappearing head (probably due to bartender draft pour).  Darker almost nut brown color.  Sweet, caramel aroma and very sweet, roasted, slight chocolate flavor.  Clean mouthfeel for so many roasted grains and higher ABV.
350 ml bottle from archerliquors.  Hazy copper brown with a slight fizzy white head.  Caramel and slightly roasty aroma and taste.

Bottled
Beer with great sounding name. Dark nut brown color, huge cloudy brownish head. Toffeish malty aroma, light notes of whi cream. Fudge, whisky and chocolate - sweetish and liquerish palate. Nice dessert beer and good example of Scottish ale.

Copper brown; small lingering head.  Aroma of alcohol and amber malts, some peat, smoke and old tennis shoes.  Flavor of sweet malts and caramel, slight alcohol, smoke, scotch, wet cardboard, hops, mocha.  Tasted many times over the years and generally enjoyable.

Bottled (Thanks heemer77!). Dark murky brown/red colour with big off-white head. Lacing. Aroma is caramel, meat, yeast, spices and caramel malts. Very interesting and different, once it warms up, it also gets quite much ginger bread in it. Flavour is ginger bread, spices, fruity hops, cookies and flowery hops on the tongue. Very different from mostly anything I have had before.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2007 Bottle, Wills front yard.  Taste of peat, smoke, all malt.  Enjoyably complex.  A small hint of Dewars or Blackbush in there somewhere.  Could only have a couple- heavy taste and mouthfeel.  Well done.
Thanks to miketd for the bottle.  Pours dark brown, however its translucent.  malty aroma. hop up front. chocolate and malts on the finish. well balanced

Bottle poured into a small glass.

Pours a dark brown, almost opaque  with a tiny head. Has a malty smell with chocolate and coffee-like overtones

The taste has hints of coffee and chocolate and malt has some stout-like qualities. The mouthfeel is smooth with a full body. While it opens up as it warms up it has a dense like quality. 

This is a very drinkable beer. It stays consistent as you are drinking. Always maintains a nice flavor and is not too heavy yet still has a nice body to it.
This is what comes to mind when I think of a Scottish Ale.  Pours reddish brown with dense head, truly malty flavor with just enough hoppiness to please those who love bitter.  Pretty good.

Bottle via trade with HogTownHarry. Deep ruby-brown with a faint wisp of a tan head. Malty aroma with some dark chocolate and fruit notes. Smooth mouthfeel. Flavour is big, but not aggressive - plenty of malt and mocha, some chocolate cookie, and a surprising hit of hops in the finish. Solid!

poured into tulip.  pours a dark dark amber, almost a brown with a fizzy bubbly head.  sweet smooth malty aroma.  sweet milky creamy mouthfeel.  sweet and smooth thruought with candy caramel finish.  lots of bubbles.  almost tastes like a creamy thick sweet tea.  good stuff.

Medium brown pour, somewhat opaque and a thin but nice looking white head.  Malty aroma with some cherry, vanilla and light chocolate.  Full bodied, smooth and perfect carbonation.  Chocolate, mocha, roasted malts and bisquit/dough.  Finish has a nice citrus hop lingering aftertaste.  Very drinkable, very tasty, really, really good.

Bottle--Color was dark amber to red with a short lasting dark white head.  The aroma was of malt with caramel.  In the taste was the expected malt, caramel and a nice balance of hops.  1000 miler to Florida

On tap at the Clark Street Ale House.  Dark and reddish.  Slight alcohol smell follow by a sweet, spicy and chocolate aroma.  Very complex.  Tastes quite thick and smooth with sweet malty aftertaste.  Again, is quite complex, hoppy, malty, chocolate.. A little all over the place.  Great for a scottish ale.

bottle aquired via trade with Schutzenliesel..pour dark brown with a slight reddish hue..aroma of mild alcohol, chocolate, raison, and light spice...flavor is a bit of a let-down..somewhat earthy beginning gives off to a "hop-death" finish...the obvious syrupy sweet malts overlying the old hop profile...would like to try this fresh

Pours a muddy brown with a thin white head.  Faint aroma of dough.  Mouthfeel is smooth and velvety.  Flavors of cookie dough, biscuits, cocoa, and some fain mocha notes.  Finish is very dry and satisfying.
Bottle.  Light aroma of sweet malt, some yeast and spice.  The flavor is similar to the aroma; with apple and some tart.  Pretty good.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2007 pours a very dark brown color with a small off-white head.  The scent was very syrupy and malty with some hints of coffee and chocolate.  I was very impressed with the complexity of this beer.  There were some notes of coffee, syrup, roasted nuts and barley, malt and dried fruit.  There was an excellent mouthfeel with flavors dancing on the palate.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Pours a slightly murky color of brown sugar and cedar bark with a finger of tight bubbled, off-white head.  Some herbal, earthy hops float lazily from the glass with some maple syrup malts.  Notes of butterfinger candybar and light chocolate biscuit as well.  Medium bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel with a fleeting briskness.  The flavors start out lightly smokey with some juicy raisin flesh and a hint of fruity yeast.  This dries out quickly, leaving behind a pleasant toasted french bread crust lingering toward the back end of the palate.  Minimal hop presence on the finish, but loads of tasty malt caramelization waits pleasantly in the final smack.

Bottle from Corral Liquors in Granite City, IL. Pours a lightly cloudy burgundy-brown with  a small, rocky, off-white head. The nose is all about the malts: earthy, roasted and slightly smoky. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied, slick and soft while simultaneously washing the tongue with tiny bubbles. The flavor is of round toasted malts, sweet and almost woody, caramel, and toffee with earthy hops in the background. The aftertaste leaves just a tinge of bitterness at the back of the tongue, but the malts are king here. I really enjoyed this one.

Courtesy hopscotch.  Thanks Eric for bringing this special request for me!  Pours a hazy maroon, copper color with a small white head.  Smells od malts, caramel, and dark fruits, with a unique burnt toast aroma.  Caught me off guard a little, but made it interesting.  The taste is mildly carbonated, with a nice frutiness to it.  The caramel and maltiness were there, but not overboard which I like in my scotch ales.  Too much sweetness and malts throws the balance off.  This was nice.

bottle. this ale is a rich chocolatey brown that is very slightly hazed and displays orange highlights. very short white foam doesnt last for long. lots of sweet malts on the nose with hints of chocolate and light toast. well rounded smooth and creamy texture is a pleasure to drink, more chocolate flavor with some light roasted notes and a nice dry bready toasty finish with mild hop bitterness.

A fair Scottish ale, but I think it could be better.  It pours a deep caramel color.  Little aroma, not much head.  Up front, theres a solid maltiness, and something that reminds me vaguely of peat, though Im pretty sure nothing in here is peat-smoked.  Theres not much middle at all -- it kind of disappears on your tongue, until an aftertaste with a mild but pleasantly sour tang and a hint of alcohol comes in.  A good beer for drinking with food, I think, but nothing to get excited about.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2007 draft.  translucent mohogany.  almost flat.  (cask conditioned?) Taste of malt and fruit (grape like).  Super smooth.  Somewhat like a raison.  Interesting but not for me.  Too little carbonation.
Poured brown, minimal head.  Flavor was malt, dark fruit, some spice, & molasses.  Just a hint of alcohol.  Very smooth.  Nice.

Bottle:  pours an auburn mahoghany color with a medium off-white head and no lacing.  Nose is rich with dark maltiness and a little bready.  Taste is sweet and malty smooth with a little dark fruitiness.  Raison and winelike notes into the finish with just a hint of the moderate abv.  Thanks Eithcubes.

Im not a fan of scottish ales.  But as they go this one is by far my favorite.  That isnt surprising because somehow FFF seems to make beers taste great no matter if you like the style or not.  What you have here is a dark ale with a strang scent of molasses and caramel.  Very smooth taste with lots of hops and brown sugar.  The bitter finish lasts a long time as well asthe caramel and sugar.
12 ounce bottle. Shaker glass. Dark brown with a small head. Aroma was roasted malt and hops. Taste was of sweet malt, caramel and a hint of hops. Not as creamy and smokey as I would have expected.
UPDATED: AUG 20, 2007 This style really lines up with what three floyds does with all there brews. Sugar and oil!! I cant imagine a better scottish ale. Please try this on a cool rainy day. WOW !!!

light brown body with a red tint.creamy light brown head that leaves some lacing.nice aroma of chocolate,smoke,brown sugar,and molasses.flavor blends up what i grabbed in the aroma plus some pine hops,caramel,and butterscotch.overall id say its pretty damn tasty!

12 oz bottle at the Daily bar in Chicago.  Nice borwn with red tint and small brown head.  Spicey, floral aroma with some alc and deep malt notes.  Flavor of black licorice, caramel, alc is a little too strong, prunes, not bad though.  Light to med body.  A pretty good beer overall, but not the best from three floyds.

Pours a deep mahogany, with a bit of tan head.  Aroma is yeasty and malty, very pleasant.  Good malty taste, with a hint of spices that reminded me somewhat of Dogfish Heads Raison d Etre but much more subtle and subdued.   A faint cloying finish, though.  Pretty good stuff.

Poured into a standard pint glass, produced a small off-white head which diminished quickly.  The body of the ale was a clear medium brown color with hints of red.  Aroma was a nearly perfect balance of malt and hops, with a faint whiff of alcohol as the ale warmed.  Taste-wise, this ale was very satisfying with a creamy malt flavor, finishing off with a sweet, alcoholic glow at the end.  This was a well-balanced ale with a wonderful warming finish, perfectly suited for colder months, and great any other time of the year.
Poured reddish brown with tan head. Aroma of malt, fruit, and spice. Flavor was the same but with a hint of chocolate in the finish.
A clear walnut color with tan head.  Taste has a sweet roast flavor that is balanced perfectly.   My wife took this one away from  me and I never got it back.  Please go and taste this awesome beer.

Bottle frome Capones. Mahogany pour with tan head. I noticed some sweet malt aroma with hints of chocolate and toffee. As it warmed the flavor got extremly smooth. Malty, chocolate finish. I really really enjoyed this. It was just so damn good!

Bottle: This one pours a reddish brown in color with a brown head. This one smells a bit of chocolate, maybe a hint of a citrus, and I seem to even notice what may be a ever so slight hint of raspberry.  The mouthfeel is very smooth, just the right amount of carbonation and just a touch dry. I notice a hint of hops, citrus, caramel, and toffee. This is very refreshing.

2005 12 oz. bottle provide by and shared with csbosox.  Pour is brown with red highlights with a medium off white / tan head.  Lighter than Old Chub (which we were tasting side by side).  Aroma is roasted malt sweetness though not a huge aroma.  Taste is more of the malt, and very dry, almost a woody taste.  A little bit of oxidation towards the very end.  Overall, a very nice sipping beer.  Very interesting to taste side by side with Old Chub.  Not sure this helps me understand the difference between a Scotch and Scottish Ale, but fun nonetheless.
12oz bottle-A dark amber body with no head and an aroma of roasted malt and slight alcohol. Taste of malt with some citrus and dryness on the back end. Nice tasting scottish.

Appearance: Pours out a clear dark mahogany body with a thin, tan-colored head that dissipated fairly quickly.

Smell: The aroma is dominated by a heavy, sweet maltiness, mostly caramel, but one can also find some chocolate and cookie crumbs in the scent, too. Also, theres some hints of smoke and spruce twigs.

Taste: A clean, smooth flavor of toffee with heavy notes of chocolate and bread crusts. As the beer warms, the sweetness takes on a nutty aspect akin to eating sugar-coated walnuts. A trace of floral hops streak across the tongue late in the taste. For all its initial sweetness, this beer does finish semi-dry with a slight bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Low carbonation.

Drinkability: Another flavorful quality brew from Three Floyds. Hmm, this one could make for a surprisingly good session beer.
Deep red color with a creamy tan head. Roasted, robust flavor with a hint of smoke and a sweet finish. Medium/heavy bodied, normal carbonation. Very well balanced beer.
On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown coloured with a mediun sized head. Malty and round with notes of fruits and bread. Also hops and pines. Very well balanced.

Rated 2/21/07:  Thick amber pour produced a minimal off white head that left minor spotty lacing. Was surprised that I couldnt get a thick head to form, but luckily the mediocre appearance wasnt an indicator of things to come. Earthy malt scent with a slight hint of alcohol, some sweet figs and minor floral aromas. Extrodinary mouthfeel very rich, thick and filling. Hearty finish with a very slight trace of alcohol. Flavor is more involved than the aroma. Heaping malt content-roasted, sweet and smokey. Also flavors of fermented grapes, raisins, and roasted nuts. Complimenting floral hops are detectable but not upfront. What a filling fully satisfying brew.
Chicago Trip. Saturday 16:30+. On tap at the brewery. Very dark mahogany. Very strong malty nose. Malty peat flavour. Indecipherable words follow in my notes.....

On tap at 3F. A dark amber almost brown pour with a light head and lace. Not much hops slight fruitiness in the nose. A sweet rich malt flavor with a light bitter finish. A slight hint of abv comes through but just a hint. Just a tad overly aggressive on the carbonation for me. Very good Scottish that if not for the carbonation would have really rocked.

Aroma is sweet malt - chocolate, toffee, a little roasty and smokey. It is light brown with a red hue with a small heady layer on top. Many different sweet flavors reside in this beer: chocolate malt, some nice sweet roast and smoke, and the toffee from earlier. I also get a bit of sweet alcohol flavor. Not too many noticable hops, but I can get some delicate mild balancing hops to make sure it is not all sweet. Noticable lingering sweetness and warmth on the palate. Pretty good stuff really. I can get a small amount of citrus hop resin in the mouthfeel after not sipping for a minute or so, but it is mild.

Pours dark brown with a reddish tint - off white head that sticks around for a bit & a layer rest on top. Clean thick roasted malt - some burnt toffee - very grainy malt aroma. Taste is dark nutty / burnt roasted barley malt. Medium bodied beer with very grain feel - frothy medium carbonation. Finish has bitterness with a sweet maltiness. Nice Scottish ale with some extra hoppiness
Malty carob nose with a dark brown color.  Hint of cereal on the nose.  Body very sweet  and malty with some grainy hints.

A 12-oz bottle shared by brewfiend. Pours a dark ruby brown brew with a thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate shake, caramel, butterscotch and roasted barley malt. Taste is sweet, malty and more butterscotch. Finish is smooth, thick and no bitteness. A sweet aftertaste.

Bottle pour:  Dark amber in color with about 1/2 inch creamy tan head.  Scents are very sweet and malty.  Possibly some raisins and hazelnut.  Slightly bitter start followed by a well-balanced sweet, mildly bitter and strong malt finish.  Nice brew by my favorite brewery.

12oz bottle from Immy - thanks, Tim! This is definitely one of those robust Scottish ales that I truly enjoy - not quite the ka-pow of some wee heavies, but a luscious malty serving of goodness. Its crisper and not quite as full bodied as some, but I actually enjoy the variation and the emphasis on balancing the malts with some crisp hops. A nice way to tweak it.

Acquired as bonus in trade with Monger.  Poured a reddish chestnut color with a thin white head.  Light malt aroma with a defined malt background.  Thinnish palate.  Light malt tones with a nice hop tinge in the finish along with a bit of dryness.  More of a hop emphasis than most Scottish style ales, but the hops dont really take center stage.  Overall, a decent, drinkable brew.

Came across as a malt bomb to me, but very likely due to my extremely bad tasting procedure for the eve which put this behind about 15-20 other beers. Not that I didnt have a large enough sample. That is if 16 oz. is enough.  I did enjoy it, thought it was well made and much like I might have wanted, but as I had previously consumed hoppy beers (okay, JUST preceding I had a gumball) - this left me wanting to move on or wishing that some greater degree of hops came through in the finish. Good beer despite my whining.Thanks very much to 3F for bringing these to the Craft Brewers conference.

Medium dark brown.  Sweet, mysteriously mildly smoky.  Raisins cherries.  Finishes out with some astringency.  Somehow lacking the depth taht I was looking for, and pop-ish at times.  Enjoyable enough.  On tap, Clarke St Ale House, Chicago.
Dark brown, small head that disappeared quickly.  No lacing.  Thin body.  Malty and sweet.  Solid Scottish ale.

(Bottle) Pours a dark shade of brown with a moderate off-white head. Aroma and taste of a variety of toasted malts. There are hints of chocolate, toffee, and some smoke. The palate is pretty decent. Overall, this beer is good, but not too special...

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2012 12oz bottle. pours brown with reddish tint and white head. nose has some chocolate, toasted grains/nuts, meat, and subtle coffee. flavor is caramelly sweet, meaty, and toasted nuts. very malty. hop presence is well balanced and not over hopped. body is a tad thin. alcohol is well hidden. a great example of the style. 

12oz bottle 6/15/12, I finally get this beer nice level of hoppiness that plays in perfect unison with the tobacco and toasted malts. Some smoke too. Killer $10/6pk beer. 4.0

On tap at brewpub.  I love, love 3F-- but this one just doesnt blow me away.  Maybe because its a little closer to style and isnt overly hoppy.  Its still nicely made, but nothing in the flavor really catches my attention.  But its a 3F beer-- so its better than 99% of anything else out there.
SMOKEY SMOOTH AND A TYPICAL SCOTTISH BREW. JUST A HINT OF SCOTCHY MALT. CANT BE SURE IF I TASTE WHAT I TASTE. PROBABLY DUE TO THE HARD PRONOUNCEMENT. AYE LAD!

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2007 Finally I get to taste my first FFF!  However, the only other scottish ale I have to compare this to is Eries Red Ryder.  Had this on tap at the Vintage Estate Wine & Beer in Boardman OH.  The pour is brownish and clear. Has a tan head that fades to a froth after a few moments. Very little aroma, cant smell barely anything but perhaps some raosty ness. The initial flavor impact is medium high bitterness.  Has a little carbonation. To an extent it is a bit malty roasted bitterness. There is a linger that hangs on the back of your throat after the initial swig. I cant get over the medicinal qualities of this brew. Strong, apparently high alky content from the flavors, alky is not well hidden. Not impressed. Overall, except for the bitter alky attributes, this beer is not tooooo bad. Definately on par with Eries Red Ryder.  This is probably a scotch ale that is listed under the wrong category.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 Maltiest beer I have had. Kind of tastes like malted milk balls. Great beer with  lots of sugar and caramel and some chocolate followed by decent amount of hops. Very Malty and lasting aftertaste. Sticks to the tongue and tastes really great, especially on tap.
Malty, a bit sweet and almost a hint of fruit. Not much of a hoppy taste and quite smooth.
12 oz. bottle thanks to dmac621. Rich chocholate malty flavors make this very drinkable.

12 oz bottle shared with padrefan98.  Lots of chocolate aromas off this dark brown ale with an average head.  Flavors were were very good.  Roasty and chocolate and some coffee bitterness.  An excellent scottish.
Very nice. Had this on tap. Thiis review might be a little biased since I like Scottish ales alot. Pours a cloudy brown with a nice head. Nice malt taste that rolls excellent. Has a nice finish.
12 oz bottle...reddish brown, fairly malty.  Certainly doesnt taste like 7.2%.  I appreciate it, but not a big fan of this style.
12 oz bottle.  Dark brown.  Smells malty with hints of chocolate.  Tastes the same, with a slight bitter hoppy finish.  Very well balanced, but not extremely unique.
Part of a sample platter at the brewery.  Malty ale as expected.  Brown in colour.  Full bodied.  Biscuity and chocolately.  Loved the name.
UPDATED: DEC 3, 2013 Ruby-brown with thin creamy head. Sweet, chocolate, caramel, roasted nuts in the aroma and same notes in the flavour. Full bodied, Smooth with dry bitter finish.

Courtesy of dcharms.  Pours brown with a white head.  Smells of spices, caramel, and some soap.  Tastes of caramel and coffee.  Mouthfeel is thick and chewy and does the style well.  Finish is sweet and caramelly with spicy hints.

Pours light brown into pint glass. Very little/no head with aggressive pour. Very minimal lacing. Aroma is roasted malts with a little carmel. Taste is very nice toasted malts with cocoa, coffee, and dark fruit. Bit of floral hops at the end makes for a dry finish. Slightly too roasted for my taste but still very drinkable.

Pours a dark red/brown color with a small head that disappears very quickly.  Aroma is sweet malts, caramel, a wee bit of chocolate perhaps.  Taste is malty and smooth with some chocolate.  Didnt detect much hops, in the aroma or the taste.  This is not outstanding but I think its well balanced and a nice example of the style.

Pours dark brown, faint aroma with a somewhat thin body which seems to get thicker the more you drink. Definitely one that creeps up on you but nothing outlandishly excellent or anything--I guess Im not sold on the style yet.

Bottle.   Pours dark chocolatey brown color with a decent sized tan colored head.   Aroma is choclate, caramel, ever so slight hopa nose.   Flavor is chocolate malt, caramel, sweet malty goodness.   Palate is medium-full, medium carbonation, sweet, malty finish.   Excellent.
Deep brown with a small off-white head.  Full, malty aroma with a touch of smoke.  Flavor is more of the same - sweet malt.  Just a slight touch of hops at the end.  Very good example of the style.

Bouteille de 12 oz gracieusité de dmac621. Arôme: Odeur de caramel et dépices avec une pointe de chocolat. Apparence: La couleur est roufe foncée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de scre dorge. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de mélasse en arrière goût. (Rating #896)

pours amber brown with lacy white head. Malty smell with a bit of hops present. wow, i really like how everything flows together. Its not super complex or anything but its very enjoyable and drinkable....Im feelin it. Ill have another...maybe its because Im Scottish!!!!

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 bottle....poured a very dark brown almost black with a thin off-white head.  taste is very sweet and malty.  i didnt notice too much of a hop profile as it was mostly malts.  i thought that it could have been more carbonated as mine tasted kind of flat. this could have been a lot better me thinks.  overall i found it pretty average.
Nice malt forward taste with probably more hop than the Scots would like, but for people on this side of the pond, just right.  Nicely done.
Roasted malt aroma.  Deep brown color with off white head.  Very malty taste, maybe too much.  Not has hoppy as I would have liked, but still quite good.

THOUGHTS: Bought this and Goose Island Nut Brown Ale for the Super Bowl. Very sweet smelling with chocolate and caramel. Not much in the way of hops which is true to the style. Same flavors as aroma, but even sweeter. Great beer. I like the style and this one is a good example. Just the right amount of sweetness. Also a little coffee flavor.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a medium brown with a small, off-white head that mostly diminished. The body was medium to full and dry with fizzy carbonation and just a little metallic finish feel.

Bottle via trade with pantanap.  Pours a dark apple cider like, brownish/red. with a medium sized tan head.  Nice malty, caramel, and nicely spiced.  A nice taste, malty, caramel, spice, nutmeg, and a little alcohol tingle.  Overall, this is a really good brew.  Ive tried their Alpha King and Dreadnaught, and Three Floyds are just consistently good.  I am looking forward to trying all of their other brew.

I bought a 12 pack of this brew because i loved the labeling on the box with the Scottish Dude on the box holding a big ole honkin Mug of some Frothy brew, But i was somewhat Disappointed after pouring a glass  , there was barely any head at all ??  and it seemed rather flat!! But it was very  tasty with a sutble note  in the background that reminded me of Grape juice .  All in all not to bad . It,s pretty smooth drinking and offer a pretty good buzz.

Bottle: Boring appearence.... Alcohol and malts are very present in aroma.  Grape, breakfast pastrey aromas were noted.  The alcohol is strong right off the bat, with some raisin and sour dough maltyness.  The hops mixed in with the alcohol quite well until after the swallow, when only the dry hops remain.  Not bad when served at cellar temp, but over hopped if served any cooler.

12oz. Bottle

Robert the Bruce poured a deep dark mahogany that was surprisingly clear when held to the light. Half-finger off white head that faded quickly to a thin consistent coating.

The smell is good although a little on the weak side. There is an abundance of toasted malt. This is followed up by some dark fruit with a touch of sweetness.

The taste comes out as a smooth toasted grain followed by a slightly bittersweet coffee. The bitterness fades but a small amount sticks around. This isnt one of the most complex beers Ive ever had but it is enjoyable.

Medium bodied and smooth. Leaves a nice little carbonation tingle on my tongue after the swallow.

Drinkability is good for a 7% brew, The smoothness and medium body lets you drink a few. The taste doesnt hurt either. 

Sampled 10/19/06

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2007 Mahogany with decent, creamy tan head / Chocolate malt nose / Medium body, syrupy malts, with good finish / Sweet, malty, lightly smokey flavors of chocolate, caramel, bread, and raisins.

This isnt my favorite style, but 3floyds made it more than drinkable.  From a 12 oz bottle.  Poured dark copper brown with a smallish head that left pretty quick.  The aroma was malty with caramel notes.  I expected all malt flavor.  Although it is tilted toward the malt there is enough hop bitterness to carry the malt.  A little bit of peat flavor with lots of dark roast malt and caramel.  Overall a satisfying ale that is worth the $8/6 pk price tag.  I think Ill have another.

12oz bottle (thanks to ogglethorp) poured a clear brownish/red color with a small off white head. The aroma was smoky with caramel, chocolate, roast and some fruity esters from the yeast. The taste was really clean along with a small peaty flavor. The hops were noticable in both the bitterness and flavor wich is not typical for the style. Not as big of a body or as rich as I had expected, yet still a very drinkable Scottish Ale.

This beer was graciously shared with me by Daniel (00cobraR). This pours out a deep red practically brown with a decent little head on it. Daniel, informed me that this beer had about a year and a half age on it and that the hops were more subdued than when the beer was fresh. The smell was caramel and a bit of malty sweetness. The taste is was sells the beer. Deep malts with a nice peat flavor and a just the right touch of hops. This stuff was exceptional brew!

I can say that this beer lived up to its hype.  A very attractive beer when poured.  Deep red with a medium off-white head.  Not a lot of aroma, but there are hints of caramel and maybe vanilla.  Nice on the palate, decent carbonation.  The taste is quite good.  Crisp and clean up front and finishes with just a touch of bitterness.  Flavors of chocolate and caramel are noticeable.  A very good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2007 Excellent color poured from the bottle, ruby red, cognac, burnt caramel. Not much in terms of aroma. Light malt, some floral and vanilla undertones. Mild malty taste with no one dominating flavor. Hints of oak and sweet chocolate. While this is a pretty good beer, didnt meet my expectations due to some rather inflated reviews.
UPDATED: APR 21, 2007 Decent aroma and very little head.  Some smoke in there along with some sweetness.  Nice Scotch Ale.
My second 3Fs beer... Pours dark hazy caramel with some light ruby accents.  Thin offwhite head.  Fantastic aroma of caramel, molasses, brandy/cognac etc... with a flavor to match.  Great beer!

Bottle. Pours dark ruby caramel, thin off white head. Aroma is caramel, whipped cream, pine, molasses, wheat, slight brandy.   Flavor is grass, wheat, pine, caramel, chocolate. This beer smells a little better than it tastes, its still pretty good though.

1.) This isnt a scottish beer; scottish beers arent suppose to be hoppy.
2.) It is to sweet.
3.) It almosts taste like an Irish Red...even in appearance.
4.) NOTHING like the Cadillac of Scotish Ale - Belhaven Wee Heavy.

I didnt know what to expect from this one but I found out. The aroma is very mild; very. However when caught has a sour note to it. It pours into a glass a medium-dark golden orange with a good amount of head; almost none. The flavor is also mild but in a very good way. The taste is malty and crisp. The in mouth feel is more medium than heavy or light The finish is very smooth and lingering which is another good quality of it. Super slight chocolate undertones to balance the maltiness. Overall a super brew once again raising my hopes for DarkLord day. My palate accepts this brew with the full conviction of my rating but consider me as the X factor as I may have a slightly different taste for brews. 3Floyds has it going good! Also Im trying some right now but that is not the sole reason for this seemingly high score from me. It just fits my tastes.

Pours a nice deep coppery brown color, that show ruby where it catches the light. Sparse head of tan foam, decent lacing. Mild malty aroma, I caught a hint of chocolate about half way through the glass.

Sweet malty beer, with a little bit of peated flavor, and lots of tannin and some hops in the finish. Medium to full body, mild carbonation, fairly soft beer.

Good Scottish Ales seem hard to come by...which saddens me...and adds pleasure to the hunt. Robert The Bruce has no reason to hang his head. When young, theres a bit too much of the candy sugar/imitation maple syrup character that often mars American scottish ales....but its not so strong here that it hides the wondefully natural caramel notes that are the highlight of this brew. Six months in the cellar helps to mellow the cotton candy and further complexify the caramel--but at the expense of body and mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle. Poured a beautiful deep dark amber color with an ample creamy head that begs to be drunk. Aroma was malty and sweet with hints of molasses and maple syrup. Flavor was a toasty malt with a slight hint of smoke. Fantastic beer will definitely drink this one again.

Pours dark brown and clear. Basicly headless...not much effervescence to speak of...Aroma is nicely ballanced...hops and medium malt. Low carbonation with a big maltyness, some dark fruit, and just a touch of hoppyness. Definately drinkable.

12oz Bottle enjoyed @ home during Sabres 7-1 blowout of the Bruins. very malty & chocolately nose. Brownish amber hue with little head. Smoothe drinking scotch. Malt Chocolate definately present while drinking.Another Enjoyable offering from FFF

Bottle from Sprinkle. Pours a deep amber color. Strong malty aroma. Some roastiness. A little bit of an English hop aroma. Very malty and a little bit of fruity hop flavor going on. Bitter malty finish. Alcohol is very well hidden.
Clear mahogany. Medium head. Aroma of sweet malt with just a touch of smoke. Taste adds earthy hops. Medium body. Lightly sweet finish.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2008 Pours to a partly translucent garnet burgundy.  Certainly a malts-forward brew.    Swiss chocolate and vanilla aroma;some cherry.  Chocolate soda fountain, caramel, a little rum in the flavor.  A little milky and pretty roasty; mildly vinous in the mouth.  Dense on the surface, but approachable.

Pours a dark amber w a small off-white head.  The aroma is quite mild with a hint of sweet almost caramel type maltiness.  The flavor is almost as bland with a slight roastiness coming throught the excessive carbonation and a touch of alcohol lingers on the quickely fleeting finish.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Pours dark amber with a fully receding tan head. Aroma of plums, dates, caramelized wort. Taste is smoky and sweet, with notes of plums, caramel, oak, and leather. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with moderate carbonaion. This is simply delicious.
Pours dark brown, almost black. Some chocholate and caramel notes.  Loads of malts, some chocholate in the flavor, pretty smooth drinkin with a little alcohol burn. Good beer

Bottle, poured a dark clear brown with a thin tan head.  Not much aroma, a small bit of rich maltiness that carries over into the flavor.  Nice and sweat, a little smokiness and earthiness.  Toasted malts and toffee.  Barely any bitterness.  Medium to thick mouthfeel and a syrupy finish.  Nice brew.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: My second 3 Floyds beer and another winner. A lot better than any Scottish ale Ive tried...more flavorful and fuller body. Fat Bastard would drink this. The aroma was...oddly enough...iced tea. I wasnt going to write that but it appears that I wasnt the only one who thought that. The taste was full and malty with some caramel and a little hop interference. This beer is beautiful. Nice and dark brown/red with a small off white head with a little lacing. I would like to meet Robert, ask him what a "Bruce" is and tell him he makes a great beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: On tap at BW3s.  Ive had this too many times, but almost always out of a bottle as its being served at a big ass party.  Im such a sucker for it, but it turns out its even better out of a glass, and even better still on tap!  Hazy ruddy brown, dark with a dense lasting dark beige head.  Big rich round malt.  Caramel, some creaminess, ligh floral hops.  Fantastic mouthfeel.  Creamy full, thick, appropriate carbonation.  Flavor is outstanding.  Creamy rich round malt, accented by a bit of earthy (smoke? nahh), and more hops than usual in the style.  Lightly fruity malty finish.  Creamy subdued balanced malty aftertaste.  As it warmed up more, grape and deep malt more obvious (somehow) in the aroma and taste.

This beer was strange.  It has an aroma of iced tea, as well as an appearance and flavor of it.  Im not quite sure what to think of this beer.  Reading of the QC issues (as well as other issues Ive had with highly rated 3Floyds beers), Ill let this stand, but attempt to get it again for another try.

Ive had some quality control issues with this beer.  I recently had two bottles...the first of which was too flat to review.  This review is of my other bottle.

Poured an opaque brown, but appeared reddish when I held it up to the light.  A small amount of tan head with limiting staying power.

The aroma was of first alcohol, then light hop-esters, and then caramel malt.  I was surprised the caramel smell wasnt more potent.

Flavor is of fairly light caramel-malt notes with some oakiness.

Carbonation was very fine, which is good, but I still felt the mouthfeel to be a bit thin.

This beer is very drinkable.  Im surprised its not bolder, given the other offerings from this brewery.  I found this beer to be pretty mild-mannered for a Three Floyds product.

Brown and opaque with a mid sized head. Toasty malt aromas with touches of hops and fruit barely sneaking in.  The flavour is nice caramel and toasted malts with some chocolate and a bit of hops. Quite good tasting. However, I had one out of the bottle and felt the last 1/3s flavour had almost disappeared, possibly from roused yeast sediment?

Bottle.  Pours a brown color (looks like weak coffee) with a moderate white head. Caramel, toasted malts, nuts, hops, with a dark fruitiness in the background (fig and date).  Flavor profile is similar, except the fruitness is less pronounced and the hops are more apparent.  There is a definite toasty, nutty flavor.  Finish lacks the complexity I hoped for, and its a bit watery.  Good carbonation.  Overall, a nice, drinkable beer, but not very complex.  Alcohol is apparent in the flavor, but doesnt lend itself to build any body.

Dark reddish brown pour with very little head.  Nose is malty sweetness with some fruitiness in the background.  Palate is thinner than the appearance let on - it looked kind of think and syrupy, but didnt feel that way.  Taste sort of like a weak barley wine.  Not as sweet as the nose suggest, slightly astringent finish.
Off tap into pint- poured brown with small head.  Consistency was medium bodied.  Aromas of sweet molasses and butterscotch- taste is bold and pleasant-
Medium brown in color with light head. Aroma was good. Flavor was really odd- tasted like mixed vegetables. It wasnt bad, but not really that pleasant either

12 oz. bottle.  Great looking red pour with a bit of an off-white head that leaves a bit of lacing.  Great brown sugar, malty aroma.  Caramel and bready flavors.  This one is def. all about the malts.  But, in true FFF character, there is a nice hoppy finish.  Good stuff.
Nice malty character with just enough hops to balance.  Roasty and slightly chocolatey.  Nice easy drinking beer.

Rich, brown color, with a thin head. Some lacing, though, and that was nice to see. Aroma is mostly malt. Initial flavor is of sweet roasted malt, mild chocolate, and some alcohol. A very gently bitterness is present in the finish. Cabonation is on the lighter side. Very smooth beer.

This beer is dark brown in color and quite cloudy.  Maybe murky would be a better way to describe it; opaque none the less.  It has a small fizzy tan head that dissipates quickly.  Its aroma is muted chocolate malt and alcohol.  The flavor is lacking.  It is moderately sweet, but mostly generic with just some darker/roasted malt in it.  The finish is chalky and has an almost unpleasant bitterness to it that doesnt fit with the beer.  Maybe thats just some of the peat-like characteristics coming through, but it still seems a bit off. This beer has a mild level of carbonation, a medium body, and is fairly smooth.  Good, but not and overly impressive Scottish Ale.

12 oz botttle, $1.50+tax from Pauken Wine Shop.

The best thing about this brew is the label.  Overall I found it somewhat non-discript.  More malt than hops but thin. I had this in draft at the brew pub and in bottle.  I was disappointed in the brew pub, very limited selection. I visited Three Floyds on my way from Syracuse to Chicago. Their Alpha King is a good pale ale but of Robert the Bruce, I like the name and lable
Aroma is of slight hops and caramel.Pours dark brown with very little head.Flavor is very malty with some slight hops.Medium mouthfeel with a sweet finish.
GABF-on tap-pours a light brown haead with dark brown color.  Taste is scotch, sweet malt-caramel.  OK carbonation.

Pours a two finger light tan head that fades slowly to a shallow layer leaving some lace.   Deep amber color.  Light carbonation and medium bodied. Faint caramel nose.  Starts balanced with some caramel sweetness, smooth, finish some hops showing up but a nice Scottish Ale. The ABV is vague, their site lists it at 7.2ABW?? Thats 9.1% ABV. $1.59 for a 12oz bottle from Johns Grocery Iowa City, Ia.

Tried it at work with an old co-worker.  By the time I got around to tasting and rating the beer was room-temp.  Still hoppy and smooth on the palate with a slight linger.  My sinuses are clogged so I am unable to accurately get the aroma but I am liking what hints I can pick up.  That would be hops and yeast with some caramel

Pours a wonderful looking dark brown, with next to no head.  Aroma smells a little caramelly, a little chocolate even, but moreso dark rye bread and some pungent herbal/vegetable hops.  Taste is very smooth, with some roasty and dark chocolate flavors, some breadiness, and light caramel.  Finishes a bit dryer, with a burnt smokiness, along with a nice herbal hop aftertaste.  Good medium mouthfeel, low carbonation, and very smooth.  Im seeing why people like Three Floyds so much.

12 oz bottle from wheninhell. Not sure how I have not rated this yet. Anyway - clear, dark amber with a small tan head. Light caramel and nut nose. Medium-light body. Nutty caramel flavor, bitter walnut. Sweet, light bread. Finish is bitter nut. Good.

12 oz bottle.  Nice dark brown, cloudy pour.    Great, rich malty aroma with a nice roasted scent.  Taste has rich, sweet caramel-corn malt.  Very sweet, very smooth.  Goes down nicely after sliding over the palate with a lasting flavor.  Another good 3Fs brew.

One of my first scottish style ales. I was taken in by its large scale. Very dark heavy with a roasted taste and aroma. Tons of malts and the right balance of hops. I became a true fan after trying it on tap. Great full beer hands down.

12 oz bottle. This is an Interesting, but unremarkable beer.  Small aroma of malt and that same hop smell that every three floyds beer has......cant describe it, but its not a fresh hop taste that you find in many hoppy beers.  Dark brown, almost black color.  Taste is malty/choloate.....everything is going well, but then I get this weird peppery/spicy aftertaste that just doesnt do it for me.   Finish almost tastes like asparatame.  Weird beer.

12 oz bottle via Monger (thanks james!) Pours a clear dark reddish brown with an average sixe beige head. Nose has some caramel malts and fruity esters (mostly plums/strawberries) and toffee. Tastes quite a bit different though. Almost tastes like it has rye in it with some cocolate malts. Also some chalkiness in the finish. Full bodied. Very dry crisp finish. Lingering bitter aftertaste...i like it until the finish/aftertaste....then it loses its appeal and does not make me reach for the next sip.

Bottle at acertains house.

This one was first of the Three Floyds offerings, and I was very excited to try it. Unfortunately, it was a disappointment. It poured caramel brown, flat with a limited head. The nose was roasty, some dark caramel, but the flavor surprisingly hoppy  - turning metallic on the long side - and that didnt work particularly well for the style.
Bottle.  Weak aroma and average appearance.  Brown with quickly diminishing head.  Flavor is good.  Sweet with a light bitter finish.  Very drinkable.  Watery palate.  Decent overall.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 not my type of beer but you have to try all of three floyds. i think they are one of the best brewing companys out there. this one has a clear dark brown medium body with a descent size tan head. has a balanced sweet toffe taste to it with a little bitter coffee finish.not the best from three floyds but a must try.

dark brown with a tan head. heavy coffee aroma with some chocolate toffee and caramel. flavor balanced bittersweet toffee. full body. lovely chocolate and caramel flavors leading into a bitter coffee finish. clean simple flavors. love this beer.

12 oz bottle.  Clear teak brown with a moderate tan head that thins with a lace ring.  Very faint peat and ground coffee.  Anise sweetness up front.  Mocha and some drying nutty hops.  Medium body, light carb.
Pours a dark redish brown.  Aroma of sweet malt, fruit, and a little smoke. Flavors of caramel, roasted malt, and a little fruit.  Sweet and easy to drink, not much hops.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2007 GABF 2006.  applewood aroma.  little sour malts and sugar.  cardboard.  mouth is sugary, mild chocolate, coffee. rich caramel malts.  not nearly as impressive as their other brews.

bottle - Pours dark brown with a small head.  The aroma is strong caramel malts and the taste follows suit, but also pulls off a pretty good hops balance.  The body is medium to full and it feels lightly carbonated.  The malt flavors are great.  Finally theres a pleasantly dry finish with a touch of alcohol.  Good beer.
GABF 06. Deep amber.  Aroma is light chocolate, and pretty malty.  Taste is light chocolate, roasty and lots of caramel malt with the perfect amount of hop balance.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 Walking into the Great American Beer Festival for the first time had all the effect of walking into Imperial Rome.  It was bustling, loud, raucous, yet refined.  It was the pinnacle of beer civilization where tradesman from all over the land could gather and share the treasures they had made.  Though the drinkers were from all walks of life, they shared a common thread in their adoration of a good beer.  It was a concerted effort by an immensely eclectic group to enjoy beer  an event worthy of comparison to the rise and fall of the peoples of Campania.  It seems that in the dizzying glee of the moment leading up to that grand entrance I had forgotten to bring any navigational tools.  Before me were aisles and aisles thronged with semi-sober patrons, outnumbered only by the variety of beer, and I had no clue where to go or how to get there.  So I did what any good bard or merchant would do.  I wandered.  And the first booth of interest we came across was Three Floyds.  The line was blissfully short and the drinkers blissfully ignorant.  It was an ideal opportunity.  I ran up to the booth and saw four beers before me and, not knowing which to try first I asked.  The representative sighed and looked around and said Maybe the Bruce.  And what a fine beer to start the night with!  It has a strong name, a strong brewery behind it and I generally like Scottish styled beers.  However, the sickly orange light of the convention center kept me from seeing any color in the beer, and the tiny tasting glasses rebuffed the formation of any head.  Still, it appeared to be a mostly translucent head with a faded wood color and no head to speak of.  I wrapped my meager tasting glass around my nose like an oxygen mask and took in a beautiful blend of Scottish and sweet.  Peat and hearty vegetables like carrot, potato and yam blend with apples and the smell of a sugar glaze.  The taste, too, played true to Three Floyds reputation for quality by emphasizing its sweeter side with strong licorice tones.  The most amazing malts Ive ever tasted in a beer features prominently producing a lovely balance between the savory Scottish spirit of the beer and the less expected sweet bits.  Robert the Bruce in name and in taste was a fitting beer to start the festival with.  A fine way to acquaint myself with Three Floyds too.
Sweet candy sugar tastes.  Slight carbonation sort of feel.  Reminds me of a half flat root beer.  Roasted malt is nice and adds complexity to the brew.  Very interesting.

Botlle.355ml.Pours tea ruby-amber with almost non existent top. Aroma, clean and refreshing full of fruity juicy hops, sweet caramel malt, toffee. Good clean palate. Refreshing blend of sugars and hops. This works quiet well here making it very drinkable. Light bitter roast just makes it right. Superb as every day choice.

Aroma of caramal with some light peat malt.  Appears a deep mahogany color with a small tan head that dissipates.  Flavor is savory malt with some smoke and with a nice hop balance.  Palate is medium to medium thick, with low effervescence - quite appropriate.  Overall, a very nice scottich ale.
12 oz bottle. Opaque, dark brown color with tan head that laced the glass. Roasty malt aroma and flavor accented by a healty dose of sprucy hops and a touch of alcohol. Good stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2007 Bottle, Sept 2006. Staunton, VA.  Color was a nice brown, not real dark.  Head was very  small.  Aroma was of malt, and roasted/toasted.  Not overly strong smell.  Taste was very good.  Very smooth taste.  Taste is malt, caramel, some fruit and hops.  First Three Floyds beer and impressed thus far.
Color is brown with no head. Aroma is very malty and caramel with a bit of maple syrup.  Taste is maple with vanilla, oak and a light hop background.  Decent on the palate.
Nose is caramelly and roasty; transparent brown with a small beige head; flavor of caramel with a small smoky coffee note; finish shows a few hops.

Bottle.  Slight peat/smoke aroma with medium caramel.  Appearance is dark red with a creamy tan head.  Taste is light bitterness and peatiness, hint of smoked malt.  Slight sourness.  Caramel.  Slight toffee and roast.  Chocolate.  Big maltiness.  Medium body and super smooth.  Dry finish.  Is it possible to feel the taste?  Overall, hoppier than expected, and a damn amazing session brew.  Theres no WAY this is 7.2%

(From scrawled notes) Pours medium brown with a huge off-white head that lasts.  Aroma is of apples with hints of malt.  In the mouth, it starts off like cider, then get slightly bitter.  Very carbonated, yet full.

Aroma is strong on malts and a little chocolate.  Pours a deep dark brown with an antique white head that quickly vanishes.  Medium body with malts and chocolate on the palate.  A bt of bitterness at the end.  A good beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a medium off white head. Has a nice medium body to it. Aroma of roasted malts and dough. Taste of caramel and smoke. Finishes with a little bit of a bitter kick. Pretty decent beer just not my favorite type.

bttle. Poured rich and brown settling a nice tan head. sweet dark caramel aroma. malty,sweet with caramel and toffee along with subtle roastiness. hops were well balanced and slightly floral. Less complex than most of the floyds brews but another fine one.

Bottle, purchased at Chevy Chase Wine and Liquor in Washington DC.  I love Scotch ale, and I had high expectations from Three Floyds.  This beer is certainly tasty, but it lacks that special something, that I find in my favorite Scotch, Alesmiths Wee Heavy.  Definetly worth a taste.  And it has a great name as well.
Pours almost black with almost no head. Aroma is slight but the taste is very malty with some toasted and smokey flavors mixed in. Very nice overall.

Yet another that slipped under the rating radar.  Nice translucent brown pour from a 12 oz bottle.  Big malt nose..fruity, toasty breadiness.  Sweet malt flavor with caramel, toffee, chocolatelyand a nice smooth mouthfeel.  Nutty, light hoppiness toward the finish.  A decent scottish ale.

12-oz. bottle from moejuck.  Pours dark walnut brown with very little tan patchy head.  Aroma is roasted caramel malt (cookie), brown sugar, maple syrup, yeast (dough) and flowers.  Medium bitter, moderate acidity, dark roasted, near burnt toast and malt, cocoa, finish is slightly hoppy.  Dark bodied, dry palate.
Another fine beer from 3 floyds.  Deep amber in color.  Had this in the bottle.  Would love to have on tap.  Wonderful malt flavor with a smooth finish

Bottle.  3 Floyds quality is constant.  Very good beer.  Beautiful appearance - amber with bright red tones.  
Woody, smoked taste - delicious malty flavor with a wonderful hoppy kick at the finish. 
Good beer - very unique.

Pours dark amber with a thin white head. Smell is of floral hops and caramel malts.  Taste is very similar nice intial hop kick with a strong malt takeover that commands the aftertaste as well.  Not Three Floyds best but quite good.

The 12 ounce bottle poured an almost clear dark reddish amber beverage with a small fizzy off-white head that was almost entirely gone in less than 5 minutes and it never got a chance to leave any lace on the glass. The aroma was heavily malty with significant alcohol notes. The malt aromas were roasted and the hops contributed a subtle dried fruit backdrop. Interesting. The body was huge reminding me in some ways of a barleywine. The carbonation was what I would consider normal and the texture was pleasantly smooth. The flavor was full of roasted malt character. It started off slightly sweet with dried plum and raisin notes. The finish was long and had a nice warming alcohol smoothness to it.
Small foamy head, diminishing. Dark-copper pour, smoky aroma. Bitter-Roasted flavor. Malty, smooth and medium bodied. Good stuff here.
Pours dark brown without much head. Caramel aroma, not much smell. Nice on the palate. Nutty, smoky, sweet flavor.

via trade with hippie4beer - Pours a brown color which shines red when held to the light.  Small head fades away quickly.  Has a light sweet caramel malt aroma.  Flavor is sweet and malty.  A very smooth medium bodied beer.  Its worth a trade.  Thanks Seth.

Robert The Bruce pours a very dark brown with very little head at all. There is very little aroma to this one. What aroma is there is nutty. The mouthfeel of this beer is smooth, much smoother than most Scottish Ales Ive had. The flavor is very nice-plenty of malt with just a small hint of hops in the back end. The taste is nutty and smokey. The description says chocolatey, but I didnt catch much of that in the flavor. A very good Scottish Ale, and a very easy to drink brew."

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 Bottle. Decent aroma with a generous poured head, dark body. Flavor is well balanced with a nice malt to hop ratio making it very drinkable. Decent body with pleasant palate. A fine ale.

Update: Maybe I have a bad bottle here but... This one seemed to be too bland. Not enought flavor. Im going to have to have another.

A tremendous beer done in a rather unique style. A reasonable amout of hoppiness, combined with caramel and multiple heavy fruits. Its spicy, yeasty flavor is quite impressive. The bitter aftertaste is welcoming and does not impede upon some of the more slight flavors.  It is certainly difficult to note the amount of alcohol in this beer. I find that this beer is best consumed near 45 degrees fahrenheit to ensure the consumer samples every aroma.

Pours an attractive deep burgundy-garnet color. Head is almost non-existant with no lacing. Fairly tame aromas of roasted malts, dark chocolate, caramel and a touch of peat smoke. A pleasingly full, creamy mouthfeel is noted just being shy of oily. Well balanced and quite sweet flavors of dark chocolate, roasted malts, nuts, raisins along with some smokey wood undertones. Interestingly enough the finish demonstrates some mild hoppy bitterness unusual for the style, but seems to work fine. Cuts through any residual sweetness nicely. An admirable Scottish Ale, although a bit reserved.

Looked limp on the pour and with the head and nose. Malty. A mediocre style for me that seems to limit flavor. I ampled this once while distracted in a reastaurant but I dont think more experience with this would give me more appreciation.

bottle.  Aroma:  honey, caramel, malt, resin, and a touch of scotch whisky.  Appaearance:  Dark reddish-brown.  Nice light beige head dissipated quickly into a light foam that flotaed on the surface of the beer.  Not much lacing. Flavor:  dark fruit, heavy malt and caramel, light acidity, spicy hops and then a nice bitterness.  A little syrupy, but not too bad.   Palate:  Medium bodied. Medium carbonation.  A little alcohol warming on roof of mouth.  Sweetness lingers on tongue for quite a while.  Overall:  A nice mix of malt sweetness and hop bitterness.  May be a little too sweet for some people, but I enjoyed it.

Bottle, The Foodery in Philadelphia. Poured a nice deep red and brown. Little head, little lace. Aroma is very sweet like syrup. Tastes is pretty good I thought. Honey, caramel is strong in this one. A nice Malt finish adds well to it. Im happy I bought more then one of these. Sparking up my Ashton as I open another.
I liked it. I like the alcohol content. Its kinda sweet which I like. Not alot of hops is a nice change of pace. I was pleasantly suprised, I wasnt sure Id like it.
reddish brown color.  small tan head.Nice aroma of malt & caramel.  The maltiness is a little too sweat.  Not bad just not my favorite of this style or from 3Floyds

Pours a reddish brown color with a quick fading head that leaves some nice sheets of lacing.  Smells of malt, caramel, chocolate, and a note of toasted almonds.  Taste is malt upfront with bits of caramel and dark fruit.  There is a bit of chocolate in here as well as some subtle hop spiciness.  Mouthfeel is pretty creamy and smooth.  Lighly carbonated.  Bit too sweety and syrupy for me but pretty solid.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2006 Pours a deep maroon red/brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of malt, chocolates and caramel.  Nice almost full mouthfeel that fades a bit at the end.  Malty start, floral middle, lighter end.  Pretty good.  Grim would like it.

Thanks to px2grafx. Poured a clear dark orangish brown body with a small head and minimal lacing. Aroma is malty with caramel, roast and chocolate. Also a very fruity feel to it. Mouthfeel was very smooth with a sweet finish. Nice.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2008 Pours a clear dark brown with a red tint, not much of a head but I have an older bottle.  Sweet aroma of some sweet peated malt and rye bread.  Flavor is similar, toffee,  rye bread and some coffee dryness.  Light chocolate in the finish. Glassy body with some sparse but larger carbonation bubbles.   Pretty tasty and defintely easy drinking for a scottish ale.   It has great character.

Rich, deep bronze-gold color with a sweet, nutty, roasted malt profile.  Light, even bitterness accents the full mouth feel.  Sweet grain and some alcohol notes in the aroma with light floral subtlties.  Substantial but yet easy-drinking nonetheless.

Blind rating, bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, fully diminishing.
Body is dark amber.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie, molasses), lightly to moderately hoppy (apricot, resin), with notes of peat/whiskey/alcohol, toffee, brown/candy sugar.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, lively/soft carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

A little too sweet and syrupy to be fully enjoyable, and green/resinous hops distract too, but its otherwise pretty faithful and enjoyable.

Bottled. Beers a hazy medium-dark amber-brown with a small, beige, creamy/frothy, mostly but slowly diminishing head. The aroma is malty with moderate-to-heavy notes of roasted grain, coffee and caramel; Hoppy with a light note of herb, trace resin/pine; Yeasty with a light note of pointy dank basement/damp cement; 
Light spicy alch. The flavor is smooth; lightly bitter, moderately sweet with an average-length, lightly bitter, moderately sweet, slightly warm finish. The body is light-to-medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

hazy reddish-brown colour with a little beige head; strong malty nose, slightly toasted; notes of plum and licorice; a bit oily and with a light initial sweetness; robust malt body and a strong bitterness before a long and moderately dry, bitter malty finish where more notes of dark fruits appear - a big thanks to my stepparents for this very good beer

Not an impressive pour from the bottle. Very short lived tan head and minimal lacing. The color was a brown color with orange edges. Aroma was malty but weak. The flavor started somewhat sweet and malty, but finished with a dry coffee flavor and some hoppiness. Mouthfeel was thin and carbonated.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful amber-red color; very clear.  White-tan head disappates quickly, but rings the glass for a while.  Aroma is dominated by sweet maltiness....just a hint of smoke in there too; some earthy character.  Medium body.  Flavor is again dominated by malt, but there is a hint of smoke in there as well.  Nice complexity.  Theres an initial sweetness, but it finishes dry.  Overall, this is a fantastic example of this style.   Im really surprised as 3F typically puts their own spin on their beers.  A very fine beer.

A dark red, translucent pour with a tan, tight bubbled head. Slightly sweet, smooth, full bodied. The head faded before the glass was finished. Lightly hopped with a strong malt flavor. Excellent follow through, a high class Scotish Ale.

Very nice.  Good hops ands lots of malts.  You do indeed catch a hint of the alcohol, but it doesnt detract from the experience.  Complaints that it is overhopped are probably valid, but that is FFFs bread and butter.  Tastes pretty good to me anyhoo.

Pours a dark, clear garnet color with a light tan head that diminishes yet coats the glass.  Aroma is chocolate malt.  Taste is also of sweet chocolate malts along with some coffee and caramel.  Some hop bitterness but not overdone.  Some minor alcohol warmth after swallowing.  Very good indeed.

There is an aroma of chocolate and roasted malts that greet the nose.  Upon the pour the color is a deep copperish brown with reddish hues.  The head is tan and of substantial size and duration.  A dark chocolate is the initial flavor and grows to a more roasted bitterness.  The finish is smooth.

From bottle.  Pours a clear brown, hints of red and no head.  Nose is roasted and chocolaty.  Flavor is pretty much the same with just a hint of bitter towards the end.  Fairly light but drinkable palate, although not that interesting.

Well, the tastes of chocolate malts and sweet dark malts are obvious.  Not sure why this is a Scottish ale.  Like everything else from Three Floyds, this is hoppier than anything Robert the Bruce ever saw in his life time.  Initially looks almost like a glass of Coke but it loses its bubbles even faster than cola.  Has a nice brown ale sourness to it. I would have expected a touch of peat smoke and a bit less hops.  Indeed, less is more with this beer.  I loved the first couple of sips, but lost interest before I was a third of the way through.
Had this a Monks Cafe, Philadelphia 5/4/06.  Deep brown coffee color.  Strong smooth enduring malted flavor.  Alcohol well hidden and hardly noticeable.  Full bodied mouth feel.  Highly recommended.

12 oz bottle..  rich mahagoney color small beige head . sweet roasted malt aroma .  good malty flavors with a bit of smokey chocolate  and a pleasant hop bitterness at the end . medium bodied and very smooth ...good stuff

For all the malts described in this one, all I could pick up was the hoppy finish. The 7% wasnt evident, but it tasted off... It was smooth, but if you are a malt lover, then you might want to look elsewhere.....

Bottle. Pours copper to red with a nice off white head that lasts a fairly long time. Aromas of malts, cookie, caramel and molasses. Flavors of toasted malts, that start out sweet but end up with a slight hoppy bitterness. A real nicely balanced beer that emphasizes the malts.

this was the first FFF beer i ever had on tap .it was so smooth and rich tasteing i had to have more i like it more on tap then bottle.but is great either way CHEERS to the guys for making this one of the regulars on tap at pub.

From the bottle.  Ruddy brown in color like iced tea, without much head to speak of.  Smell of chocolate and a bit of dark fruit, but rather slight.  Roasted malt dominates as advertised, with chocolate and maybe that tea again.  A bit of bitterness pops up at the end.  Easy to drink.

12 oz. bottle courtesy jerc. Dark cherry red colour with a fully lasting creamy beige head. Dark fruit, toffee, orange peel, and light alcohol aroma. Dark fruit and toffee flavours, some citrus, with a grapefruit and woody bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy and rich mouthfeel. Yummy.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & Dave B. -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a hazy ruby-brown with a spare diminishing off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, smoke, a hint of chocolate, hops and alcohol. Nice easy to drink malty flavour with some smoke, chocolate and hops in the finish. Medium body, syrupy mouthfeel. Enjoyable, a very good Scotch Ale.

This one pours a deep mahagoney with a light tan head that truns to a thick film over top. The aroma both sweet and a bit sour...elements of  smoke, roasted malt, and bitter chocolate. The flavor is also a bit smokey with some coffee/bakers chocolate like bitterness...kind of toasty and nutty. Malty yet bitter over the tounge with a dry bitter finish that kind of lingers. Nice beer for those cooler days.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, Dave B, my bottle via trade with Fyrecrakker05.  Poured deep ruby-brown with a smalle off-white head.  Nice sweet roast malt aroma, light caramel and chocolate - simple and smooth, some hops.  Taste is similar, quite a nice rye/grain aftertaste, long bitter yet malty finish.  Mouthfeel is syrupy, lightly carbonated, a little boozy for 7%.  I liked it.
UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours a  copper with a tan head. Aroma of roast, alcohol, citrus, and hops. Flavor is smooth and bitter, too bitter for me.

Dark amberish color.  thin head.  Full bodied malt aroma.  Some chocolate.  And a trace of hops.  Flavor is full of malts, nicely balanced out by the hops.  Not the best 3 Floyds and not the best Scottish ale, but a good drink!

Small light tan head tops a deep copper pour. Some raisins, brown sugar, orange and spice add up to a pleasing aroma. Rich and full on the palate, but not sticky. More dark fruit, roasted malt, molasses, and earthy flavors become nicely balanced by  light spicy and citrus hops. Finishes dry and lightly bitter.

Pours deep, deep ruby-brick into the glass with a medium, quickly diminishing frothy head.  Aromas of dark fruit (cherry and plum) with just a hint of dark chocolate.  Flavors of rich malt, dark chocolate, bitterness and caramel go down nicely.  It feels quite full inside the mouth, and has a nice lasting roasted finish.  Very good brew!
Bottled.  Had a light beige creamy head with a few large bubbles here and there.  Aroma was rich and malty and complex.  The flavor was similiar, with the addition of some mild chocolate notes.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Beautiful clear, dark amber with a small, off-white head. Lightly caramelish nose. Medium body with accents of caramel and nuts. Hoppy finish. Tasted at the Oklahoma Beer tasting March 06 hosted by mjames and lilannie. 250306

Pours dark brown with a reddish tint - off white head that sticks around for a bit & a layer rest on top.  Clean thick roasted malt - some burnt toffee - very grainy malt aroma.  Taste is dark nutty / burnt roasted barley malt.  Medium bodied beer with very grain feel - frothy medium carbonation.  Finish has bitterness with a sweet maltiness.  Nice Scottish ale with some extra hoppiness - nice job.

12 oz bottle. Not much head at all. Aroma of malts and not very hoppy at all. Tasted of sweet caramel malts with a slight hop bitterness. Didnt really have all that much hop aroma or flavor at all but the slight bitterness was nice. Solid, I like this style.
Roasty malt, some nice hoppiness. To me much less sweet than expected. Abit of resin, no heavy aftertaste, quite smooth, great beer! Thanks to Duane for the great beer!

Pours a slightly hazy reddish brown amber with a light tan head that left some lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts, some light dark fruits and a light sense of hops.  Flavors was more of the roasted malts, with more of the hops (some citrus, light pine) coming through in the flavor.  Still mostly malty with some sweetness, but nicely hopped as expected from Three Floyds.

12 oz bottle served in tulip glass
dark copper with a light tan head
aroma:porterlike full of chocolate malts,carmel some hop spiciness.
Taste is roasted malt ,slightly sweet and a pleasant hoppiness.low to medium carbonation gives it a pleasent mouthfeeI . I definately would seek it out especialy on draft

A really nice beer.

Smooth, full flavored, just complex enough without being overbearing.

Easily the best scottish ale Ive tried, and so far my favorite from Three Floyds.
Body is brown with green yellow transparency.  Nose is all rootbeer with citrus and expresso.  Flavour is earthy with coffee and a hairy tounge.
Delicious beer with a chocolate/coffee and light fruity taste. Head dissapears quickly, good aroma, first Three Floyds Beer, definately a good start.

bottle. pours a very nice deep ruby red when held to a light. i got no head on this but i wonder if its from washing my glass with soap and water?  aroma is plum and after reading murrayswines rating i cant help to pick up the raspberry also. this smells great. reminds me of wine. sweet with a bit of alcohol if you really search for it. taste is plum and other dark fruits i cant seem to place. some malt and the slightest bit of hops very light. has a dry and smooth drinkability with a light aftertaste of plum and a light somkieness. but mabye thats just me. this is a wonderful beer and i only wish i could get it every day.

I tried this after a Pils so my chops might be dulled a bit. 

The aroma is true to a deep Scots ale with a lot of sweet chocalate and a hint of coffee bitters and plum/rasberry.

Pouring into my delirium tulip, the color is like a dark mahogony with a shade of ruby red. The head is not much to speak of and actually dies out rather quickly.

Taste is as expected, deep toffee with a slight bitter malt taste. all in all though its a well rounded balance. 

The mouthfeel is average at best, but still good. I found it slightly more carbonated than other Scotties like Founders Dirty Bastard.

As Smooth as the body is, I would rate this beer as easily drinkable. I will buy this again.
This beer is representiive of why I love FFF. Pours a deep amber with a nice head. Aroma of roasted carmel. Super malty flavor, while still loaded with hops. Tastes fannnnntastic.

On tap at Charlies Ale House.  Caramel-orange color with a thin tan head.  A light alcohol note in the nose.  Solid mouthfeel, a little resin in the start, molasses in the middle, and a nice strong finish.  All around very enjoyable brew.
Nice balance of hops and malt. Very full flavor with a bit of alcohol taste. If it is one thing you can say about the beers from Three Floyds, they are not boring.

A dark ruby killer in the glass with a nice, tan half inch of head and some lacing.  Aromas are heavy on the malt -- chocolate, toast, and sweet caramel accompany a grassy hop scent.  A nice alcohol tang on the tongue, followed by a parade of malts down the gullet.  Full-bodied, if simple, beer.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2006 decent, for a scottish ale.  not a very representative FFF.  chocolatey, somewhat smokey.  really the best thing it has going for it is the 7.5abv.  RERATE: hadnt actually had this in years.  not nearly as dark as i thought.  in fact, looks like SoCo or a dopple or something.  smells of alcohol and nonspecific malts.  chocolate taste is very subtle.  this is very balanced with plenty of flavor.  i dont think i would want to drink more than a couple.

Aroma at first pour was rich peat, smoke (some bacon came across initially),  and a delicious fruitiness, though as the beer drained I got more and more hops and less malt in the aroma. In typical 3F style, this beer is highly hopped, which is kind of unfortunate for this style. In this finish the hops are nice but still really hinder the beer I think. I feel this one is kind of lost stylistically.

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank>OhioDad, thanks Scott!) Beer pours kind of a hazy dark brownish orange. Creamy-ish khaki head. Sloppy lacing. Sweet aroma of brown sugar, figs, raisins, malt and hops. Mouthfeel good and chewy - oh yeah.
