This sucker is just plain great - sweet brown sugar malt and fig flavor with a great burnt molasses finish topped off by a bitterness that brings the whole thing together. Slight alcohol burn. Lots of character in this. Heavy, full and tasty.

Aroma of light cocoa and sweet/tangy orange. Flavor makes me want to throw on a kilt and watch william wallace (aka braveheart) skewer some englishmen and get quartered by horses.  Nice smokey caramel flavors with some floral hops.  Good stuff.

(bottle - 12 oz) Hazy brownish pour with not much of a head. Aroma is very roasty and earthy with hints of sweet malts, caramel and smoked peat. The flavor is very roasty and sweet, with a decent amount of caramel and smoked peat followed up by a nice hop compliment and a smooth and malty finish. A tad watery but on the whole a decent Scottish Ale.

"By far not the most impressive scotch ale i have had. Poured a light red with a head which lasted no time. Aroma was weak to say the least. Flavor was of sweet malts, coffee and hops. Overall mouthfeel was way to thin."
Dark brown color, not much head. Complex flavor and aroma, some chocolate and coffee. Carbonated. Hard to pin down after so many beers :)

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2007 12oz, no date.  Pours a hazy mahogany with a tinge of orange, and a 1/2 finger fading beige head.  Aroma of chocolate malts, smoked peat, a little bit of earth and wood, and a little bit of pine.  The taste is caramel and chocolate malts, with the same earthy smokiness with all of the aforementioned aromas and into a dry, slightly chalky lingering bitter finish.  Lighter carbonation, medium to full bodied.Previous rating follows12 oz. bottle.  Pours a syrupy hazy brown with pretty much no head at all, even though I poured this one fairly aggressively.  Aroma is, of course, of the peaty smoky earthiness, some alcohol, some chocolate, and maybe a slight tinge of piney hops.  Floral hops up front, some toffee malts.  Pretty well balanced, as it finishes fairly clean. 7.3.6.3.14
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 12 oz bottle, via illinismitty.  Pours a clear mahogany with virtually no head.  Quice a lot of carbonation visible.  Very malty aroma, with some toffee and a touch of alcohol.  Very high level of malt on the flavor, a sweet caramel and toffee base.  Well balanced with lots of hoppy bitterness.  I was surprised to learn when I entered this that it was 9%, the alcohol is very well hidden.  Medium bodied with somewhat fizzy carbonation.  Finish is somewhat cloying and syrupy.  A pretty nice beer.  Theyve taken what you expect from a normal micro Scottish Ale and put it on steroids.

Pours a brown color with a very thin off white head.  Strong chocolate and roasted  malt with a hint of coffee  on the nose.  Sweet chocolate, coffee flavor.  Very delicious brew.  Looking foraward to buying another bottle.
my favorite scottish ale. pours dark brown with not too much head. hearty coffee and hops flavors. drinks smooth and bitter. lots of smells and flavors, very complex but easy drinking as well
Dark brown color with a thin off white head.  Hops and chocolate malt dominate the nose.  Tons of flavors in here...smokey, chocolate, roasted malt with a strong hop presence.

I swear this tasted hoppier than this the first time I had it....I had a hard time distinguishing it from Alpha King, as a matter of fact.  Was someone selling me Alpha King and relabeling as Robert the Bruce?  I drank from the bottle, so I couldnt see the color. Oh well.....  The pour is a dark, hazy brown with a small off white head.  Nutty on the front end and a big shot of vanilla in the finish.

Pours mahogany with a tan head.
Aroma is a very pure and clean with hints of malt, cream soda,  caramel and vanilla. Has flavors of malt, caramel, honey  and chocolate.
This beer is very smooth and well balanced with the alcohol being hidden very well.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with red highlights, a thin tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma is slightly smokey, with a nutty/coffee nose.  Flavor is nutty, with a smokey caramel tast that finishes ready and dry.    Palate coats the tongue, it is quite slick.  Very nice.

Pours to a nice looking brown body with a thin creamy tan head that disapates rather quickly but not fully.  The aroma is nutty and chocolatey with sweet breads and caramel.  The flavor is sweet roasted monkey bread and some smoked malts.  The palate is smokey and slick with a light creaminess and medium mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2011 Pours a nice mahogany color with slight tan head that fizzles off quick.  Aroma is sweet and of malt, caramel, chocolate with some earthy hops to boot.  Mouth is a bit thin with little bitterness in the end.  Flavor is of caramel and roasted malt with a little hops. The finish is sweet and crisp. A tasty brew for sure.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2006 Thanks to majicbill for the trade. Deep redish-amber color with a small deminshing light tan head. Aroma is malty with a hint of cocoa. Flavor starts caramel sweet with a little chocolate and a hint of smoke and a light bitterness in the finish. Medium body, creamy texture with soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with amber/bronze rays and a small tan head which diminishes quickly to nothing. Aroma is hindered by lack of head and is simple sweet malt with a little hoppiness. Tastes sweet with roasted malt and caramel. Finish comes at the back of tongue with balancing hops. Smokey bitterness lingers. Very balanced and enjoyable.

Pours a deep burgundy with almost no head.  Aroma is also very slight.  Very nice gentle flavor in which malt dominates.  I tasted vanilla, pine, caramel and just a hint of hops.  Very smooth palate.  I often find scottish ales a bit cloying, but this one is nice.

Thanks to JHop for the trade on this one.  Pours a lovely deep burgundy color with lots of extremely small bubbles cascading up the sides and a medium layer of offwhite head.  Looks absolutely delicious!  Aroma is malty, almost sweet and creamy, but at the same time some hoppiness and bubony goodness.  Flavor is very sweet and malty, bit doughy but at the same time a tad floral and a nice sweet clean finish.  Overall, one of the tops on my list.
deep brown color, aroma of chocolate roasty coffe sweetness, creamy tan head.  roasted malt flavors smooth body, not much finish.  yummy

Bottle.  Deep brown with a caramel aroma.  Heavy chocolaty flavor with nice finish.  This is a heavy beer that would be hard to drink in quantity.  But, the flavor is good and this is an excellent after dinner beer.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: The commercial description rings true. This is certainly a malt lovers drink with everything from the soft bready notes of a pilsner to workhorse amber malts and even rich chocolatey tones. There is a hint of that distinctly 3 Floyds hop profile on the nose as well as in the finish though malt certainly dominates. A nice warming ale.

Pours a reddish dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is chocolate and the alcohol is not evident. Initial flavor is of sweet chocolate with a creamy light bitter finish. A well balance ale that is very smooth and easy to drink.
I dont like this scotch ale...I dont like many scoth ales.  But its abv is redeeming enough.

Well, this is my first 3 Floyds brew to try. And I must say, I was impressed. Bottle. Aroma is not very stong in my opinion. Nice caramel aroma. Thats about all I can really smell. Must be my sinus cold lol. The flavor is very nice. Nice touch of caramel, chocolate, slight roasted flovar. Finishes very nice to. Just a little bit of a bitter finish. But all in all, still finishes clean with just a hint of chocolaty aftertaste. A very good Ale. One I will have to have again.

Bottle.  Mahogany colored with a tan, creamy head.  Aroma is dark and fruity with lots of sweet, roasted caramel malt.  Flavor is lots more malt; coffee, chocolate, caramel and a nice hit of bitterness at the end.  Medium to full bodied with a nice, long, roasty, bittersweet finish.  Would have never pegged the abv as even close to 9.1 (until after Id finished a few).  Those Floyds can really brew a beer!

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2006 Dark brown with a tan head.  Sublte rounded malt flavors of chocoalte and caramel.  Lacking the sweet cirus hop nose of a 3Fs beer and its a good thing as I think that would detract from this brew.  Rich finish that was very subdued.

Bottle.  Aromas of dark fruit and alcohol.  A little bit of citrus-hops in there too.  It looks a beat, a rel full mahogany with a frothy beige head.   Full lacing.  Tastes like a good smooth malt beverage, lots of dark fruit, wood, and chocolate.  Medium bodied.  Good slightly sweet finish.  Only a minor hint of bitterness.  Mild and comforting.  Good dark session beer, that 9.1 abv is well hidden and could creep up.  90 shilling indeed.
Dark cherry brown color with a creamy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt. Chocolate flavor with a mild roasted flavor.

wow 9% i did not taste that.  pours thin but dark brown.  Again this beer is not too hoppy which i love especilly with the bitterness I also crave.  This beer is robust enough with a hint of fruitiness to complete the scottish ale.

Bottle from Santa Pours a thin brown like tea with a strong aroma of raisiny malt.  Very malty taste, with sweetness the predominant flavor- almost candy-like.  Various fruits intermingle with the malt forming a holy alliance of flavor.  Smooth, lazy palate.  This is a surprisingly lite Scottish ale, but its dang good.  Id love more of this.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Fantastically malty.  This reminds me a lot of a good porter.  Its rich and malty with just a hint of hop bitterness.  It has that same roasty malt character.  It definitely tastes like malted milk balls.  Mouthfeel is thick, rich and creamy.  Alcohol is hidden very well.  You definitely have to be in the right mood for this one. but it is great.  Tastes like Ayinger Dobblebock, but better.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a head that goes away quickly.  Has a smooth creamy taste that does not linger long.  The first impression is toffee and cherry, followed by a hint of chocolate.  Overall, a good solid choice from a great brewery and easy to find.

Pours a lustrous dark mahogany with a foamy quickly dissipating head that lingers as a very thin layer that clings to the side with some lacing.  Aroma is sweet malted milk balls I only wished it was more powerful.  Has a smooth creamy feel in the mouth to go with a well proportioned roasted toffee flavor maintaing the hints of chocolate and malt that you smell.  Has a pleasant roasted aftertaste that makes you want another bottle of this good beer.

# 700 - Ruby, light tan fizzy head.  Rich and complex nose of chocolate malted milk balls (the inside), toffee, cookie dough, soft cherry, light hazelnut, and the smallest hint of smoke.  Big time dark malty flavors with fig, cherry and caramel nut stealing the show.  Hop role is limited, but keeps the malt in check for near perfect balance.  Medium bodied and smooth, cask-like carbonation, malty finish.  Had been years since the last taste of this, will only be 5 more days now before the next.  Really nice"malt bomb"...

Pours copper hue with significant carbonation but only a thin buttermilk head.

Not much going on aromawise, although if the minimalist head retention was specific to my bottle or pour that may have had something to do with it.

A fizzy, fairly viscous sweet brown sugar greets the tongue with a faint bit of hop bitterness at the finish.  Tastes an awful lot like a brown ale to me, maybe a little bit sweeter.  Sweetness/bitterness pretty well balanced though nothing spectacular.

Overall, a fairly vanilla offering from the venerable FFF brewery.  Its a shame that this is one of the easier to find beers from that label, and so far its been the only one to really let me down.

Had a fermented wood barrel aroma along with some mild sweet fruit. Dark amber body with not much for head but a filmy layer of head lasted on the top of the body of beer. Flavor hada mild alcohol presence. For me the thing about this one the palate was left with a good roasted wood aftertaste. Good stuff.

Bottle poured dark red amber with a small head and light lacing.
Nice sweet roasty, caramel aroma.
Mild flavor of sweet roasty malt,caramel,raisins with an easy sweet malty finish.
I cant believe the alcohol content is 9.1%
Very well hidden!
I wish I had more of this.

Dark gold and deep brown in color with a nice ivory head.  Notes of dark coffee and malts are very present in the aroma.  Heavy malts and chocolate dominate the flavoring, maybe even a bit of peet.  Very smooth ending.
Pours with a big light brown head on a dark golden brown body, leaving some lacing as the head settles. Strong aroma of chocolaty roasted malts. Thick body with a bitter chocolate malt taste.
Pours garnet with almost no head. All malt in the aroma. Toffee, coffee, and such. Flavor begins sweet and malty, ends with a subtle hoppiness that pushes it from good to great.

Tap at 3F. Small creamy and smooth tan head, sparse lacing, transparent, and a reddish brown hue. Malty, caramel, chocolate, and roasty nose. Flavor was sweet malt, some chocolate and caramel, some light hoppiness, roastiness. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium body.

Bottle. Pours deep reddish brown. Thin head and little lacing. Aroma is bready malt with hints of dried fruit. Flavor is roasted malt and plum, with a slight bitter finish that lingers mildly. A very smooth high alcohol beer. I need to pick up a six of this stuff.

Light mahogany color that becomes transparent as it thins. Nose is all malt sweets with a distinct roast character. Mouthfeel is even and velvety smooth. Flavor is all malt with chocolate and raisin accents. No hint of the alcohol. I very much enjoy scotch ales and this is one of the best American variations on the theme.

Pours a deep amber/ brown color with only a thin off-white head that quickly fades away to a thin ring that leaves very little lacing.

Smell; rich caramel malts, some candied fruit, with a bit of choclate in there.

Taste: roasted caramel malts, theres just a hint of chocolate and coffee, and a bit of a hop presence in the finish. Mouthfeel is a little thin. Overall this is a pretty nice, easy to drick beer. Glad I picked up a 6er of this.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Deep dark color.  Malty and sweet aroma.  Flavor is of roasted barley,  chocolate malt and light hops in the back-end.  Fantastic!! Cant wait to try some other Three Floyds.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2010 bottle. Weve got a sturdy deep mahogany pour here with no real head. Theres a full, bready malt aroma with subtle fruits and tiny vinous notes. The flavor is a dense plethora of malts starting with warming caramel and buttery bread, this fades to a drier spiced plum.  9.1%abv?? really? so smooth. . .


[March 20, 2010]

6-pack from the brewpub. Pours a cloudy dark copper with a small white head. The aroma is weird. Very, very juicy with hints of peach, orange, toffee, and miscellaneous fruit. This is not as hoppy as I recall, but it has been a great long while. It is still highly hoppy for the style. Palate is smooth with a flavor of cherry wood, peach, toffee, and vanilla. Not too bad, but its not my favorite FFF offering.

Bottle. Dark brown body, with a good sized tan head. Big malty aroma, earthy burnt sugar, and notes of peat? Flavour is richly malty and sweet with an underlying caramel and toffee. Mild whisps of peat/smoke/leafy greens or celery throughout. Alcohol is almost non-existent. Medium palate could be more full for perfection. Very good but didnt quite meet my high expectations. Grows on my a bit  as the glass goes on though.  Thanks again Probiere!

Bottle (and memories of draught). Pours a very dark, but pristine, mahogany with lovely beige head. The aroma is a symphony of caramel malts, some chocolate, dark fruit, and the faintest hint of mild hops. The flavor is very roasty up front and works its way into a malty sweetness with chocolate, caramel, and sappy notes. There is an even bitterness throughout, culminating in a satisfyingly earthy finish. I am very fond of this brew.

Looks a lot like a cola.  Darkish brown with a frothy tan head and quite a bit of little bubbles.  Aroma is also cola-like... sweetish, but weak.  Flavor, however, highlights a sweet coffee/chocolate flavor that is not heavy as in a stout or porter, but definitely present.  Mixes nicely with a prune-like fruitiness and then gives way to a smooth finish.  A slight metallic taste/aroma is distracting, but ephimeral.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12z bottle.  Hazy, brownish hue with a reddish hazy outline.  Barely any head or bubbles.  Slight coffee roast in the nose, along with sweet raisins, caramel, and chocolate.  Body is rich and sweet, but still somewhat chilled.  Nice dry, coffee finish.  Flavors are stiffled, but the mouthfeel is nice...giving it some time.  Alright, some time has passed, lets see what we got.  Same nose but more chocolate.  Still sweet malt note, then a bitter woody, dryness, and finally the hop finish.  Sweet and smooth.  Extremely well balanced, with emphasis on the malts.  Nice sweet chocolate malts with a slight hop dryness.  Absolutely Fantastic!
has the same flavor as a winter beer would have the chocolate flavor as well as the sweetness. it goes down smooth

Deep dark bold and cloudy brown.  Sweet scotch scent.  Alcohol is present with the scotch taste, but is well balanced with the chocolate and malt and just a touch of hops.  Good bold flavor that goes down smoothly.

Cask-condition version available from Firkins, Libertyville, IL.  Dark amber hued ale having a small white diminishing head with good lacing.  Sweet malt aroma with strong flowery hops. No discernable carbonation.  Medium bodied that starts with creamy sweet malt flavor and finishes dry with moderate hop bitterness. Nice balance.  A very good enjoyable tasty ale that is lovely on its own.

Clear amber body with a rather thin beige head. Good aroma of smoked malt, caramel and hops. Good flavor of smoked malt, caramel and hops with a bitter finish. The body has a medium thickness with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. A very good scottish ale.
Draft at 3F. A dark brown color with minimal white head. Nose is some dark malt and nuts, some smoke. Taste is a nice malt profile enhanced with some hazlenuts and vanilla. Yummy.
Draft @ brewery. Pours a brown color with a white head. Nose is malty and lightly nutty and caramel. taste is mostly nutty and caramel, ligh tmalt here and there. Finish leaves you  mouth sticky.
Bottle.  A nice dark brown with a tan head that fades to white.  A verey nice malty taste.  A bit thin but a very nice almost chocolaty finihs.

This was 9%?!  No way!  Anyways, this was a very nice overall but had a few shortcomings.  The body was a bit thin, and the mouthfeel watery.  The aroma was enticing but not particularly complex.  Looks a pleasant walnut brown shot through with crimson highlights.  Head is tannish, large, and diminishes to scum.  Aroma peat, caramel, chocolate, toast, and smoke.  Taste much the same with lingering peat and chocolate notes.  This worked very well.  A nice aftertaste on the swallow.  Thankfully, low hopping leaves the malt to shine.  Like I said, unfortunately thin-bodied, but a very pleasant drinker and the best Scotch ale Ive had in a while.

Nice appearance with a average tan head on an amber/brown beer.  Aroma is of caramel and light fruit.  flavor is initally sl sweet with a nice bitter and balanced finish.  Slightly light in the palate but decent overall.

Pours a hazy chestnut brown with a thicj off white head.  Beutiful aroma of wood, caramel, some fruitiness, and fresh malt.  Smooth and creamy feel.  bready malts and cocoa are prevalent in the flavor, acompanied by a rich earthiness and some dark fruitiness.  Piney hops dry out the finish.  Relatively low hops presence from what Ive experienced of Three Floyds, but pretty hoppy for the style.

Bittersweet chocolate, orange and roasted malts in the husky, chalky aroma.  Clear dark brown with ruby highlights is topped by a decent, fine bubbled, off white head that recedes to cover with some lacing.  Chalky character to the tasted malt flavour with some thick, sweet caramel and a hint of smoke leading to light finishing bitterness.  Plenty of residual sweetness in the after taste.  Medium body with fairly lively carbonation.  Bottle (trade, Aug-05) sampled with GonZoBeeR, MartinT, Olivier_MTL and Rastacouere.  Thanks, npdempse!

Bottle: Poured a brown color ale with a medium dark-white head with low retention. Aroma of hops is clearly detectable with some caramel malt. Taste is lighter then expected with some caramel malt and a bitter finish. Watery feel at the end is very unpleasant. Body is definitely too thin for my liking and alcohol is very well hidden. Definitely not the best from 3FL and not even close to the best of the style.
On tap at The Map Room.  A dark brown almost opaque beer.  Is that ABV right??  Cus I tasted none of it.  Another great big beer from Three Floyds.

A very nice all-around beer.  It has a curious aroma of hops yet no sign of hop flavor when tasting.  Very chocolately smooth, not overbearingly thick, but pleasantly so.  Very well balanced taste-wise; for a heavy beer, very drinkable.

Pours a  very dark brownish amber color with a beige colored head.  Aroma is a combination of nuts,woodchips,smoke,caramel, and toffee.  Taste is a nice blend of nuts,toffee and smoke flavored woodchips.  Another gem from Three Floyds.
Love this Ale, great taste nice feel and texture, good color. Smooth and not overpowering

This scottish ale has tons of flavour and body.  Its smoky, thick, full, adventurous, but it lacks some drinkability to me.  It isnt thick enough to be a good stout style, and the flavour is almost too muchfor how light the mouthfeel is.  Im torn on this one.

Brown in color.  Quickly disappating head, ends with thin layer.  Aroma is predominately caramel, somewhat sweet.  Taste is smoky nut flavor, with the caramel coming through as well.  Another good selection from a top notch brewer.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2006 Pours dark reddish brown with creamy white head, mostly diminishing. Some lacing. Aroma is caramel, toffee and chocolate. Flavor is very rich, caramels, chocolate, nuts, and toffee, are followed by quite a bit of hops, perhaps too much.  Full bodied, smooth texture, low carbonation, medium finish.
UPDATED: OCT 11, 2005 Tastes pretty good. Strong and bold, with a good ammount of roastiness. Good hop balance. Excellent Scottish ale.

Couleur auburn, apparence pleinement filtrée.  Bonne quantité de mousse beige rapidement diminuante.  Agréables parfums de café, de malt et dherbes sous une touche fruitée.  Saveurs maltée de connivence à lenveloppe des grains, de pains grillé, modérément fruité.  Grande amertume finale semblant légèrement hors contexte.  Carbonatation active et piquante, alcool bien masqué.

bottle...Brown pour with reddish hints, thin cream colored head.  Wonderful malty aroma, butterscotch, caramel.  Nice heady malt flavor to start, bittering a little in the middle as the hops develop the palate.  The inherent sweetness of the malt to start and the bittering in the middle lend to a nicely balanced beer.  The finish is hoppy and roasty, with a hint of chocolate malt.  Almost too hoppy to finish for a scottish ale, however, I like the boldness.  This is well balanced and extremely enjoyable.

Bottle. Deep brown color with little head. Aromas of dark fruits, nuts, caramel, pine, and fresh sweet malts, along with a perceptible bitterness. Flavor follows, but with a fantasticly well-balanced bitterness throughout. This beer could easily fall apart with its sweetness if not for the bitter hops. Likewise, it would be unfortunate if the hops were too bitter in the finish; but this is perfect! A really remarkable and balanced palate, leaving a pleasant sticky-sweet aftertaste. Didnt think Id like this one this much-- a welcome surprise!
Very complex flavor.  Bitter with a tiny bit of sweetness and just enough hoppy flavor.  I may have to come back to this one.

Aroma:Cady sugar,malt,caramel.....
Appearance:Redish brown,good head...
Flavor:Alcohol,strong flavor,spices,biterness,light caramel...
Very nice Scottish. Richly malty in aroma, malt flavors of toffee and molasses. Hops well into the background - appropriate for style. Faithful to any of the standard Scottish ales, but fresher.
Dark brown and clear.  There was no head - but I didnt pour it.  Aroma slight but pleasant.  Mmmm Full bodied powerful taste!  Good.  A little too strong for me personally.

The beer looked reddish amber with a one finger thick head, and decent lacing.  The smell was earthy, spicy, floral, nutty, and slightly smoky.  The taste was malty sweet and chewy, and continued on into nutty, spicy, and chalky flavors that lingered on, and faded into peat smoke.  Reminded me quite a bit of a Dopplebock, but was a little more sour.  The mouthfeel was thick and sticky, and aftertaste soothingly sweet.  A complex beer that you dont have to sip.

Very dark brown and syrupy; big, bubbly, tan head.  Aroma is very heavy with tons of malts; otherwise nondescript.  Flavor is also hearty with malts; barely a hint of chocolate; slight alcohol twinge.  Full body with very little stickyness; nice.  I like this beer even though I cant quite put my finger on it.

Massive molassases malt alliteration and aroma. Mmmmm. Smells very good. Deep reddish brown color. No head. Mellow malt profile underlays the flavor palate, but there is a very grapefruit rind bitterness that comes in toward the middle and finish. Molasses flavor not as noticeable in the flavor as in the aroma. A great session styl beer for a cold night when a slightly bigger kick of alcohol is welcome.

GTM. Could have sworn Ive had this before. Ive seen it and passed it up multiple times in liquor stores thinking I had had it. But alas, the rating never made it onto the system. Molasses aroma, not very sweet. Large, off-white  to tan head. Dark brown body. Very nice appearance, beautiful; if I could give it more points for appearance, I would.  Hops at back of the tongue. Sweet, very well balanced. An excellent brew.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2007 12oz - Aroma is roasted malts, caramel, hazelnut, and toffee.  Pours a solid browm with a small head and great lacing.  Flavor is very malty.  Caramel, roasted nuts, and a touch of hop. Palate is smooth and tangy.  A very tasty brew.

It poured dark, hazy reddish chestnut, small rocky off-white head which quickly dissipated with minimal lace.  Aroma was malty with notes of chocolate, caramel, nugat, brown sugar and molasses.  Taste was malty but not too sweet, with chocolate, caramel, ripe dark fruit, coffee, smoke, burnt toast, smoke and peat.  Nice bitterness but no hop herbalness.  Well-balanced, smooth and creamy, with a good viscosity in the mouth, and some of the tastiest malt Ive ever had.  Another 3 Floyds winner.
Bottle.  Great malty brew, creamy and nutty texture.  Dry chalky finish.  Wonderful.
Bottle: Malty aromas, dark brown color with and off-white head that quickly disapates.  Some chocolate malts, nice bitter tastes, a touch of hops, a very smooth mouthfeel.

This is a very good beer.  Pours medium brown with red and copper overtones.  Thinnish, tan head.  Lively carbonation. Roast, chocolate, molasses and malt.   Bit of a weak finish.  I would love to try this on tap...

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2005 12 oz bottle.  Big time chocolate and roast with hops in the background to keep you going.  Garnet, brown and red, tones. Thin tan head.  Chocolate and roast with supporting bitterness.  Flavor seems to fade as beer warms.  Too much carbonation.  Maybe too thin.  I like this beer a lot, but best characteristics faded as the beer warmed.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2006 I have been curious about this one for a while as I have heard good things about this beer but am not a huge fan of this style. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer pours a medium brown color with reddish highlights and a huge tan head. The aroma is sweet, malty and has some light fruit and hops. The mouthfeel is rather smooth. The flavor is rich and malty with roasty notes and a light but sharp floral hops and a hint of ripe fruit. Sweet malty finish. I will be trying this one again.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2006 On tap at the Blind Pig, Champaign, IL. This is one of my favorite Three Floyds brews given the hops isnt as "prolific" as it is in many of their other offerings. The malt and vanilla flavors, and what a wine drinker would refer to as "toasty oak," blend nicely. I didnt pick up the chocolate noted in the description, so Ill be sure to look out for this next time. As a final comment, think this beer could be improved by upping the alcohol level a few percent. RERATE: I must be growing more generous in my days on this website. Increasing the overall by 2. This beer has emerged as my favorite Three Floyds beer. If given the choice, Id rather drink this than DL, although DL is a better constructed beer.
pours a reddish copper in color with a small-medium tan compact head, good aroma of roast, alcohol, citrus, and hop, the taste was ever so smooth and just like the aroma, with a bitter finish.
Ordered in Chicago, and really enjoyed it.  Dark reddish appearance, smooth pour, and a sweet aroma and flavor.  Very excellent, malty scotch ale.  Three Floyds can do no wrong!

Bottle.  Pours a reddish/copper, thin dense tan head, good lacing.  The aroma jumped out of the glass (most worthy), beady and light doughy coffee, syrupy notes and a liguring pale spiciness that runs through the beer. Very pleasant and clean medium dark nose.  Toasty flavor,  tingling effervescence on the tongue that seemed to mute the flavor somewhat.  Dominated with malt, very little hops.   I was hoping that the flavor would run more robust spicy dark malts in the forefront, but blended addition of pale malts seem to dominate.  But it was an all together different and totally enjoyable experience when the beer warmed up.  Remarkable aroma on this beer, very drinkable.

One of the best Scottish ales that Ive had. You can taste the quality in the beer (even if youre not a fan of the style). The beer also has a great dark red color and a hint of the slightly higher alcohol content in the aroma. Three Floyds does it again.

Ok, this is the 2nd time I have rated this because the site had an error.  #1100.  Purchased in Rhode Island.  Sweet, milky chocolate, slight roasted aroma with a twinge of metal in the end.  Garnet/amber color that is transparent with a small light tan head.  Sweet to start with chocolate milk hints with more roastiness and a peat-like malty finish.  This is somewhat sweet.  Seems more like a hybrid of a porter and a scotch ale.  Still quite yummy.
Lots of sweet malts combined with a hint of bitterness at the end - caramel, molasses most apparent. Deep copper pour, tan head. Smooth all around.
A dark copper color with a tan head. Malty aroma. A very malty taste, smoother than other Scottish ales that I have tried. Still, the alcohol is not masked tremendously.

Out of a 12, malt aroma almost burnt.  Poured a dark brown, slight weak coffee color to it, decent off white head.  Flavor was about the same as the aroma, roast malt, again a tinge of burnt.  A slight hint at the hops but mainly malt.  Palate was enjoyable and easy drinking. Overall a good drinker.
Maltbomb. Roasty, surprisingly creamy body for the color, and a rich finish.  Clover (or is it thistle?) notes and barbecued pork rounded out my sample.  Nice, and I hope to try it again.

Serindipity favors the prepared palate - a verb swerve away from the original - but thats just what happened when I tasted the Three Floyds, Robert The Bruce Scottish Ale.  I kept seeing this beer on the menu -but ordered two other beers that ended up not available. So on the 3rd swing I ordered this beer.  HOME RUN!  Great aroma - full, robust, with wonderful after-taste.  To me there was a hint of licorice ... that lasted well into my food and the rest of the bottle: but it was not overbearing.

Im new to this brewery .. but I wont be for long.  Gotta love serindiptity.  Hmm, I guess there really is MORE THAN CORN in Indiana.

looks like a supernova when i swirl it around.  dark brown and ruby color with decent off white head.  aroma is of carmel, scotch, malt, vinegar, sweet and sour sauce, red apple.  flavor is malty, very sweet, brown sugar, and some hay, lots of acidity, dry with some butterscotch.  a decent brew but not mind blowing.
A great microbrew. Actually everything i tried at Three floyds was excellent.  If you are near the NW indiana area or chicago you must stop by and try the selection of beer.

slightly hazy red brown, off white head.  aroma of chocolate, raisin, molasses and mild hop.  flavour is sweet, smooth and toffee-ish and strangley underhopped for a FFF brew(in a good way).  silky mouthfeel.  brown sugar anf mild roast in the finish.  nice.

<font face="times new roman">Deep and clear mahogany-red hue capped by a creamy, tan, milkshake head.  The sun is slowly slinking below the horizon as I enter a dessert shop nestled among tall buildings on a busy street.  Being a creature of ritual and habit, the waitress already knows what to bring me.  Only a minute after Ive made myself comfortable a steaming cup of java and a delectable caramel and chocolate confectionary delight is set before me.  The bell on the door chimes as another customer enters and with him wafts of a passerbys peaty pipe tobacco. Restrained malt sweetness and acidity balance throughout.  A light bitterness is all but lost to a slightly vegetal and dry finish.  Mouthfeel is the definition of ordinary without an indication of robustness.12 oz bottle, snifter.</font>

Bottled.  Deep brown (almost red) coloring with an eggshell head.  The flavor is strongly malt with some hop in there for balance.  Nice warming feel as it goes down, which is something I really like out of a Scottish ale.  Very enjoyable.

Dark brown with a deep dark red hue when seen under  a bright light, has a large tan head,. ...very enticing. Bold roasted malt sweet flavor. Includes a taste of caramel and hint of chocolate. The hops are well balanced, a perfect blend of hop bitterness is combined with strong malt. A bold full bodied well balanced hearty brew with a smooth finish. This is an excellent Scottish ale style brew.
a great scottish ale.  the best ive tried for sure.  A nice roasted taste pretty smooth too.  will probably get again next time i have a chance.

Pours a big head dark  brown.  Tastes is very interesting.  The hops taste is balanced well with the traditional scottish ale bitterness.  Even a bit of sweetness round out this comlex brew.
My favorite scottish ale yet.

Light brown in color with a frothy, creamy head.  Slightly dry, chocolatey nose.  Very full-bodied, almost chewy.  Dry maltiness but sweet on the palate at the same time.  Some smokiness, noticable strength.  Some butter character as well with a noticable hop character.

Bottled.  As a change of pace, I tried a TF beer that is NOT a hopmonster.  The pour was a mahogany/maroon brown with a slightly off-white head.  Aroma was malt and fruit esters (though not to the degree of most British import ales).  Flavor was malty sweet of caramel, roastiness, chocolate, toffee, rasins/dates with a tinge of smoke though I dont think a smoked malt or peat malt was used, some yeast strains can impart a smokeiness to a beer.  The 7% alcohol is beautifully supressed. Was full bodied and had a smooth enjoyable mouthfeel.
Draft. Dare I say, an easy drinking Scotch Ale? At 7%! Wow, this stuff is great. Roasted yumminess with heavy chocolate and toffee notes.
Nutty ruddy toffee roasty smoke...but not so rich that you can barely finish one.  I just love this beer and drink it often.
Complex woodey, chocolate and other aromas, nice dark brown/red almost purple.  Thin head that faded.  Nice chocolate malted flavors.  Very unique beer, I really like this.

Poured an iced-tea brown with a thin head.  Carbonation was low-medium, and the aroma consisted of coffee and other assorted roasted malts.  Taste followed the aroma, but also included some chocolate.  Finish was slightly bitter from the hops.

12 fl oz. brown bottle, from heemer77. Poured red brown, sizable off white head. Leaves a wonderful coating of lace in the glass. Aroma is malty, light roasted note, lots of chocolate. Also noticable hops. Seemed a bit nutty, big dark malt sweetness combined with chocolate. Hoppy finish. Big mouthfeel - lots of body.

12 oz bottle.   Pours really dark.  Not porter or stout dark, but its close.  Very small whitish head, dissipates quickly.  Malty aroma.  Malty taste too.  Chocolatey.  Coats the mouth almost.  Good stuff
Had this one bottled. Rich, almost smoky, quite maltywith notes of chocolate and clove.  Not bad.

I sense a pleasant aroma which has malts and hops in it. My nose tells me this is a very complex brew. My mouth tells me it is very full and has a good balance of everything thrown in. It has a bit of a kick as it heads down my throat but the flavor makes me want more. So far this isnt my favorite of the Three Floyds beers as I find it a bit too burnt for my likings. The finish almost has a tobacco-resiny flavor to me. But its not a bad beer overall. The only thing that offends my malt-loving taste buds is the after taste. Otherwise, I could drink much more fo this one.

Mahogany color with a light head.  The aroma is Smokey, caramel, with malt.  The flavor is similar with a malty, smoky, lightly sweet taste.  The maltiest brew from 3F Ive tasted.  The body is medium and watery with a slightly syrupy finish.  The malt, as I said, is the name of the game in this one.  Not too bad.

Pours a deep ruby with brown tinges.  Medium sized off white head lingers nicely.  Nice combination of different malt aromas with a slight hop backing.  Slightly sweet nose is quickly overcome by rich malty flavors of roast, toast, and caramel.  The hops poke through to provide an earthy note and some residual bitterness to crisp the edges.  The finish is toasty, with muted hop flavors complementing nicely.  Mouthfeel is silky and somewhat full without being heavy.

Bottle. A good reason to visit Indiana is to buy 3F brews. This is a very good version of this style. Very complex aroma and flavor of roasted malt and hops. Full body with long pleasent finish. Great brew.

This poured out a light brown with a strong reddish hue when the light hit it. It had a decent sized beige head form that dropped quickly leaving sticky sheets of lace to decorate the glass. Very strong chocolate malty smell rises from the glass that is backed by a slightly sweet fruit presence. The warmer the brew gets the more the chocolate seems to stand front and center. There are also notes of a slight earthy hoppiness that seem to emerge now and then. The sweet malt hits the palette first with ripe dark fruitiness that seems covered in a slightly bitter dark chocolate. There is a bittersweet aftertaste that is pleasant and lasts for a while. Alcohol adds a little bite that comes out when it warms. Mouthfeel is about medium with good carbonation and a smooth feel over the tongue. Drinkability is good, this goes down easy and I could definitely handle a few more.

From a bottle, poured dark, dark brown with a think white head.  Bready aroma of caramel, brown sugar and some fruity notes.  Flavor of stale brown sugar with a dry, astringent, scottish bite to it and a medium body.

On tap @ 3F. Served in the pint glass I brought. Dark brown, off white head. Caramel, spice, malty aroma. Flavor is caramel and dark roasted malt. The review sucks because it was my last after drinking at 3F for several hours. I have a 6 pack bought at the brewery, I will re-rate.

This is really outstanding.  Very dark red beer with a full, tan head.  Aromas of malt, pepper, cloves, and rotting fruit. Flavor is predominately sweet malt, with some sweet fruit and a chalkly, dry aftertaste.  Heavy.

big hop scent w/ hints of malt and a weak scotch.  Pours a nice dark copper color w/ a large fluffy white head that laced pretty well.  Palate is medium body well carbonated and creamy.  Flavor was a hopful front w/ a light malt and hints of scotch or scotch barelling in the finish and a light alcohol flavor.  Overall a great beer.

Crap- 7%?  For some reason I thought this was just a regular 5% scottish ale.  Does have a moderate to full body though.  Pours a clear dark amber with a low but lasting beige head.  Low carbonation.  Aroma is well balanced between earthy and floral hops and crystal and roasted malts.  More hop aroma than most scottish ales, but not overwhelming- a nice addition.  Flavor is sweet smooth and malty backed up in the finish with a fair amount of bitterness, but the main idea is the full malt and slight roasted flavors.  Nice smooth finish.

not much head, dark color but since i was drinking from a plastic cup, im not sure i got the full understanding of the appearance.  i thought i caught a bite of coffee in the aroma.  although it was a touch bitter, it was too sweet.  an oily, slick palate.

Lots of baked caramel, dark chocolate and spice in the aroma.  Very tempting deep ruby appearance as well.  This beer is a real  mouthfull - big body with a great balance.  As the beer comes to temperature, a hop combo becomes present as well.  The creamy malts really deliver to balance the brew.  Smooth finish to another great beer from 3F.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2005 Mahogany-brown with a fluffy,khaki,head. Aroma is malt,dominated with maybe a bit of hop. Velvet,smooth,texture but still quite thick. Great melody of flavors. Quite nutty,with caramel and lots of earthy(peat,wood,smoke) notes. Finish is malty,and hops are only for balancing,but are noticeable. The more I drink of this one,the more I want. Extremely smooth and easy drinking for a larger,bodied beer. Very flavorful and interesting when fresh. Havent had this since they started bottling own beer,Ill be getting this often.  Glad I live in Indiana,for once...

Copper brown in color.  Splotchy grey head.  Aroma consists of caramel, hay and oats.  Flavor is of sweet caramel, toasted pecans, barley, oats and rye.  Balance favors the malts - caramel and rye seem to take the cake.  Dry, nutty and a tad spicy finish.  Honest rendition, not all that impressive.

Robert the Bruce of Scotland looks crazy.  This is a very good ale.  Little bit of spiciness in it, but it is mainly sweet malt.  Hops are present and provide a nice balance to the beer.  Beautiful looking and just an easy drink in every way.  A wonderful brew.

Poured reddish/brown with a creamy head.  There was a good circle on the side of the glass.  Sweet nose of butterscotch, nuts, pine and caramel.  The pine is quite present in the taste and is similar to the Alpha Klaus Porter.  This was very nice.  This style is pretty good.

Pours red/brown with a big bubbly cream beige head. Nutty toasted caramel aroma. Very malty and earthy with piney hops. Nice mouthfeel. Burnt sugar, citrus, chocolate and dried fruit. Wood and whiskey notes. Clean hopped finish. Very good.

Pours a rusty brown/ mahogeny with a 1/4 inch head that stays. Aroma is of citrusy hops, caramel, and a slight smoke and leather. Flavor is caramel, roasted malt, rich naked malts (like sucking on a few kernals of nicely roasted malt) and a mild but present hoppy kick. Very light bodied for such robust flavor yet not in an unsatifing way. Goes down very easy and leaves a nice rich aftertaste.

From the bottle this pours a very clear copper color with a medium white head. Aroma of brown sugar and some oxidation. Taste was very smooth with a very mild maltiness to it, lighter body with a bit of spiciness to the finish. I think this bottle was a bit oxidized and it gave it a very flat malt taste and thinner body.

This might sound odd, but I think of this as kind of my Celebrator substitute. The flavor profile, I swear, is strikingly similar. Theres a bit of smokiness in there somewhere, thats the Scottish part I guess. But its got that wonderful dark malty sweetness with just enough hops to keep the sweetness in check.

Dark mahogany pour under a rocky and long lasting khaki head.  Brown sugar, toffee, roasted malt, dirt and dark fruit in the aroma.  Well balanced big flavors of spice, chocolate, caramel and lightly roasted malt with a subtle hop backbone.  Finish was sweet but crisp with a very "English Ale" coppery component.  Glad I found this locally - looking forward to more.
it has an odd flavor that seems to be found in a few other scotish ales, it makes you want to take another sip just to see if you can figure out what it is

Coca-cola coloured beer; thin yellow-brown head, very fast gone. Creamy, roasted malts nose, cake-like, with an inevitable touch of American hops, and (suggestion?) blooming heather. Finishes pure caramel, like just melting sugar. Hop-bitter takes the lead in the taste, to be followed by mellowing maltsyrup sweetness. Theres bark, says MartinT, but I have to think of black cardemom pods, and quinine. Some more spicyness - pure cinnamon, maybe, thats bark too. Finishes a bit metallic, the malts not resurfacing again. Thick, nearly viscous, not thin at all. Bit harsh aftertaste. I wonder about my bottle. My impression is much thicker, more bitter beer than what I read - more 3FL? Thanks to Craig/Jamie for this one.
Pours like a dark-brown ale. A malt lovers dream with a light, clean finish. Slightly smokey taste with hints of molasses. Highly recommended!
Alcohol is in the air, thats my first immpression from the aroma.  It pours a very deep amber with minimal head.  A very strong taste, plenty of hops, with a dry finish.  It tastes strong.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2005 Deep red color with a creamy tan head. Roasted, robust flavor with a hint of smoke yet a little sweet at the end.  It finishes with a good feel in your mouth. If I didnt know better I would have sworn it was from Scottland.

Bottle. deep copper body, small white head. aroma is heavily malt, but also some caramel and yeast. big full body, silky smooth palate. sweet and predominately malty. Superb balance. Great first impression for Three Floyds, Im looking forward to trying some more. Thanks a lot to MrManning for hooking me up.
A deep amber color with a full tan head. A faint smell of olives in the aroma is the only drawback. The flavor is a roasted malt with a good hops presence.

This beer is very different than the traditional Scottish Ales I have drank imported from Scotland.  The nose is very intense of malt, Munich?  The hop bitterness is pronounced, but melds well with the body and mouthfeel of this beer.  This is definitely an American version of a classic British beer style.  This is the first beer I have tasted from this brewery, but it will not be the last.

Thanks to my friend Diana for picking this up for me.
Pours a dark copper body, topped by a beige, medium sized, foamy white head. Aromas are huge malts, brown sugar, biscuits and bread. Candy too. Taste is sweet brown sugar, huge malts, mild smoke notes, bready, earthy. Good! Finish is slightly boozey, sweet and bitter. Good overall example of a scotch ale. 3F does it again!
Solid brown Scotch ale.  Very enjoyable and earthy.  Great malt character.  Wonderfully blended.
super dark, thin head which doesnt really last.. not alot of lacing.. good aroma.. malty taste.. smooth smooth smooth    nice lingering aftertaste

dark brown body with a thin layer of cream colored head.  aroma is sweet and heavy with malts, with hints of roasted caramel.  taste was very malty, with the chocolates only coming in on the aftertaste, body is rather full, with a chewy mouthfeel. i think the chocolates will come out more as this warms up.  the flavors are very smoothly blended and only a bit of bit on the end.
Definately a creamy chocolaty beer with a smooth taste, but a bit of a bite in the aftertaste

Bottle.  Pours a deep mahogany with thin tan head.  Aroma is of chocolate, caramel and roasted malts.  Smooth.  Medium-bodied.  Taste is all roasty chocolatey malts and a touch of toffee.  Some stale tastes.  This may be another beer past its date though its still not too shabby the way it is.

Bottle, from Rileys in Madison.  One of the most beautiful beers Ive poured in a while.  Deep amber, earthy, nice frothy head that lasts for the entirity of the beer.  Aromas of nice roasted malts with a distinctively smoky character.  Taste is complex...tobacco, smoky malts, notes of dark bitter chocolate.  A pleasure.  Id gladly go back to Medieval times if this is what they drank...

Slight acidic flourish glances the tongue.  Sticky texture coats the mouth and and a whiskey sourness is quite noticeable.  Ends with charred grains and faint hops.  My favorite character of this beer, however, is the gorgeous deep, deep, ruby-red color.  Wow.

Bottle, from Somerville Super Saver. Ok nose, carmel, rootbeer, little bready yeasty, maybe a little tobacco or something. Clean brownish orange color. Good head that faded quickly. Sweet roasty flavors, same as aroma, but better. Tad peanut/almond. Medium body, lite creamy mouthfeel, bitter sweet finish. Tasty brew, Kinda
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: (Bottle)  Pours dark amber-brown body with an average-sized creamy beige head.  Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, and nuts.  Roasted malt flavor.
Deep garnet body with a thick tan head.  Aroma is heavy on roasted malts and caramel.  Flavor has components of bitter chocolate, roasted barley and some sweetness.  Finishes dry and full.  Nice.

Large, abundant head of light tan bubbles.  Great carbonation.  Rich and malty aroma with plenty of smoke, roasted grains and peat.  Just what a good scotch ale should have.  Maybe a hint of dark chocolate also.  Color is a dark mahagony brown.  Flavor is quite smooth.  Not overpowering with the malts.  More roasted grains and smoke.  Lingering smoke taste.  Hides its alcohol well.  Dry roasty finish.  A very good scotch ale.

Pours reddish brown with slight tan head.  Nose is of smoked malt with underlying chocolatey notes.  Flavor is sweet and malty, quite robust.  Some fruityness as it warms.  Nice faint bittersweet finish.
Brown color (kind of like Coke), with a tan head. Aromas of sweet malt, brown sugar, hops and fruit. Flavor is malt, smoke, hops, and brown sugar.
Malt smell fruits.  All goes in and down very nice.  Bitter-sweet and a little hoppy at the end.

Bottle. Pours Brown in color with a little head. Malty caramel aroma. Well balanced beer.  Big caramel flavor. Smooth.  Palate is thick.
Nice beer.
Pours brown with little head.  Aroma is of roasted malts.  Flavor has alts and a bitter nut flavor.  Expect more from Three Floyds though.

Nice clean dark red color with a thin head on top.  The aroma is pure maltiness.  The flavor, also, pure maltiness.  This is one heckuva malty brew, and I like that.  Very caramely and smooth taste.  There is hints of roasted and chocolatey malts.
Tap at Isaac Newtons. Brick red, clear, tan head. Malty carmel and hop aroma. Flavor is big with carmel malts, and heavy with American hops. Bitter finish. Thick palate. Reasonably drinkable.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Dark chestnut color, thin tan head. Very malty all around, pretty sweet but not overly so. Hints of dark fruits and maybe even some chocolate. Sure there were some hops but it really is the sweetness that is the main star here. Medium to full body. Very good.

Thanks to Wohlfs for the bottle. This my 2nd scotch ale and so far I love this style. Just a decent malt aroma, had a burnt sugar smell to it. Very nice sweet malt taste with some caramel? When it warmed it almost taste like tea. The weaker aroma hurts the score a little. But overall a very easy drinking brew.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep amber with a wispy tan head.  Heavy malt scent with hints of roasted nuts and cherries.  Wonderful malt taste with an extremely smooth finish. Certainly one worth looking for.  An excellent brew!!

Deep scarlet brown color with a thin dark tan head that slips away leaving a light broken skim and thin collar. Lacing sticks in minimal thick strings.

Aroma is of maple syrup and deep dark caramel, nice deep sweetness to it but lacks a bit of strength. Notes of char or smoke leak out.

Taste has a premium maltyness to it engaging an interesting little play between sweet caramel and roasted grains with the roastyness winning out in most sips. Pale leafy hop notes and touches of char bring through to the finish in a well mannered disposition and placement that happens late across the back of the palate. I like that part alot, nice finisher.

Feel is a solid medium body maintaining a decent creamyness and malt laden thickness that moderately coats with a smooth left over oilyness. Finish is nice with a lingering char and leafy, deep pine hop tone.

A favorable beer that can be handled fairly easily, but after a couple it may start to effect the noggin as the 9% is hidden very well.
Dark red/light brown in colour, no head, very little aroma, strong coffee flavour with mild hop bitterness, warm mouthfeel. true to the style

An opaque brown beer with just a glimmer of red off the bottom of the glass and a medium tan head.  The high ABV is evident right in the aromatic mist; shockingly light character initially ... very nice first impression.  Smooth and mellow chocolate syrup almost ... pretty nice.  What a great combo!  Excellent brew.

Bottle, thanx Duane. Poured cloudy and red/brown with fizzy tan head. Immediate malty aroma. Earthy and woody, pleasant and inviting. Wow, chocolate malt all over. The lacing is smooth and Slick with a mid-body and oily mouthfeel. bitter sweet chocolate after taste.  Caramel comes forward as do the hops as this warms.  The slightly higher 7% alcohol gives this and extra something, as does the adequate and not overpowering carbination. This is an amazing brew, being more of a malt guy, not a hop head. This was enjoyed and I cant believe I one have one :(
I keep coming back to this one...I love the supremely rich maltiness in aroma, mouthfeel and flavor.   Cant see me ever getting tired of this baby.
Pours a garnett color, with brown hues and a tan head. Aroma is earthy, sweet malt and grass. Flavor is hoppy, somewhat thin, but a decent roasted malt body.

Pours a thin off-whiteor tan head, with irregular lacing.  Little molasses aroma.  Medium-dark red brown beer.  Taste is hoppily bitter up front, a pit smoky, then a long lingering finish where the, chocolate and slightly roasted flavors emergethen some more late smokiness.  Just a hint of this is very nice.  A bit oily on the toungue.  A bit too heavily hopped for the style, but that makes it more quaffable.
Pours a clear, yet dark, brown color body with a smooth looking tan head.  Has an earthy aroma with a nice malt sweetness.  Big carmel malt flavors.  Taste a bit smoked.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2006 Deep red color without much head to speak of.  Plenty of malt in the flavor.  Slightly odd aftertaste but overall quite a nice example of the style. 8/3/7/3/17RERATE: Very dark red with no head. Aroma is dark earthy sweetness. Cant really smell any smokiness. Nice body, but really not too much else going on.
Red/brown color with a small off white head. Sweet malty aroma with a touch of caramel. Flavor was malt, peat, black tea. Dry, bitter finish.
UPDATED: JUL 22, 2007 Brown pour almost no head at all. Caramel taste bigtime with some roasted character with more sugar and maple syrup.

bottle. a wonderful Christmas gift!  reddish brown in color with a decent head.  robust malt flavors and some hops noticed as well.  balance was almost perfect, but not entirely there.  still a very nice brew, wish I had more than one bottle.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2004 Thanks Wohlfs for bringing in. Chicory and roasted malt. Doesnt all quite work out that great, but different as you would expect from this brewery. Layers of taste that evolve as you work through the bottle. Mild taste, medium to even thin mouthfeel. Barley doesnt work

Not exactly what I would have expected from a traditional Scotish Ale. Dark amber, with some grey undertones. A sweet roasty malt start, a slightly metalic middle, and a lovely fruity, bittersweet, roasted finish. All in all, while not exactly what would be considered in style, this a another well-made brew from FFF.

Pours hazy red in color with little head. Smells sweet, earthy and of caramel. Excellent body and mouthfeel. Tastes moderately sweet with some roasted overtones and tartness. A little hops in the finish. Lacking in peat or smoke for the style in my opinion.
Bottle.  Nice molasses/chocolate malt aroma.  Clear light brown color with small head.  Strong chocolate malt flavor with mild hops finish.  Very nice and very drinkable
On tap. Poured a dark reddish color with a small off white head. Malty sweet aroma and tastes. Caramel and toffee. Light spices.

Poured a dark amber with an off-white head.  Decent hoppy aroma.  Slight malty taste with a hint a smoke, with an average body.  Flavor was rather thin.  Ive definitely had better scotch ales.  My first Three Floyds, and I was rather disappointed by this one.

Not my favorite style of beer, but this one isnt bad. Pours out a reddish brown color with a decent sized head. The aroma isnt overpowering but gives notes of roasted malt. The taste isnt overlly complex, but it is smooth. It has a carmel/chocolate flavor but the palate isnt overlly impressive.
not a lot of scotch ales out there that i like... tooo sweet for me.  but i have to say, to the Floyds three...thats a lip smackin good beer.
pours a reddish color with a medium head.  aroma is chocolate and flavor is the same.  caramel maltiness is secondary.  palate is a bit watery.  this is ok.

Deep mahogany with loads of ruby red. 
Large thick head of off white cream on top. Wish it stayed a little longer.
Lots of malt in the aroma with some hop presence too.
Creamy rich and very smooth with sweet malt and caramel going from the beginning to the end. I dont detect any peated malt so I dont know about the style, but this is a very pleasant beer overall and a very easy one to drink.
Sweet chocolate aroma and rich pleasant palate.  A fresh ale with many promising attributes.  The chocoloate color belies the definite sweet aroma.  Smooth to the end, this ale is worth repeating.
Bottled 12 oz. Dark brown. Sweet malty taste but very little peaty taste. Ok but not as good as skullsplitter.
Nothing spectacular.  Another solid Three Ffloyds brew but bottom of their line.  Full body and tastes more like an average chocolate porter than a scotch ale.
Dark amber color,fresh full slightly hoppy aroma, a full nicely blended malt hop taste, a little heavy on the malt, very flavorful. Anothe 3F gem
Fantastic nose of caramel and toffee.  Rich aromas lead to a balanced sweetness.  Not overly heavy.  Very pleasant to drink.  A nice representation of the style.  I really enjoyed this beer.
Mahogany brew with moderate beiga head. Great sweet malt aroma.  Taste is a little less sweet and a little more hoppy than the originals from Scotland.

Ruby colored beer with a disappearing light brown head. Sweet yeasty and caramelly aroma with some spices. Distinctive Three Floyd aroma, could it be the yeast? Fruity tones and a bit of alcohol also. Flavor is rather sweet malty and fruity, mild with a thin finish. Toffee notes and hints of pepper. Nice and easy without beeing spectacular. Thanks Steve (wohlfs) for trading me this one.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2005 Dark caramel color with a thin off-white head.  Sort of like a light spicy porter.  Smooth and creamy with a good malt character.  Not a session beer but good stuff.(3)
3/12/05 Had on cask and this did not work at all.  The cask version had a definite alcohol aroma and taste that was distracting for this style.  Also the grassy hops became overpowering for any malts to come through.(2.1)
A nice pour with a brownish/ orange color.This is one of the better scotch ales i have had.medium malt with some wood and nuts.Very easy dri medium bodied beer.

Thanks to wholfs.  Ruby, creamy head. Some citrus hops, cotton candy malt.  Sweet  earthy malt, a nice progression from bitter to slightly citrus.  Sweet orangey finish.  Kind of reminds me of a really smooth barleywine

Bottle. I generally dont like Scotch Ales but I dig this one. Big body that is nice. Flavor notes that come out are malt, raisin, candi sugar, apple, straw, some light chocolate, and grape. This finishes beautiful and has just the right amount of bitterness. Quite nice. Maybe the worlds most perfect session beer.

Hazed brick. Fluffy, off-beige rocky foam. Gorgeous aroma of beet sugar, assorted berries, roasted hazelnuts, and unspent grains. Slightly nutty with cocoa-dusted malt hulls and some Crystal firmness. Puffy, yet perfectly creamy carbonation. Beefy malts immediately add girth to the already-puffy body. Malts turn immensely bready and gain more depth from the cane sugar and cocoa roughness. Minimal earthiness, other than a mild mossy twang, gives way to a glut of chocolate. Chocolate steadily richens, overriding the splash of plummy fruitiness, malt-enhancing acidity and oxidation, which accentuate every aspect of the malt. Remarkably fresh spent malt flavor and creamed coffee underpins the everlasting cocoa-dusted crushed grains flavor, which lasts well into the finish. Surprisingly tame hop profile for this brewery, which makes way for a flavorsome showcase of their complex, well-extracted, high-lovibond malts. And to boot, this is worlds better now that its bottle conditioned and no longer contract brewed in MN.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle:  Aroma is malty with caramel and coffee combination with slight alcohol.  Pours a darkj reddish-brown with a tan head that struggles to ever become anything.    Very little lacing.  Nice caramel flavor with a slight hop and even more slight coffee in the finish.  Alcohol is hardly noticeable, just a touch in the finish.

10.05.04  12oz bottle, thanks to Marinaro500.  Deep garnet pour, glowing; little head fades to trace.  Subtle malts and peaty earth on the nose, floral undertones.  Funny, even with this beer, the sacley little floaties are visible that I see in all FFF beers.  Flavors are roasty, prune, apple butter, nutty.  Reminds of a lighter version of a strong ale.  Pretty interesting stuff, not at all what I expected from this hop-happy brewery.  Thanks for the bonus, Joe!

Poured deep brown with thick decadent tan head...smelled roasty malt, hops...taste is malts, with sugar, caramel, mild smokiness and a hint of chocolate...much hoppier than I expected...very bitter finish with heavy alcohol accents...

Lightly Rich Brown Coloring.  Aroma May Have Some Pine To It.. But Very Rich and Heavy Overall. Sweet MaltsSweet Roasted Flavor..Could be Burnt Caramel.. Good Malts.  Some Bitter Chocolate.. Some Hops at the End...Dry on The Tongue and Bitter.  Like if you Had Just Licked Pine Sap off the Bark..  Very Charactable Scotch Ale!
dark amber hue. very smooth beer, sweet caramel with a bit of hops coming in the finish. a nice malty break from the IPAs i had been having.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2006 Medium brown body with a sandy head. Warm caramel nose, a touch of brown sugar, and fruit. Aroma suggests a candied apple. Malty flavor with an unexpected acid note that keeps this clean on the palate. Also has a roasty edge and a distinct hop presence. A solid Scotch Ale, but a little on the roasty side.

super dark and rich dark malty, bubble-gum aromas.  some smoke too.  lots of malt with light bitterness, super-strong presence of toast and butter.  quite good, but its got sort of a dusty taste that detracts just a bit.  enjoyable.

Damn, now this is what Im talkin about!  Very rich, malty sweet aromas with carmel and toffee and a little bit of smoke.  Great flavors.   Silky smooth body and awesome malty goodness.  Finishes soft and a little sweet.  Damn good.  Probably the best scotch ale Ive had.

pours a dark brown with a fast disipating head. roasty coffee/malt aroma. primarily roast malt taste that has a nice hop side that comes out later in the taste. i just noticed this is 7%, it is very well hidden. this is an enjoyable brew, thanks for the bottles Bunkypop.
Amber brown w/light off white head. Hop nose w/roasted notes and molasses. Heavey weight w/bitter sweet carmel finish. Carmel, pine, molasses, nuts, and cherry. Great beer.

Reddish brown.Hoppy nose.Piney.When you sniif this you can almost sense that you are in a virgin stand of pine trees.Not standing with a virgin in pine trees!!! This is a good beer.No alcohol presence but the piney flavor here isnt so strong that you cant get some malts and yeast.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour.  Quickly dissipating tan head.  Interesting unique malt/spicy aroma.  A little yeasty as well.  Heavy, but pleasant malt taste - well balanced - the mouthfeel was surprisingly crisp for such a malt heavy beer.  Nice hop kick at the end.  I enjoy this style, and this example was one of the best Ive had.

Bottle: Deep, dark ruby red beer with a tiny off-white head.  Aroma: Earthy, scotch, peat smoke, caramel, coffee.  Flavor: Initiatlly dark roasted, earthy, malt hits the tongue.  This is followed by bitter hops, unsweetened chocolate, earth, dirt, roasted malt.  Interesting overall bitterness with what I can only describe as an almost overwhelming sweetness swept under the rug the entire time.  I couldnt have asked for better carbonation and mouthfeel on this one.  Very nice.

Dark red beer with very little head.  Aroma is slight but roasty.  Beer seems lighter than expected in terms of mouthfeel.  Good roast flavor not as much malt taste as expected.  Good beer but, not one of the top scottish style ales in my book
Pours deep red with very little, short lasting off-white head. Nose is malt and coffee. Taste is malt, a nice amount of hops, some coffee, some caramel... and a decent smooth finish. Not bad overall.

Dark amber scotch colour, off-white ring. Very light aroma of earthy hops, single-malt scotch, caramel malt. Light acidity on the palate, earthy, oily, light leafy bitterness. Nothing particular, despite all due respect, this would definitely be rated at least .2 lower if it werent a 3F. The creamy medium-full mouthfeel and soft carbonation is great though.

12 oz. brown, longneck bottle. No freshness date seen anywhere.
Poured out a deep chocolate brown color, with amber highlights.
Thick tan colored head at first, that slid back to a thick lacing down the sides of the glass. Aromas are of chocolate malts, malted milk balls, Brachs caramel candies, and slight earthy hops.
Tastes are mostly of malts, with chocolate espresso notes as well.
Yeasty to a fault, but a clear brew all the same. The flavors of the yeast are there, but none of the cloudiness associated with it.
Caramel candies and warming alcohols make up the remainder of the flavors. Very warming, slight, brief but fleeting hops bitterness at the very end of the beer. Finishes somewhat sweet, but well balanced. It could use a touch more hops, however, for the style.
A decent effort, but not the best Ive had.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 As advertised, if you like malts, youll like this beer.  It has a nice reddish-brown color with a healthy, lasting head and the malt aroma dominates.  Tempered only slightly with hops, this gives a huge malty mouthful that goes down oh so sweetly.  Great brew.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Lawn, IL<font size=-1>
Yum! Now this is Scottish style ale. Sweet and malty with a perfect bitter accent to tweek the balance.

Bottle Pours a nice clear mahogany with a modest off white head.  Good even lacing. Aroma is a rich slightly sweet, pitted fruit and dark malts.  Flavors are a nice balance of malt and slight chocolate notes.  Feel is medium heavy, and the finish is very smooth and soft.  Very little bitterness.
Quite good.

This is a top notch beer for malt lovers.Very,very flavorfull,and malty with enough hops to keep it in balance.
Looks about as good in a glass as you can expect a beer to look.
Kinda high in the abv department,so be carefull.
Has a mild aroma,but what aroma it has is very nice.

Dark brown color with a red tint. Small head and an excellent flavor. A great ale to sit back and relax with. Didn;t really taste the chocolate, but the hops and malt were very present and the finish was spectacular.

Hmm... opened with barely a squeek and poured with no head.  Its carbonated, but barely.  I guess shipping can take its toll :P  Pours an elegant, crystal clear-but-dark brown that shines red when held up to light.  Very neat.  Aroma is very mild, but thats probably due to the utter lack of a head I got.    A vigorous swirl at half glass pulls up dates, chocolate, smoke and malt.  Nice.  Flavor is mellow and rich- chocolate again, malt, smoke, dark bread, caramel.  Again, its a bit flat, and   the finish seems to coat my mouth substantially.  All in all a good beer from FFF... but whos suprised about that?
Deep brown/black. Nice tan head. Caramel malt aroma. Nice malty flavors with some toffee, and a little kick of hops at the finish.

Got this one out of a bottle.  Nice colored head, brownish and creamy, which left some lace.  The color of the beer itself is a nice robust dark brown.  Almost no aroma whatsoever from this bottle.  The taste has a bit of caramel and some chocolate, and a bit of smokiness.  You can really taste the malt and its also a little more on the bitter side than most Scottish Ales Ive had, which is good.  Goes down and puts a warmth in your belly.  I still like Skullsplitter a little more, but Three Floyds is really doing Indiana proud.

Dark chestnut brown w/ mahogany hue. Tight, creamy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, caramel w/ hints of coffee & smoke. Full, oily body. Lightly roasty chocolate, toffee, caramel & molasses flavour  w/ some earthy, spicy hops & a long bitter finish.

Chocolate and coffee in the aroma, ruby, small toffee head. Tastes like a melted tootsie roll, some orange hints also. Delightfully rich and bitter. Terrific!

 Thank You joey_capps.

clear dark brown with red highlights, thin white head, sweet barley malt aroma thats slightly coffee-ish, flavor is alcoholic with strong accents of chocolate, thin palate which leads to a dry finish thats a little on the thin side, but the label is pretty tight, Bobby Bruce can rage but hes a little over rated in my book.

(draft)  A nice dark brown color that revealed red when help up to light.  I thought the taste was very good, though there seemed to be a slight gritty feel until the head had dissipated.  The slightly bitter finish made me want to drink again to get back to the nice flavor.  Not recommended on an empty stomach, as I wanted another pint but had to decline.

pours a very carbonated deep amber/red, sightly hazy.  nose is malty, underpinned by a mellow roartiness.  flavor is very smooth, dominated by malt notes and a mellow chocolaty-ness.  palate is excellent, with none of the stickiness that so often accompanies malty beers.  a pleasure to drink-lush w/out being overbearing.

Great malty aroma of chocolate, hazelnut, caramel, and hints of coffee.  Brown with red-orange tints, thin beige head.  Interesting blend of chocolate and caramel malt with fruity hop flavors, bit of a roasty finish.  Medium body, medium carbonation.  Great aroma on this beer, a little too much hop flavor, though.  I like my Scotch ales to be all malt with little to no hop character.

Pours a dark brown with an off-white somewhat thin head.  Malty aroma with a light whiskey aroma swirling around and a little alcohol detected too.  A sweet, sharp malty flavor with a faint whiskey  aftertaste and some chocolate.   The sweetness here is prevelant.  Overall palatable but uneventful.  Just OK., but worth trying.

Bottled. 
Muddy grey/orange colour. Aroma is vague, a little chocolate maybe. Flavour is fruity and sugary. Maybe a bit flat but arent all Scotch Ales? Pretty good.

Light grapes and wood aroma.
Brown color, low carbonation,  low head.
Brown sugar flavors.
Light body, somewhat flatish.
Maybe the sample was too small, but I found it to be kind of boring.
ah, another great beer from three floyds.  this one, as the description says is definately "a true malt-lovers delight." but it also has a satisfying slight hoppy finish to balance it out nicely.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2008 This one surprised me. Very pretty deep Bock-ish coloring. At first smell, like a Brown ale. First taste is the same. Once I get past the dark malts, the same hops that are used in the AK are used here, though to a lesser degree. This is how a dark malt based beer should taste. No weird grainy tastes, just the finer nuances of the malts, complemented with a luxurious hop complex. Simply wonderful.

Bottled: Dark amber coloured. Light beige head. Malt, butterfatness, some sweetness and a light touch of hops in the aroma. Light caramel, bread, hops and some spices in the flavour. Medium bodied, but finishes a litlle weak. Some bitterness is present on the palate.

Deep deep amber,thin head,not much in the nose except a little hops and sweetness. Not as sweet as it smelled. Decent mouthfeel but the taste was basically caramelly, a bit bitter and dryish with only a hint of malt. Ok but not impressed. I will give em a thumbs up for hiding the ABV but then again 7% is not that high.

Murky brown with little head. I could smell the hops as well as the malt which isnt normal for me. Has a roasted smell with a hint of chocolate. Very smooth with the initial malty taste dying fast. Taste is rather bland other than decent malts with a hint of chocolate and possibly raisin with a weak finish that doesn't hide the alcohol.

Poured the color of the bottle with some surprising level of carbonation.  The aroma had the prune/raisin smell of a belgina bruin.  The malt quantity was NOT as advertised, as the alcohol tore right through the flavor.  There is a "roastiness" to this, that reminds of an old-style ale.  There doesnt appear to be any sweetness or biterness, yet the dark chocolate hints were there.  Sir Robert did finish with a lively kick, but alas it might have been his last kick down my throat.
Deep copper/brown with a beige, foamy head.  Aroma is malty, fruity, and a touch of citrus/hops.  Medium bodied with a creamy smooth texture.  Full, robust flavor, sweetness, maltiness.  Excellent.

Pours a deep brown with a slight off-white head.  Aromas of grass, caramel, and roasted malt.  Mouthfeel is a little thin for the style and light-bodied??? a surpsrise considering most scotch ales seem to be at leat medium bodied , if not full..  Flavors of caramel, raisins and a slight prune flavor.   A dissapointment from one of the better brewers in the world.

12oz bottle  Dark brown/amber, fizzy, no sustained head or lace.  Big dark malt aroma, some roasty slightly smoky notes too.  Full bodied, bittersweet malty beer. Id agree with Eyedrink it did remind me of an Old Ale a bit.  Some nice chocolate, roasty accents.  Very enjoyable beer with a nice lingering malt finish.  Thanks to jsquire for sending this one my way!

Rating # 525
Major thanks to TheBeerGod for sending me this brew not once but twice! The first bottle was murdered when it was violently pushed out of my closet by a bottle of DFH WWS. Mike caught wind of the tragedy and sent me a back up bottle,  Thanks Very Much, Bro! 
 Aged for 7 months.
Pours with a deep and rich cherry wood amber body. The head is a creamy tan cap that sits atop. Aroma is malty.. Full with  thick fruits and butterscotch and toffee. Notes of apple, pears, peaches, apricots, plums, figs, and a toasty toffee malt are in abundance here! A hint of coffee, lightly kilned chocolate malt adds some smokiness as well. Those toasted malts and ripened fruits are insanely delicious! Wow, the body is oily and buttery delectable and hospitable! Man, this is earthy with a toasty biscuit quality Damn, the Bruce is Totally Delicious!

UPDATED: APR 21, 2005 I just hate going into a beer with high expectations. 3F is one of my favorite breweries and I finally got hold of this stuff (thanks Gasspasser), and it tasted more like an Old Ale than a Scotch Ale. Yes its malty and it has the 3F trademark hop taste but where is the peat? Bits of chocolate make it nice and sweet and well balanced but seems to be lacking the damn peat.
Had it on tap. A very rich and tasty brew. Lots of malt with chocolate flavors. Also has some hops that mix in well to make this a well balanced, full flavored beer.
Nice thick taste, and a great finish. This is a smooth beer that holds to the writting on the bottle,  malty grandness.
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2004 Looks great, smells great, big juicy, fruity, chocolatey, roasty, toasty malts balanced by assertive yet mild hops.  This is great stuff!

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2004 Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Flavor is that of chocolate and a bit of coffee.  Oh man I love this brew.  It tastes better the second time I sampled it than the first.    3 Floyds have out done themselves with this brew!!

Light malty nose, hazy deep amber, fomay head. Very warm, fruity malt body. Some caramel. Something very Old World about this - like a British ale (only thicker and good). Even got a little butterscotch coming through, but not too much. Dainty spiced end (pepper). Oily mouth feel and not thin at all.

Bottle. Dark brown and ruby, very little head. Aroma has caramel, chocolate, whiskey barrels, tamari, very nice. Medium body, lots of roasted malts, chocolate, hints of smoke, earth. Very quick finish, some sweet stickiness, metallic. Alcohol well masked. More mellow than I expected, but good, especially for a style that is hit or miss for me.

Deep copper pour with a smidgeon of head. Big spots of lace here and there. Toffee and warm biscuits come out first. Traces of alcohol, hops and malts also in the nose. The flavors show the chocolate and roasted malts from the description. Small pepper as well. Bitter end to this one. Tangy palate.

Bronze amber color with light head and some carbonation, moderate lacing for the comparable carbonation. The aroma is malty with some brown sugar sweetness and a very dry, hop note coming through. The flavor is very balanced between the sweet and the hops. The impact of the sweetness is very large but the hops ride it down the palate perfectly, never letting one or the other take center stage. The finish is dry and dusty too with some darker malt notes rounding it out. Very unique scottish, good. Thanks Falconseye!

Overall it was a pretty good beer.    It was on my list of beers to buy this weekend but ended up finding it on tap at a local restaurant.  Was a nice amber color, with a small white head.  Taste was filled with malt, caramel and very light coffee.  Not bad overall, probably wont pursue buying in bottle though anymore.
Medium brown orange color, medium frothy head. Butterscotch toffee and malt nose - very light though. Also the flavor is light, malt, raisons and pepper - kind of weak.
